More on labelling our favorite DJs:

 > But if I were, I don't know if I want to be type-cast as far as DJ 
 > style.

 > To some degree we need labels, shorthand handles for a much more 
 > complex
 > reality.  But it's all too easy to cross the line into fixation with
 > labeling.  The map is NOT the territory!

Agreed, simply because how a DJ gets the crowd off goes far beyond simply what
genre of music he's playing.  Keep in mind that within any genre there will be
very good tunes as well as some very trite and mediocre songs as well.  It's
also all up to the DJ to beatmix the tunes properly in addition to picking the
more interesting songs to play in his set.

Maybe if we had a list that had the names of DJs and a comment on whether each
individual DJ had good taste in music or not.  :)

paul.geronca -----------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------- milkweed

Subject: Re: Anthem of the Sun?
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com

Suffering a from a temporary lack of judgement and some rather persuasive
chicas, I went to Anthem of the Sun and even plunked down the $20 for no good
reason that I can think of now... It was at the YMCA @ 240 Golden Gate, a new
and unused location though obvious not bust-free, as it was shut down at
sometime after 3.  This really, really sucks cuz everyone was really gettin
into it and was suddenly dumped onto the streets and pretty much forced to
get in their cars and drive off in front of much police.  There was a very
interesting period, when the music was shut off and we were told that it
would start up again in about 15 minutes.  So everyone sat around in the dark
talking and trying to entertain themselves including some phat freestyle
rapping.  Probably the strongest sense of communal vibe I felt all night.
 The party was shut down conveniently before any of the big DJs could go
on(are Jeno and Garth even back fro NY yet?)  I sincerly hope that Richard
Sun(I'm assuming he's the promoter) never gets to do another party in this
city - I knew better but lots of people don't. Continuing my night of poor
decision making, I got in a car that was going to a party in Oakland.  Turned
out to be Ghost and friends' nitrous gallery/warehouse.  Definately not my
scene, interesting to observe though pretty depressing.  There are some
really lost people out there and I really wish we could pull them back into
something positive but I don't know how.  Overall, an interesting view of
some of the other flavors of SF, but I think I'll stick to the really great
smaller SFR related parties I've been to and of course I await the return of
the Wicked boys - see ya there.

phuture

Subject: Re: Anthem of the Sun?
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com

I think the problem with Anthem of the Sun was that they found
a nice place that was north of Market, close enough to residential
areas so that loud thumping scrathched some of the locals the
wrong way.  There were a couple of noise complaints, which brought
the police.  From there the police and the not so nice Anthem security
just started screaming at people to leave now.  It's really too
bad, because there was a nice vibe going on upstairs, where a good
several hundred were dancing visciously, with the other half of
the main room covered with resting bodies.  The security were
unfriendly from the start, though, and they wouldn't let you
stop on the stairs or in hallways, as they continuously yelled
"keep it moving.." which was a problem as there was no chill out
or even remotely quiet area to pause... which lead many people 
on quests for the quiet areas, only to walk around in circles.
Beyond that, I still had about three hours of good dancing.  Met
enough HAPPY people to make me feel good about the evening.
Didn't feel good about the $20 and rude way they pushed everyone out.
In my opinion, they should've made some attempt at refunding 
part of the money... many but many people were fuming outside, which isn't
a nice way to end an evening.  So be it.  My weekend was doomed
the moment I started looking for the beach party in Santa Cruz.
How did the Santa Cruz party on Saturday go?
I must keep hope that raves will work in SC as that's where I live.

Regards to all...
-john.

Hello, my name is Tony.  No, not DJ Tony, stupid.  I dj under the assumed 
name "fog".  

My particular styles of definable music are:
House Music
Techno
Trance
Super-Tribal-Break-a-Funk
Hard House
Soft house
Ambient Techno
Ambient House
Super-Duper Fast (But not too fast) Deep house
Stoner Disco
Underground Trance
Natural Sounds

In fact, you can call my music whatever you want.  But you won't really 
know what I play until you hear me spin.  And when I buy new records, I 
am not necessarily going to stick to these dreadful parameters.  

Well, now I feel classified, just like a box of cereal.  Won't someone 
please come pour milk on me?

distressed

	id AA14350; Mon, 1 Aug 94 11:14:54 PDT
Received: from pbssi.srv.PacBell.COM by srv.PacBell.COM (4.1/SMI-4.0)
	id AA14862; Mon, 1 Aug 94 11:14:53 PDT
Received: from lizard.srv.PacBell.COM by pbssi.srv.PacBell.COM (4.1/SMI-4.1)
	id AA27444; Mon, 1 Aug 94 11:14:52 PDT
Date: Mon, 1 Aug 94 11:14:52 PDT
From: lxfogel@srv.PacBell.COM (Lee Fogel)
Message-Id: <9408011814.AA27444@pbssi.srv.PacBell.COM>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: weekend report
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

We really weren't gonna do anything this weekend, but Anthem Of the Sun
got us curious, mainly because the new location was so close to home.
We got there a little before 3 and hung out outside a bit, but didn't get 
a good feeling from things.  Paranoid  behavior by the door and our
familiarity with this neighborhood led us to conclude that this party was 
in no way legal to go all nite.  Reports of an  overcrowded nonventilated 
scene from people leaving also helped us decide to not go in.  Had I known 
this was a Richard Sun production, we wouldn't have even bothered.  

Sunday: We went to the World Unity festival at GG Park Band Shell.  We
managed to be entertained by the diversity of people and *some* good
music.  The Band, Trance Mission was notably excellent - ethnic tribal
music, with digideroos, etc. - very trancey and danceable.  We encountered
Mr. Crunch who pointed us towards the other end of the Concourse where
Spaz had set up a small but effective sound system.  A bunch of 
percussionists created some clatter in an attempt to accompany the 
music, but it sounded more like a battle than a fusion.  Oh well,
it was all in the name of world unity where the struggle to forge
harmony often leads to chaos.  Not that I don't mind a little chaos in
my world, but when the goal is harmony/untiy, it can just end up feeling
like a lot of misdirected and wasted energy.

Anyway, there weren't many ravers there, so we never got much of a vibe 
going.  Shoban started DJing and upped the BPMs much to the distress of 
the percussionists who nevertheless flailed away.  But wind caused the 
tonearms to flail all over the place as well.  Anyway, thanx to the Spaz
people for trying - hopefully more publicity next time will get a real
party going.
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
Lee Fogel/\/\/\/\/\eVerything/\Is/\possiBlE/\/\/\/\/\lxfogel@srv.pacbell.com
____________________________________________________________________________

The latest poll taken on sfr, asking the question "what is your favorite 
dj?" shows these results.

Julius Papp - 6.25%
Aaron - 6.25%

Garth - 6.25%

Doran - 12.5%

Undecided - 6.25%

Thanks to all, there will be another poll soon with a less ambiguous 
question.  Many of you were confused as to how many entries I wanted, and 
basically I just wanted one.  

Happy Lucky Charms,

Subject: Re: Anthem of the Sun?
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com

Simon was to come on at 4am and was all phsyched to play, so we get in
around 3:15.  I was surprised to see signs all over  the doors with
"Private Party" written on them.  Was the place already overcrowded?  Was
this a way to keep the prying eyes of law-enforcement distanced?  No sooner
had we arrived when someone came up to Carlos and said shut the music down
for a half an hour until the cops leave.  I ran downstairs to see what was
_really_ going on and there were three cops on the street yelling at people
to leave or risk arrest.  Nope, it wasn't going to happen so I ran back
upstairs and grabbed our stuff and left.

The space was nice, but unfortunately not bust-free.  The sound system
kinda sucked, but I suppose they were trying to keep the noise level down.

- Steve

Subject: Santa Cruz/Monterey Report...
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Date: Mon, 1 Aug 1994 13:21:37 -0700 (PDT)
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL23]
MIME-Version: 1.0

   The weekend started off with my friends party in Santa Cruz.  He was 
extremely psyched and had a lot of people psyched also.  Unfortunatley, 
he assumed that he would be able to pull it off in the small cove to the 
left of Bonny Doon... 

   However, since the last HUGE FMR at Bonny, the Rangers have been told 
they can arrest people for crossing the train tracks.  This comes from 
So. Pacific Railroad, they have told the Santa Cruz police to arrest 
people for trespassing on the tracks.

   Anyways, the rangers caught my friend WHILE unloading the gear.  They 
gave him a parking ticket and told him they would arrest him and his 
friends and confiscate the sound system if he threw the party... So this 
scared the shit out of him and he didn't have the guts to throw it at 
another site.  He also never changed the voice mail.. ::SMACK!!::  I told 
him I was a bit pissed for having to drive up to SC (With my other 
friends as well) and then have no party and THEN not changing the 
message..  Sigh.. The only thing that Santa Cruz seems to have left are 
some of the smaller, indoor, parties like the sweatbox and the redroom.

   So I slept most of Saturday, in preperation for our Cloud Factory 
party.  We had been planning it for quite some time and had a great 
beach site (a GIANT sand crater from an old sand mine.) two good systems 
and five great DJ's.  Our planning paid off, and even though we had a few 
brushed with the cops (they closed down the map site) and even though it 
was a bit of a walk to the site, we still had almost 100 people show up 
from Monterey and Santa Cruz.  Unfortunatley there weren't too many of 
you from San Jose or San Francisco....... But HOPEFULLY you will all trek 
up here in two weeks for our next party ;)

  Well, if anyone else wants to comment on the party, feel free.. I feel 
kind of biased since I was one of the DJ's and helped throw it.. 

 p.s.

  Many thanks to Bryce for DAT'ing the whole night.  Hopefully we can get 
a four or five tape set out of the evening in a few months... maybe ;)

 Peace..

-Ernie

Subject: great weekend!
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

An awesome weekend! I'm so sorry other people had bad run ins.

Friday: the last SPAZ.
Although it didn't go all night it ROCKED until 2am when noise complaints
from upstairs Kalesa forced it to shut down. Since it was the normal
time range and $3.00 then this is no big deal. Alex, Shobhan, Topher
and others spun in the totally packed downstairs while Weird Blinking LIghts
and OST jammed live emusic upstairs after Takeshi spun an ambient set.

Saturday: Ultraviolet
A new gorgeous central warehouse space with massive well ventillated rooms
and amazing Jeffery/Denise decorations. $3.00, all night.

Its amazing how great the underground parties are. Our under $5.00 scene
is really great here. Its very diverse and filled with great locations
and people.

I'll never understand how anyone could even THINK of going to a $15.00 or
$20.00 party when there are so many great small parties around.

Make sure you check out Weird Blinking Lights at Gaia Mantra this saturday
at 2:00pm and its FREE!

-rsn8

Deak--

What you and others need to know is to consult people
who know before you plan BDBeach parties.  It is not
just SP that prevents crossing the tracks, it is literally
against the law to use the beach the way we have for
parties.  It will be heavily surveiled for some time now
because of the last large, messy FMR (NOT becaue of the
Rolling Stone article).  I've lived here for 22years
and gone to may partiesin the 70s, 80s, and 90s at BD
Beach.  After suitable (whatever that amounts to) time,
we start having parties there again. Let's have more
consultation in the community before alerting the forcres
again!

ciao,
Will

I'm a little uncomfortable with this polling stuff which is why I didn't
participate.  16 responses isn't enough to tell much, anyway.  Also, not
to complain too much, but I've never heard of "Richie Rich Hawtin" although
both Richie Hawtin and Richie Rich were at the Detroit music conference
I just attended :)

One of the great things about the current state of affairs is that there
are so many different DJs with so many different and valid approaches.
Someone might be 'on fire' one night and not the next; some are steadier
than others but never reach the peaks of those who try and sometimes
fall on their faces.

Hi!  Sorry sorry to all those who went searching for the New Moon party
last month and either couldn't find it or found it after it was busted.
We had problems with our voicemail (American Message Service) & couldn't
change our outgoing message to let people know what was up!  In the end,
we moved it to Berkeley's Chateau co-op, home of MESS, where after a
refreshing dip in the pool, we started up again.  Thanks especially go
out to Bryce, Sean C., Rowan & Sean's pal Greg (from Davis) who kept it
going during the afternoon.  It was fun hanging out on the porch with you
guys!  

This coming sunday the party will be indoors, possibly in SF.  Voicemail
(415-267-3076) is troublefree at the moment....but...does anybody have
advice on which companies are the best?  We are thinking of changing
services.  Also, advice on folks to avoid would be nice, too.

-anthrax

---------- Forwarded message ----------
Date: Sun, 31 Jul 1994 11:03:01 -0700
From: John Bagby <cubensis@well.sf.ca.us>
Subject: Burning Man and other fun nuggets

RE: Brians correction about the Burning Man Festival, um, in fact the
organizers are asking for $30. from EVERYONE, however, given that people
cannot afford the techo-pagan fire ritual, they are reasonable and want all
participate.  They are very strict with tickets, each one has a serial
number and officially they are printing up Zippy Pronoia Tour/Burning Man
vouchers, good for $5 off the $30 ticket price.  These vouchers will be
handed out by the Zippies (the Tour zippies, that is) from August 21 to
August 28 at the Grand Canyon Area.  Details to follow.

Contact 1.415.AM.PROID for updates as we post them to voice mail.

REGARDING the heaps of dialogue, the criticisms (both the fair and lying-ass
slime variety), we are reading it all as a group, and pondering the
appropriate responses to sfraves and alt.culture.zippies...

The FACTS of what happened at Vivid Pronoia (yes, the objective FACTS) are
not quite what everyone may think.)

We have limited online access, lots of zippies who want to respond
individually, and as a group.  More power to the power of debate!

Hang in there, we will contribute to the dialogue and address concerns
shortly.  Meanwhile, manifest life poem...

-cubensis
 pincus

 Zippy Pronoia Tour to US '94



From sfraves-owner  Mon Aug  1 19:08:31 1994

Date: Mon, 1 Aug 1994 19:08:17 -0700 (PDT)
From: Brian Behlendorf <brian@hyperreal.com>
Subject: Saturday Night [Troy Sheets <tsheets@chaph.usc.edu>] (fwd)
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Message-ID: <Pine.3.89.9408011943.D6526-0100000@taz.hyperreal.com>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk



---------- Forwarded message ----------
From: Troy Sheets <tsheets@chaph.usc.edu>
Subject: Saturday Night
Date: Mon, 1 Aug 1994 19:01:52 -0700 (PDT)

	We left the South Bay for San Francisco on Saturday night
with a few parties in mind, but having no idea what would be good
or bad.  
	Our first stop was the Berkeley student co-op, where the
Mother Earth sound system was set up.  We knew many people there,
and had a good 1.5-2 hours of dancing fun.  The semi-enclosed room
was comfortably full with about 20 people dancing.  The vibe is
what you would expect from a small gathering such as this.  Not
many people, but everyone putting a lot of energy into the air.  
Happy people and good times.  We could have stayed there for much
of the night, but San Fran was beckoning...
	Anthem of the Sun did have a good location.  The YMCA provided
a real ravey feel, with lots of hallways to hang out in/explore.  But
most of the hallways were brightly lit, taking most of the mystery
away.  Twenty bucks got you a good location, a good sound system, 
and even good music.  But, as we all know, you can't buy vibe, and 
this event was sorely lacking.  Most of the people there were about
the same age I was when I got into raving in '91.  But I don't 
remember the parties I went to being like this.  I remember my first
raves as being totally chaotic, totally crazy, and completely fun.  I 
remember huge rooms of people where no one was sitting down, 
where no one could really stand to sit down(?). I remember complete
and total release of youthful energy, and it was wonderful.  
	But, Anthem was different.  Sure, many people were dancing,
but most were just half-into it.  There were lots of little wanna-be
gansta types.  Everyone had the "rave" clothes, but few seemed to
rave like I used to (It took me about 7 events before I invested in my
first Clobber shirt.)  I am wondering if the rave scene that swept 
through my life when I was 18 is different now.  It seems more
diluted, to much like any other teenage party.  I would like to think
that it was just a bad event, but if that same event had occurred in '91, with
the same location, laser, sound and DJ's, It would have
gone OFF!  I'm still having just as much fun going to raves/house clubs
now as I did when I started, so I don't think the scene is going bad.
I just think that the younger people are getting crappy events, and
this is preventing them from seeing how wonderful raves really are.
I would hate to be this narrow demographic of people who 
experienced raves.  I would hope instead that each year more and
more kids got into the scene, into the "real" rave scene, the rave
scene we experienced.
	Anyway, my friend suggested we leave and check out Funky 
Budda.  I tried to forget the fact that I paid 20 dollars for 45 
minutes of club.  I think we left just before things started to fall
apart there.  Funky Budda was in the same location that Spundae is
held at.  We got there and Mark Farina was spinning a wonderful, 
funky house set.  This club was pretty cool.  It was a classic house
club.  Probably about a 50/50 gay/straight homogenized crowd, 
complete with freak show-ers and drag queens (A guy there had
18 inch platform shoes!).  By about 4:30 the place was bursting with
energy and love.  I don't think I have heard such good house music 
since I left LA.  By about 6:30 the atmosphere started changing from
a house club to a gay pick-up club.  I even got hit on.  ("what, you're
STRAIGHT!!??", "Yeah man, but I ain't NARROW!")  Hmmm, come to 
think of it, maybe it was mostly a gay club.  Oh well, the music
and vibe were great, and that is what matters to me.  Funky Budda
is a great place to go if your 1st choice San Fran club does not work
out.  21+, 5 dollar cover.
	Comment/Question:  I have noticed that most of the cool 
renegade parties out there spin mostly hard trance/techno.  Do any
of you do more funky, housy parties?  Let me know.

-troy.

You have to expect that people will have to pick people who are local. 
They are the ones that people are most exposed to and they are there week 
after week. As for DJs who are from elsewhere, there has been some 
"guest" djs that come from various places. Some of them are really good, 
but when you go and see them half the time you don't know who they are or 
whether they are on or not. A one time experience doesn't really 
constitute a favorite DJ...

Since I posted a request for information about XLR8R Magazine, I've
received about 8 direct replies.  I want to thank everyone who responded.
Once again it just goes to show how tight a community SFRs are and most of
them were not tied to the publication.
>From all the postings, the greatest news came from Matthew J. Corwine (he
does have links to the magazine), who informed me that XLR8R magazine is
moving to San Francisco.  I think this is great news.  For one thing there
will be more coverage of the local scene although I thought they were
already doing a pretty good job at it for a magazine from Seattle.  Another
posting gave me an address on Haight street but was not specific whether it
was their new operating location so I will not post that address.

benefit from as I'm sure I'm not the only one interested in the development
of their move to the Bay Area.

Great News...and thanks again everyone.

One person wrote me today:
>System 7 Deep House?  Nahhh . . . . . the way people
>explained it to me deep house is that happy discoy
>house with diva vocals.

Another person wrote me today:
>> deep house
>OK.  Like non-Diva NY stuff...

SO clearly getting agreement on what these terms mean is first, before
anything else can occur (whether anything else is desirable or not :-) ).

I think that would a good idea and could be entered into the new version
of the alt.rave FAQ as well.

If people have entirely conflicting ideas of what these terms mean (even
techno and house, by the way!) then what is the point of even using them?

thanks,

    Ken

Francisco.  It's quite a loss for our fair city, but quite a gain for 
yours.  The format is being upgraded, the circulation is growing, and 
Andrew, Andrew, and Ethan are pleased as punch to be down there.  Here is 
all the appropriate contact information:

XLR8R Magazine
Andrew Smith, Editor

Michael Manahan, and Dervish, on Visible come October.  Seems as if 
people are really digging the track so far, so sometime in the next two

hyperreal.com, so please check it out and give me your opinions...

From: "Dana WATANABE" <DWATANAB@uci.edu>
Message-Id: <199408021732.AA14281@mothra.nts.uci.edu>
Subject: Burning Man and other fun nuggets [<cubensis@well.sf.ca.us>] 
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com (sfraves@hyperreal.com)
Date: Tue, 2 Aug 94 10:32:37 PDT
Cc: cubensis@well.sf.ca.us
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.3 PL11]
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

> From: John Bagby <cubensis@well.sf.ca.us>

> REGARDING the heaps of dialogue, the criticisms (both the fair and lying-ass
> slime variety), we are reading it all as a group, and pondering the
> appropriate responses to sfraves and alt.culture.zippies...
> 
> The FACTS of what happened at Vivid Pronoia (yes, the objective FACTS) are
> not quite what everyone may think.)

This really has nothing to do with the situation at hand,
but sorta does...

It's just that it scares me when people start talking about objective facts,
because then they usually follow it up with lots of perceptions
and in doing so tned to ignore other possible perceptions.

It's most likely because i come from a system of thought that
believes the only facts are those which we create.
(ie 1+2=3, why? because we said so :)

You can have your perceptions of what happened and someone else witnessing
the same events will have a different perception.  Even more likely
is that you witnessed different (or more) events and thus have a completely
different perception of the situation than others might.

BUT for you to have the "objective FACTS" would mean that you have
no subjective filters in your brain/soul.  Hell, even if you were a 
camera i wouldnt trust you to represent the objective facts
much less a living machine with feelings and ideas.

just some thoughts

 ,
dana

"The only thing better than messing with somebody's sense of reality
is messing with a whole LOTTA people's sense of reality...."
               -jms

To: SFRAVES@HYPERREAL.COM
Subject: deep mustard (Re: music terminology)
Sender: owner-sfraves@HYPERREAL.COM
Precedence: bulk




reflections on deep house 
to Diva or not to Diva ...

>SO clearly getting agreement on what these terms mean is first, before
>anything else can occur 

It ain't gonna happen.  I called the music from last friday tribal to deep 
and my roomate called it acid.  We were at the same party.  We listen to lots
of each others music.  We like to talk about music.

I sympathize with the adjective overload syndrome.  And with all the SF
parties it would be nice to have some better guide. 
You just have to go and commit.  
Let it take you somewhere.  
It's ok to warm up to something different.
I prefer this.  I like variety.

The music doesn't always have to hit you like a mack truck
Maybe it gets Deep because of your new funky friends
Or the groove you just found
Words just don't always cut the Mustard
It is too experiential 

Think of the descriptions as little clues or hints for you to work with
The promoter doesn't want to spoon feed you  
This is not, however, all that easy ...
Some parties do jam mash potatoes down your throat
while others leave you starving


>If people have entirely conflicting ideas of what these terms mean (even
>techno and house, by the way!) then what is the point of even using them?
>    Ken

because I can say to my friends, "I like House"
and we all smile ;)

Dave

> Actually the artist(s) is the Bass Bin Twins. I've seen 2 12", including
> the aforementioned 'A-1 Love,' but there's supposedly a third one as well.
> I believe it's one guy who recently moved to SF from LA. I'll see if I can
> find out more info.
> 
	Actually, his name is Pete, and as far as I know he's indeed 
living up here in SF.  I met him @ Rasputin's a few weeks back, and he 
struck me, on 1st impression, as one of the coolest motherfuckers on the 
scene.  He put out a white label that scorches like none other, and 
seemed perfectly modest, even humble, when I started flying off the 
handle about what a milestone record it was.  I'll speak up if I hear 
from him again.
		...minor



From sfraves-owner  Tue Aug  2 14:12:07 1994
Return-Path: owner-sfraves
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.9/8.6.5) id OAA00685; Tue, 2 Aug 1994 14:12:07 -0700
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (Smail3.1.28.1 #12)
	id m0qVR7v-0003VHC; Tue, 2 Aug 94 14:11 PDT
Message-Id: <m0qVR7v-0003VHC@taz.hyperreal.com>
From: laura@taz.hyperreal.com (Laura La Gassa)
Date: Tue, 2 Aug 1994 14:11:59 PST
X-Mailer: Mail User's Shell (7.1.1 5/02/90)
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: styles o' music @ renegades
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


Someone posted earlier today asking what was played at the various
renegades and said something to the effect that they thought the
renegades are mostly techno.

If you like variety and music in general, you are bound to find
something you like at any and all the renegades being thrown (NMR,
MESS, Spiral Jive, Cloud Factory, Liquid Air, Sunset, sorry if I
missed anyone :-) ).  None of them are more than about half techno.  
Sometimes you can even catch a few hip-hop or even industrial tracks
mixed into a set.

Of the "usual" Liquid Air DJs only about half of them play techno, 
and the style of techno ranges from very acid-house influenced to very 
smooth spacey trance to harder more "old style" techno.  On the house 
side the last Liquid Air featured sets from Tamara (funky stuff and old 
school acid house from 1988), Lee An (progressive and "happy/disco/diva"), 
and Deaks (progressive and light trance).

Speaking of Liquid, we're pulling out the sound system this FRIDAY in
honor of Bryce's birthday.  He's spinning near the beginning so get
there early if you want to hear him :-)  It's free, it's outdoors, and
we're attempting a location that hasn't been used in a LONG time (no, 
not Bonny Doon).

Call (415) - 985 - 5244 or finger me Friday night for info.

See you!

Laura


From sfraves-owner  Tue Aug  2 23:39:11 1994
Return-Path: owner-sfraves
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.9/8.6.5) id XAA09567; Tue, 2 Aug 1994 23:39:11 -0700
Received: from ultima.org by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.9/8.6.5) with SMTP id XAA09561; Tue, 2 Aug 1994 23:39:06 -0700
Received: by ultima.org  (Linux Smail3.1.28.1 #1) 
 	id m0qVZES-000BgxC; Tue, 2 Aug 94 22:51 PDT
Message-Id: <m0qVZES-000BgxC@ultima.org>
From: brycer@ultima.org (Bryce Ryan)
Subject: Cirrus Review
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Date: Tue, 2 Aug 1994 22:51:15 -0700 (PDT)
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL23]
Content-Type: text
Content-Length: 2989      
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Well, it's a bit late, but then again, i've been constructing an InterNet
site...where does all the time go?  In any case, I was invited to attend
Cirrus, which was put on by the folks at the Cloud Factory in Monterey.
I was asked to bring Liquid down, and to provide some advice on logistics,
location, etc.  As time went on, however, it became clear to me that the
folks at the Clound Factory were very organized, and they eventually told
me i needn't bring Liquid, just myself.

I thought the date was a good omen, from the very first mention to me...
the eve of Lammas, an ancient harvest festival.  Lammas is traditionally
the time of the first harvest, and one of the major festivals in a variety
of ancient Northern European calendars.

The site was absolutely awesome, and worth the work to load in (though the
load out was a real bear, as ernie has already mentioned).  Cirrus was held
in a natural amphitheater, and was well away from any neighbors of any kind
(except birds and marine life).  At the top of the amphitheater, one could
see the breakers, the bay, and beyond, the lights of Monterey...quite
charming!  There was also the long hops down the side of the site to the
base, where the sound system was set up.  Despite a few logistical problems
at the map point, which were ultimately corrected by quick updates to the
voice mail, almost everything went smoothly.

Cirrus had an excellent sound system that thumped but good, and filled the
entire space with sound...very impressive for a rental...and the sound
provider was a pro.  I attended from the very beginning to the very end, and
met many old and new friends.  The quality of the DJing was superb...Tim,
K-Go, Ernie, Christian and I provided some bang-up music which kept people
dancing till just past dawn.  The Cloud Factory had originally asked for 
US$2 at the map point, but when problems arose, requested donations at the
decks; many people contributed.  Despite a few mishaps, all of the equipment
needed to throw the event without a hitch were present, and were provided by
the entire group of people who organized the event.

I have to tell you all that i was *very* impressed with the organization
of the folks from the Cloud Factory.  It was a group effort from the
inception (that's clear) all the way through the end.  Everyone pitched
in to help where needed, travelling, hauling, whatever needed to be done
got done without grumbling, without nasty encounters, and without any
hand-wringing.  They were prepared for a variety of potential problems with
interlopers (though none showed up).  They got the word out, and kept folks
informed of the latest news...a very good package, all told...they put many
an SF-based organizer to shame, and they've only been doing this for a very
short while.

I strongly recommend to you all that you attend one of their events in the
near future.  These folks know how to do it right!
-- 
--------Bryce Ryan----------AMBIANCE---------brycer@ultima.org--------

  Went to CU last night at 1015 Folsom and spent most of the evening in the
 ambient room with Dubtribe ( I had been wanting to hear their live stuff
 for some time ) and I was pleased. Way out excellent tribal ? rhythms
 played on electronic/natural drums, great vocals from a woman ( who is 
 she ? ) and nice mix of beat oriented ambient tunes. Check it out - I 
 notice they will be back on Sept 7 at next CU monthly....

  About 2:30 I left the ambient room and went into the main - WOW What a
 PARTY. Can we talk about dancing sardines ? But it sure looked like the
 people were having one hell of a great time. I didn't expect this many
 party people on midweek but there they were dancing their asses off...
 definitely not for the claustrophobic but absolutely worth checking if
 you want to dance with a crowd... at $7 I have no arguements with the
 price....

 Mike Clay

  I noticed something as I listened to the music at the CU last night
 which has caused me to wonder if I'm hearing things "right". The music
 I heard in the main room seemed to have far more beat than music - but I
 am defining "music" as synthe or other instrument melody... Don't get me
 wrong what I seemed to be hearing was WONDERFUL to dance to but I'm not
 sure that as a musician I would enjoy simply listening to it... which
 brings me to a question for those on the net with more listening experience

 Am I indeed hearing 2 (or more?) major types of music...

 1) played at FF had the strong beat but also has an almost equal element
    of "play with your head electronic sound" VERY strong synthe presense
    with more of a sense of melody...

 2) played at CU had a strong beat without nearly as much of the melody 
    and electronic swirls Etc.


  Comments ?



  BTW I'm fishing for differences to help me search out types of music and
   am not really aiming at judgments of better or worse ie. this is great
   but that sucks. Also labels are going to be a major pain in the butt..
   but then in order to talk you have to use something.....


 Mike Clay

Subject: Little Boxes on the Dancefloor [pms/G=JD/S=MAREMONT@mhs.attmail.com] (fwd)
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Message-ID: <Pine.3.89.9408041318.E8518-0100000@taz.hyperreal.com>

The first of about 8 forwards...

---------- Forwarded message ----------
From: pms/G=JD/S=MAREMONT@mhs.attmail.com
Date: 2 Aug 94 22:01:15 GMT
Subject: Little Boxes on the Dancefloor

On the subject of categories of and labels for music, the following comes to
mind.  Categories can be a heplful tool for distinguishing various parts of the
musical field, and labels can be useful devices for gathering
together musics with similar properties for discussion, promotion, and
discovery.  Categorization, however, is by its very nature a process of
analysis and division, separating various dimensions of the vague musical realm
from each other across lines which are generally arbitrary and often quite
unnatural.  The consequences of these two aspects have become quite clear over
the past few years.  What once was just Rock (a category used originally to
separate it - I imagine - from blues and pop) has fragmented into Metal,
Hip-Hop, Grunge, House, Techno, New Age, Glam, Goth, Ambient, Industrial, etc.,
and all of these realms have further shattered into micro-genres.  Because of 
these tiny domains, marketing and communication becomes far more efficient 
(witness the specificity of zines and net lists), and more types of music are 
allowed to flourish.  But these little regions all to often tend to ghettoize 
music, and to include or exclude recordings or performances based upon a 
definition which soon hardens into a formula - a formula which then becomes a 
law for those who wish to dwell within a given micro-genre.  In this way labels
tend to discourage musical cross-pollenation and to encourage the sort of
inbreeding that produces mediocre and generic music; yet it is that very
cross-pollenation that produces new genres in the first place.  I realize that
this is a paradoxical situation, for here we are in a techno/house forum
which has attracted us precisely because we know what those labels mean.  I
also admit that I generally use the term "ambient" to describe what I do,
dsepite the fact that I dislike what the appearance of that term has started to
do in that area of sound.  With chill rooms and dance floors, the rave scene
provides a setting in which many forms of music come together and coexist
in blissful collage, and I hope that the compulsion to label does not close the
doors that have been opened here.  The highest compliment I can pay a piece of
music these days is to call it "none of the above." <-- Joshua / Thermal

Subject: more afternoon thoughts


House is a Curtis Mayfield bassline
stripped down and launched into outer space

Techno is when your rocketship has wierd fuzzy barnacles
all over it and is smashing through an asteroid belt


********

That looks like some kind of test question.
Please diagram the misleadingly obtuse sentence for 10pts.
(I have a great deal of work to do and I am procrastinating)

What does ComeUnity usually cost?
My copious efforts to get in for free have drawn a blank.
Any further virtual assistance would be most welcome!
Lets make this whole internet connectedness shit really pay off...

No offense to you hardcore no-commercial folks but I just
REALLY felt like tossing out the "get me in free" request 
this afternoon.  Hopefully you can deal with it.

I am in such an odd but cheerful mood,
Dave

---------- Forwarded message ----------
From: lee@cafe.berkeley.edu (Lee An)
Subject: Re: styles o' music @ renegades
Date: Tue, 2 Aug 1994 21:04:25 -0700 (PDT)

> Of the "usual" Liquid Air DJs only about half of them play techno, 
> and the style of techno ranges from very acid-house influenced to very 
> smooth spacey trance to harder more "old style" techno.  On the house 
> side the last Liquid Air featured sets from Tamara (funky stuff and old 
> school acid house from 1988), Lee An (progressive and "happy/disco/diva"), 
> and Deaks (progressive and light trance).

Arghhh.... I've been insulted! =)

Sorry Laura, but I would never consider what I play "happy/disco/diva." I 
though _I_ was the one playing funky/acid house from the late 80s (along 
with lots of Italian/UK trance), unless of course you consider DJ Pierre 
"happy" house....

I think it's just a matter of semantics, but from my perspective, what I
play is as far away from happy/disco/diva house as Richard Hawtin. Well, 
okay, not quite, but I think you should stop by the Sound Factory to get 
the full diva treatment before you accuse me of such a crime again. =)

> Speaking of Liquid, we're pulling out the sound system this FRIDAY in
> honor of Bryce's birthday.  He's spinning near the beginning so get
> there early if you want to hear him :-)  It's free, it's outdoors, and
> we're attempting a location that hasn't been used in a LONG time (no, 
> not Bonny Doon).

I second this. I've been listening to Bryce's new tape all week and I 
must say it's wonderful. I suggest that everyone make a special effort to 
come early to watch Bryce spin. I'm sure he'll blow you away.

Lee

Precedence: bulk



---------- Forwarded message ----------
From: KEN.STUART@tigerteam.org (KEN STUART)
Subject: Re: DJ identification:
Date: Tue, 02 Aug 1994 16:53:00 GMT

Hello,

Okay, it sounds like what the DJ spins at an event is dictated by the
promoter.  Well then, once again, we need the promoters to supply more
information!

If the listing only says:

" Groovy Thump '94
  At a new location near SFPD HQ
  DJs  Toni  Joe  Glumph
  (415)555-5555      (408)555-5555     (510)555-5555  "

and the recorded message never says anything other than the location or
the map location, and the DJs all have been known to spin a variety of
styles depending on the requirements of the promoter, then you really
don't know if you're going to get happy-house or hard-trance.

Maybe instead we need a listing of recurring events:

Groovy Thump             annual                happy-house
Ride Cymbals Forever     weekly                hard-trance

etc.

respect,

    Ken
    Ken.Stuart@tigerteam.org

ComeUnity
was not very expensive 

I'll focus
On friday I had a good time
On saturday I was doing some shopping and I 
dropped by the X-Large store party with nice people
free beer and music.  What was most fun was "touching
base" - catching a little bit of the previous evening's 
mood.  Head bobbing and smiles.  Very mellow.
Some genuine excitement.

This is what I wanted from ComeUnity.
A midweek drop-in.

I got the big room at 1015 Folsom and a 
weekday city bar crowd.  Not drinking.
Just out.  Plenty of dancing.  Social.        
Maybe a bit overly flirtatious.

I heard Simon and Garth.
I was not inspired.  The music was sparse 
and seemed dry.  It was all or nothing.  
Seeing the staff drag an overdose/heat exhaustion victim
through the crowd was sad.       

Dave

Subject: Putting on my OWN rave

HI,

  I am finally getting the opportunity to put on my OWN rave.   I am currently
trying to decide what date to hold the rave.    I want to do everything right,
like have it low cost (To pay for the space usage),   have the right DJ's,  
and have both free food and food available for sale,  such as sandwiches,
and other stuff.

  I want to hold it sometime within a month,  and not have it conflict with
Burning Man,  or Grand Canyon rave.

  I am working through experienced promoters,  that seem to have an incredable
knack for superb organization.   I have had lengthy discussions on every aspect
from paying DJ's and getting sound systems,  to finding spaces.

  So,  please let me know of any preferred dates you think I should pick to
hold it,  sometime a month from now.

More details follows...
John D.

Subject: Grand Canyon Mega Rave Update
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

GRAND CANYON MEGA RAVE UPDATE. GOOD NEWS.

Hello all,

This is Andrew Morin of EPIC Productions, I want to update you all 
on the situation regarding the rave near the Grand Canyon. There has 
been talk for several months about the "Grand Canyon Mega Rave" and 
whether the event would actually take place. One of the hang-ups 
was the inability of the World Unity Festival, which the Mega Rave 
was to be associated with, to finalize a site. It appears that this 
hurdle has been overcome. We visited the actual site, which sits 
atop a spectacular Mesa surrounded by the Kaibab National Forest 
which borders the Grand Canyon. There are many obstacles still to 
overcome to produce the event, but things are starting to come 
together. EPIC Productions, in association with Fraser Clark the 
Zippy philosopher, and the World Unity Festival, will be producing 
the event. 

The World Unity Festival begins on August 22 at the Mesa which is 
located approximately 35 miles to the north of Flagstaff, Arizona on 
route 140. The Mega Rave is now scheduled for Wednesday, Thursday, 
Friday and Saturday August 24, 25, 26, and 27. There will be camping 
near the festival as well at National Forest sites in the immediate 
vicinity. I'll be providing additional details about the rave as the 
picture becomes clearer. You can call our information line for 
updates: (415) 905-8800 or (408) 457-4955.

Some people (including the press in Europe and Australia) have been 
calling the Mega Rave the real Woodstock of the 90's.  It really could be an 
amazing event . Spread the word and lets make it happen! 

Love,
Andrew

X-Mailer: Z-Mail (3.0.0 15dec93)
To: Brian Behlendorf <brian@hyperreal.com>, sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Re: DJ identification: [KEN.STUART@tigerteam.org (KEN STUART)] (fwd)
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Mime-Version: 1.0
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Ken, you STILL don't get it.  What doesn't apply to DJs as far as
labeling definitely does not apply to events.  Furthermore, events
come and go so quickly and the names change so frequently that it
seems hardly worth the effort to put together some kind of permanent
comprehensive list.  The sf-raves calendar is the best and most
complete current guide I know of for the Bay Area (by FAR), but even
in spite of diligent upkeep by Derek it isn't and can't be completely
accurate.  

Most of all, what I object to is the paint-by-numbers approach to this.
"Oh, it says here COSMIC FOOFOO is happy diva hardcore, that sounds OK
to me!"  The musical identity of each event is complex and derives as
much from the attitude of the crowd and the characteristics of the space
as from what the DJs are playing.  I've heard DJs play nearly identical
sets in different places and come away thinking the experience was 
considerably different overall.  I don't mind broad generalizations --
what they do at Sound Factory is NOT happy diva hardcore, I suppose :-)
And while at least a little bit of an idea about the differences in
the various events is helpful, I don't believe that this is supposed to
be a shopping mall experience.  There is no Orange Julius or Foot Locker
of the house/rave/techno/hiphop/industrial/whatever scene, where you
know exactly what you're going to get when you walk in the door.

I LIKE it that way, even if it leads to unachieved expectations a good
portion of the time.

---------- Forwarded message ----------
Date: Thu, 4 Aug 1994 17:50:01 -0700 (PDT)
From: Kendall Griggs <kgriggs@mercury.sfsu.edu>

On Mon, 1 Aug 1994, Tony V Garcia wrote:

> 
> I had a feeling about this party.  As it turned out from the posts, the 
> outcome exceeded my expectations.  I am sure glad I didn't waste my 
> time.  My heart goes out to those who did.  

Well, I know this is kinda late.  I expect much "seen it/ dunnit/ sawit/ 
" and so forth but here goes.

I'm fairly new here and havn't met anybody on this list, but still we had 
a good time at Anthem of the Sun.  Totally warm vibes everywhere.  I was 
under the impression that they (the people who put it on) had all their 
ducks in order; as they even had their security personnel trying to keep 
everybody mellow.  This was my FIRST event and I thought it was a blast!  
I really didn't know what to expect, but I was impressed.  The lazers 
were the BEST I have EVER seen!!! (now these may be nothing compared to 
what some of you have been to).  The fog worked well too, it didn;t plug 
up my lungs like some places do (Slim's).  At one point, we were 
near the front and almost were zapped by that red laser-sight thing 
that hit some woman's water bottle on her head!  Everyone seemed 
appreciative 
of the music, but I have a couple things I'm not clear on.  First, I 
think there's got to be a way to find out WHO is WHO; there were so many 
DJ's there that I'd be cool to know who each one was so we newcomers can 
identify with them and get a feel for what they spin and how.  Also, we 
couldn't find the chill room w/ ambient music; I was hoping to see what 
one was like, but there's always next time.  

I'm glad I didn't forget to bring my own water.  But overall we had a 
good time, dancing the night away.  We must have left just before it was 
busted up, but one person who drives a group has the most power and when 
he/she gets tired, everyone else can't do much but to aquiesce or walk home!

Any more suggestions for us rookies out there?

Since this was my first, how should one rate a sound system?  What does 
one look for as it sounded great to me; I could hear rumbling bass and 
high tweeters...

On Thu, 4 Aug 1994 BUEHRING@sonoma.edu wrote:

> amazing event . Spread the word and lets make it happen! 

You know, I appreciate the fact that there is a high potential for cool 
stuff to happen during those 3-4 days, but despite the hype that has been 
generated regarding this so-called megarave on the net,in XLR8R mag, and 
many other places, there have been no firm details regarding a rave at all.
How are those of us who don't live near the grand canyon expected to make 
the TIME and FINANCIAL commitment to head down there...?  Spread the word?
About WHAT?  If I am going to drive or fly all the way down there (and 
I'm sure this is the case with many of us), I want to know for certain 
that there will be a "mega rave", because I certainly wouldn't want to 
travel that far to listen to philosophy and wander through a new-age arts 
festival--I can do that here in Washington (no flame intended).

Andrew

From: csc@pilot.njin.net (Sean Casey)

To: Kendall Griggs <kgriggs@mercury.sfsu.edu>
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Re: Anthem of The Sun [Kendall Griggs <kgriggs@mercury.sfsu.edu>] (fwd)
In-Reply-To: <Pine.3.89.9408050126.C21674-0100000@taz.hyperreal.com>
References: <Pine.3.89.9408050126.C21674-0100000@taz.hyperreal.com>
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

 > Since this was my first, how should one rate a sound system?  What does 
 > one look for as it sounded great to me; I could hear rumbling bass and 
 > high tweeters...

Look for the same things you'd look for in a good stereo system.:

Bass should be tight and have lots of punch, but should not be muddy.
If they turn up the bass too high, it reverberates off the walls and
every song sounds like a 5 engine locomotive going by. Not good.
Strong, clear bass defines the beats.

Mid and highs should be clear--but not screeching. You should be able
to stand *somewhere* and hear a good stereo image. That makes for good
tweak factor :). I'm starting to really believe in putting mid-high
cabinets over the crowd and aiming them down because highs don't "go
around". They're pretty much stopped by people in front of the
cabinets.

The sound should be loud, but you shouldn't need earplugs. Some mostly
deaf DJs and promoters don't seem to understand this. That's why
they're deaf. Responsible promoters don't turn it up to hearing-damage
levels.

Sean

 electronics.

 even a song on it I've heard a DJ spin but for the life of me I would
 not be able to even guess as to the record classification. If Ken or

 music that is available - what's hot (and why) or what's just so-so.

Hey all, I've just been through a really rough time in which I lost
my job (though no fault of my own) and in which I contracted the worst
case of poison oak (from the 2nd site of the "Zippy" party) that the 
doctor at UCSF Medical Center Acute Care Clinic had ever seen.  Anyway,
my job hunt is going really well and the doctor put me on steroid/antibiotic
treatment and my skin is starting to heal.  I'm telling you all this because 
I'm suddenly BURSTING with positive energy and am looking forward to 
tonight's  LIQUID LEO party!

Last night Bryce, Susie, Cyril, and I went to look at the site.  We feel
pretty positive about it and it has nice amenities like lots of easy
parking, a nearby porta-potty, and is sufficiently hidden from sight yet
affords interesting scenic views.  It's Bryce's Birthday and he's stoked
to give us a good set, and if Ethan's set from the Santa Cruz party is
any indication of what he's into now, we are in for the technotrance trip
into space.

So, even though my skin looks bad I'm huggable and NOT contagious.  Come
on out and say HI, if you're a lurker and want to meet some sfravers please
join us and we'll make sure you get introduced around.

Logistics:  call the Liquid line at (415) - 985 - 5244 after 10 for
directions.  We'd like people to arrive starting at 12:30.  Please
park quickly and quietly and quickly get our of your cars and up to
the site.  You can also finger my account for directions after 10 tonight.

Aside from Ethan and Bryce we'll be featuring our main man of smooth
groove Lee An, and I'll bring my records along too.

See you later,

Laura

later on, we exchange phone numbers, or if the person has one, e-mail 
addresses -- why should this be done in the reverse direction??)

From: brycer@ultima.org (Bryce Ryan)
Subject: Liquid Leo: an end
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Date: Sat, 6 Aug 1994 04:15:37 -0700 (PDT)
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL23]
Content-Type: text
Content-Length: 1229      
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Greetings!  My sincere and deep apologies to all who attended or tried
to attend Liquid Leo.  Twenty-one people were cited for violation of
a curfew law.  The officers claimed we were in the park illegally, though
no signs were posted stating that.  We did, however, get a few songs, and
I was just starting to get into a groove when we were visited.

I must say that everyone who was there reacted very well, making as
happy an occasion as possible, talking geek-talk with the officers,
helping pack up, and so forth.  Thanks for the gifts of upside down
cake (literally), roses, cookies, and more...everyone shared their
things, and made as good a time of it as possible.

after i post this, i will be setting up a mailing list on Ultima to
discuss this, strategize, bitch, rejoice, whatever.  It will be run
by majordomo, so sending a one line msg of "subscribe oyster-gate"
will do the trick.

Oh, and i think it's important that no one ever try to do an event at
that site again: Oyster Bay Regional Shoreline.

Again, my apologies.  I'll try to make it up to you all.  And thanks for
all the birthday best wishes...you all really touched my heart.
-- 
--------Bryce Ryan----------AMBIANCE---------brycer@ultima.org--------

Followup to the Santa Cruz party.

It worked!  Not only did I have a cool party at my house with
10-20 people dancing pretty hard until 3am, with no neighbor
or police interactions.... but also the warehouse party had
a good crowd of 40+ people when I got there at 3:30, a nice crisp
unmuddled sound system, and a good floor.  You know, floors are
important... solid, good traction, trippy black and white patterns...
DJ had the right attitude, even if he couldn't beat match very well,
I forgot his name as I was very tired... but he was responsible for
the whole thing and he is going to try to hold them every week.
Same place.  Main problems were that the place was sort'f small, not
enough people to make it crowded though, but enough to make it pretty
warm inside.  I'll go so far as to say hot.  So if you decide to try
it next week bring cool clothing and water water water.  He's
charging $5 a month, charging on one weekend a month.  It's a wonderful
thing to happen to Santa Cruz, for those quiet friday nights.
So... what more can I say.

So are people going to Wicked or Ex-Why-ZZZ tonight?

warm saturdays....

-john.

		drive from 80 and 580..perfect for late-nite excursions
		to distant events
		(oh yeah, um, 20 min bike ride to UC, 5 min walk to
		Plaza BART, just two stops from Berkeley)

Pets:		cats, snakes, fish, maybe a dog? Cat already in residence
		(cat has attitude)

		unpretentious El Cerrito.  sometimes foggy, sometimes hot
		hot hot.  apt is in a four-unit complex, neighbors are good
		people.

		neat, pretty mellow.  my only hangup:  please no tv in 
		the common space..but lots of music!

within a day, for sure.  Move-in date is flexible, oh, and there's a lot
of storage space, if needed.  I have no preferences with regard to gender,
race or age.  Unfortunately, to get into the place you have to go over a

 By request from Denis 

 WBL plays Gaia Mantra - the sun shines in SF - the day was HOT !

 After the appropriate setup, warm up of the analogs, tunings and other
 preps the show went on with ~ 20 people or so wandering in and out.

 Nice analog ambient performance. LFO's oscilating, waveforms forming,
 brains rotating around their stems. Good group of people sharing fun
 vibes... and the price was right...

 A good time was had by all and Even as I type my music partner is
 messing with my mind by playing "analog madness" through massive
 processing. The performance of WBL has inspired me to add a heavily
 analog/processed ambient work to our works in process. When I hear
 good stuff I get inspired and I heard good stuff yesterday !


 PS Good to meet you Cindy and glad to see you out and about Ethan. To
    others I talked with -  great day wasn't it ?

believe) so come early and come often.

peace to ya mind in da summertime,
whitsitt

vibe over electronic means. thanks...

At 18:17 8/4/94 -0400, SLGibson@aol.com wrote:
>There's a dance cover of the old Doobie Brother's song, the chorus of which
>goes "Without love, where would you be now?", which has become my housemate's
>holy grail.
>
>If anyone has any clues who it's by, what it's called and/or where to get my
>hands on it,
>they would be most appreciated.
>
>Thanks all.

'Long Train Running' by the Doobie Brothers. (Remix, not a cover.) This was
re-released both in '92 or '93 and in '94 with different mixes, althought
the commonly heard one (the Ben Liebrand Full Guitar mix) is on both
re-releases.

Joe

From sfraves-owner  Mon Aug  8 05:16:22 1994
Return-Path: owner-sfraves
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.9/8.6.5) id FAA10673; Mon, 8 Aug 1994 05:16:22 -0700
Received: from bethe.ucdavis.edu by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.9/8.6.5) with SMTP id FAA10667; Mon, 8 Aug 1994 05:16:19 -0700

	id AA14871; Mon, 8 Aug 94 05:16:34 PDT
Date: Mon, 8 Aug 94 05:16:34 PDT
From: alves@bethe.ucdavis.edu (David Alves)
Message-Id: <9408081216.AA14871@bethe.ucdavis.edu>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: wicked thoughts
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


Wicked
was fairly expensive ... 
I think this is the most I have paid for a party in about 2 years
A cup of ice was free.  Water was a few dollars.

It was about 1:00 and the line was long.
I may have waited with the honorable and former sfr entertainer
John S Lee.  I am not sure though.  

It was packed, hot, and loud.  There was a cool hallway exit and a very hot
and smoky balcony.  Behind the dj and to the sides of the bar were little
areas where the sound was nice.  The sound was decent everywhere.  

People were cute and older.  
Diverse, with a mix of serious 
tshirt ravers and more fabulous clubby types.  
It was not a super "feel me/share with me" crowd.
(Although I did bum a smoke and a mint!)
I can see how the combination of all of this could be interpreted
as being colder or even rude compared to the hug fests that some 
parties are.  I thought it was great.

I danced with people I hadn't seen since going to the short lived zendada
a few months ago. I suppose you might call them the wicked posse.
I am not sure though. ;)  It was very fun.  You get the coolest feeling 
when you see people who have moved you before.  The obvious, I guess.
A greater hope for the morning, definitely.

I did a strange little jig with some really tall muscular pierced guy and
his friend.  He shook my hand when it was over.  In fact, this encounter was
typical for the evening.  As the music moved from the beat focused (all you need)
stuff back into richer sounding (what you want) pieces it got wierder.  
(pardon my parenthetical House mantras ...)
anyway, this may have been Jeno  
heavy on the Dramatic breaks and frog noises.

There is an excellent sense of timing, a feeling of 
experience, dancing with the Wise.  
I had fun playing along.

Overall, this was probably a pretty average Wicked.  
Dave

Yeah, Wicked was wicked, is wicked, will be wicked..  I really missed those
guys while they were gone.  Quite a few "tourists" early on, but as usual
they disappeared sometime after Jeno started up - it really felt like two
distinctly different parties with a very clear switch, though that might have
been me :-).  I was rockin' too hard to hug anyone till it was over as were
most, but there were definately some friendly hugs/goodbyes at the end.  I
brought a couple people who had never been to a Wicked before and they
couldn't shut up all day sunday about what an amazingly great time they had.
 What is that song with the frogs anyway? I gotta have it.

The only track I know of with frogs on it is 'Tree Frog' by Hope, which
to my knowledge was first released on a Belgian label last fall and has
been relicensed and rereleased several times.  Has a sort of chugging
beat with a voiceover, "It's getting closer," interspersed with frog
noises.  Very catchy.  I played it, if memory serves, at either the
first F&F or at the Berkeley party in February.  At the time it seemed
like more or less a novelty track (but with more character than other
'novelty' items like the recent 'Swamp Thing' by The Grid which I detest).
However, I note it's charting very highly both here and in the UK which
means it caught on without any serious promotion and that means a BIG
response from DJs and dance floors.  And so it goes.

Anyway, if it's NOT that one, I'd sure like to know! 

"It's not easy being green!"

phred
p

I just got this in the mail from Mute:

Plastikman's Sheet One A Case of Mistaken Identity

New York, NY -- On Monday, July 27, a 20 year old in Rockwall, Texas
(just outside Dallas) on his way to visit his girlfriend in the next
town was pulled over by the police for speeding.  He was asked to step
outside the car so the police could search it.

Inside the car, the police found was NovaMute Records' Plastikman Sheet
One CD.  Apparently believeing that the perforated artwork of the CD
booklet might contain "controlled substances", the young man was arrested
and booked on suspicion of "possession of a controlled substance."  This
charge is considered a 2nd degree felony/schedule 1, that means the 
punishment can be 2-20 years with up to a $10,000 fine.

The young man's father called Mute Records New York office for help in
trying to convince the police the CD booklet was artwork.  Mute Records
couriered a sealed shrink-wrapped CD to the father to show to the police.

The young man spent 5 1/2 days in jail and was released this past weekend
on $5500 bail, and a trial date has now been set for August 23rd.  Currently
the polic are testing the CD booklet in a lab.  Results will not be ready
for three weeks.

PLASTIKMAN is Richie Hawtin, one of the most revered figures in the global
techno underground.  He is the founder of +8 Records and the man behind
F.U.S.E. and Circuit Breaker.  Richie Hawtin is also known as one of the
world's top DJs for his trance, ambient techno music.  PLASTIKMAN's
Sheet One is a trip through the highlights of the electronic underground.
Mind music for the post-acid generation.

At press time, it is unclear whether NovaMute Records will include this
artwork in future PLASTIKMAN Sheet One CDs.



Hug Your Waistline to the Bassline............................................

Tamara Palmer * trance@netcom.com * izzyzi5@mvs.oac.ucla.edu * 

.........................................................Women Respond to Bass

Date: Mon, 8 Aug 1994 19:29:53 -0700 (PDT)
From: Willis Wong <walrus@quack.kfu.com>
Subject: Wicked sweaty smiling frogs
To: sfraves list <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
Message-Id: <Pine.3.89.9408081909.A20124-0100000@quack.kfu.com>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

So the Wicked location was the King Street Garage that I keep hearing 
about?  It seemed more like a club to me as far as all the architecture.  
This has got to be one of the sweatiest venues yet.  I would agree that 
some of the good places to dance were right next/behind the DJ tables and 
in the two corners at the sides of the bar.  The only problem I had was 
in the the corner on the left of the bar the floor was always very 
slippery.  I am assuming this was sweat condensing off the big parachute 
they hung off the celing... but boy was it wiggly.  Speaking of celings I 
really feel sorry for whoever has to put up those "wicked nets" every 
time, they must be so nappy!  But they're always there.
One thing I notice about Wicked is that the people are all there to get 
down and feel the music and dance.  I always get that feeling and it's 
always so satisfying to see so many people at once hooting and cheering 
in response to a _feeling_ .  I mean I've seen people cheer when 
they see something blow up or change into a bunny, but rarely when they all 
"just feel like it".  Thanks Wicked.

what's that Drip Drip song I always hear?
walrus@quack.kfu.com

Just a quick reminder to let everyone know about
tomorrow's SFR South Bay Lunch ...

When: Wednesday  
Time: 12:15ish to 1:15 or so ... 
Where: Greer Park, Palo Alto

Directions:

* From 101 (South or North) take the Oregon Expressway Exit
  Northbound: Past San Antonio Road 
  Southbound: Past University Avenue 

* Left at the first signal - W. Bayshore
  (it's a frontage road that takes you south again)

* Follow this road approx. 1/4 mile (pass apartment complexes on right)
  
* You will see the park on your right hand side. Turn into the first 
  driveway on your right.

* We'll meet on the grassy knoll , behind the round baseball fence.
  Next to the restrooms and ball courts.

Bring lunch, toys, yourselves!

	id IAA18568; Tue, 9 Aug 1994 08:23:49 -0700
Message-Id: <199408091523.IAA18568@netcom10.netcom.com>
X-Sender: nrg@localhost
Mime-Version: 1.0

Date: Tue, 9 Aug 1994 08:25:39 -0800
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: nrg@netcom.com (ethan miller)
Subject: Friends & Family
Cc: komotion@netcom.com
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Greetings Friends!

Just wanted to give everyone an informational and philosophical update 
on the upcoming Friends & Family which will be in SF this Saturday, 
August the 13th.

As you may know, F&F has always been a conscious attempt to provide a
smaller and more intimate alternative to the larger scale and often more
expensive traditional SF fare. Towards this end, certain things are, and
will continue to be, important to us. 

Primary amonsgt these is that this party be a collaborative, cooperative
effort. Experience has shown that nothing generates vibe like the
collective interaction of as many different creative people as possible. I
hasten to stress that this does not apply solely to 'peformers'; no party
is a party without the people who simply come to the party...as someone
that comes to this party, your input, suggestions and criticisms are
welcome before, during and after the party. On a larger scale, F&F
continues to evolve with parties roughly every six weeks, so if you want to
be a part of it, in any way shape or form, please let us know, we'd love to
have ya :)

Next is that F&F be home to a broad variety of dance and listening music
both intra-, and inter-event. We make it a point of including in every
party djs that will play: ambient and other forms of experimental
electronic music, djs that will play house, djs that will play trance, and
yes, djs that will play that poor bastard stepchild of the sf scene: techno
:) 

We are also going to make it a point to provide air time for evolving
talent. Every party will feature at least one, if not two djs or musicians
you have probably not heard before. 

As I mentioned above one of the other chief goals of this party is that it
be as inexpensive as possible. The arrangement we have with Komotion (the
space that houses this party) is that the party is a benfit for the space
(I have attached Komotion's blurb at the end of this post in case you're
interested). This one will support the audio and print magazine they
publish which, in my estimation, is fantastic material. Please seek it out;
you will enjoy it, in addition to which submissions are welcome so if you
have something to say consider it as a forum :). Future parties will go
towards making some improvements to the space though we would also like to
to do benefits for other worthy causes; suggestions are welcome. But in any
event, the $3 donation requested at the door is the bare minimum needed to
meet our costs and and the space's. As a matter of policy everyone involved
in the party works for free.

Lastly, one of the things that brings me the greatest joy about this party
and the ones that have preceded it is that they are sfr parties! With the
exception of Galen *every single person* involved is from sfr! Right On.

Okay now some specifics:

This party kicks off with the debut of Sean Casey. So come early and show
your support for new musical blood in the scene! We'll also get to hear
Giamma (who I haven't heard since the first F&F) who will finish the party
off with some house grooves in the morning :) Jon D returns with his hard
and often fiendish musical mayhem, Lee's gonna roll some trance, I'm gonna
spin some techno/trance and our Friend Galen from sunset will join us and
play... whatever he feels like :) John Howard has, unfortunately,
cancelled.

Doin the do in the multimedia, might-be-ambient, could-be-a-chillroom,
lounge, planet six is gonna get it goin, next is freezer of noc/noc fame
followed by Weird Blinking Lights who's new CD is a must-have. Next our
very own HDW who has indicated to me that he intends to twist our minds in
no uncertain fashion +) Mohsen will also join us. M, it turns out, will be
covering Woodstock for the Well, we'll miss her, Ovid may still do
something...

Visuals by our own Michael Clay and others (yes! yet more collaboration...)
Lasers by Sean Casey...
Audio by soundvision and the liquid sound system :)

There's still plenty of room for participation so if you wanna bring alter
materials, body paint, day glow string, additonal lighting, or a nude guy
or gal please feel free :)

This party is *all* ages, everyone is welcome! We will however enforce a
strict dress code: no one in long pants will be admitted. Thank you for
your cooperation in this matter.  +)

Komotion is located at 16th & Folsom in sf
party goes from 10pm til 7am
cost $3
additional info: 415.985.5244

looking forward to seeing you all there!
lots of love
ethan.


Komotion Blurb:

Komotion is an artist's collective, an alternative, an experiment. We are a
diverse group of musicians, writers, artists and engineers seeking to
create an environment that inspires and informs. Our multi-purpose arts
center is home to some 40 musicians who perform, rehearse and record here.
Our evening events, run by all-volunteer labor, are adventurous and bring
forward special talent. We have presented music of all kinds, art, poetry,
film, theatre, video and dance, as well as hosted numerous benefits. Our
engineers produce many recordings by emerging Bay Area artists in our
16-track studio. A core of writers works on our magazine, which provides a
forum for debate around cultural and political issues.

Komotion doesn't pay the performers at its events except to cover their
expenses. The door charge, drink prices, etc. are so low that in general,
we can only cover the rent and the basic expenses out of the events. Even
without money, however, many new acts and established artists have chosen
to perform here. Being artists ourselves, we put great care into the sound
and other aspects of the facility, to create the best possible experience
for performer and audience alike. The actual scheduling of events, editing
of the magazine, etc., is sone by committtee in a kind of anarchistic
fashion. We find things to be livelier with as few rules as possible.

Komotion has a current membership of about 300 locally and another 100 or
so internationally. At this point, our events are not "membership only" but
becoming a member is an expression of support for a center of this kind. On
our tenuous budget, *we need your support* to continue. Becoming a member
means contributing money or something neede for the Klub's operation. $5,
$10, $20, and $50 memberships are available, though donations of any amount
are welcome.

For more information: call: 415.648.4923; or email: komotion@netcom.com

laura sez:

deepfog says:

>The real dj's in the scene seem to be playing more music with beats and
>less synth.

I'm just curious -- what, pray tell, is a "real" DJ?

Laura

just keeping you on your toes, laura 8)

deeeeepfog

---------- Forwarded message ----------
Date: Tue, 9 Aug 1994 02:19:36 -0400
From: David A. Wolfe <woof@panix.com>
To: Multiple recipients of list NE-RAVES <NE-RAVES@umdd.umd.edu>
Subject: RaveStock (from Scotto)

--=====================_773668436==_
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"




--=====================_773668436==_
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"

Scotto came over and I thought I give him the opportunity, him
being net impaired and all :), to say hello.

****************insert scotto text here***************

Hi! First off, I am completely computer illiterate, but try to be
talented in other ways. Please bear with me as I am a virgin on
these machines. So here's the story before the book, pay-per-view,
documentary, and movie come out; SCOTTO STYLE.

A couple of years ago, lady Kier from Dee-lite and the Drop
Collective were passing around some ideals (and a joint) about the
future of "techno" and "house" in Rock-n-Roll Amerikka.  We came up
with the ultimate party RAVESTOCK.

After visiting her lawyer who also is Michael Lang's (woodstock),
we were advised of plans for W 2 and a potential lawsuit if the
rave were to take place. By that time, I had set the press wheels
in motion, (Details Jan "93). So after constant proposals, faxes,
phone calls, it came together about 12 days ago (a year later than
planned).  This was partially due to our prior relationship with
Metropolitan when they supported MASKARAVE 2 , part of the See the
Light Tour featuring Moby, Orbital, Aphex Twin, and Vapourspace.
There were 5,000. Also, the ORB simultaneously put in proposals to
Polygram/Woodstock et all. The most ridiculous part of this is the
lack of time and budget provided. At any rate, flyers are out, and,
it's happening.

We don't claim to be perfect. Events have conspired, in the past to
fuck up our events, and we have made some mistakes. But our
intention is, was and always will be to produce events that create
an environment that supports our community and that our community
supports. The ORB canceled a european date at a huge festival to be
with us @ RaveStock, Orbital has to fly in from london and fly
right the fuck out to france. AphexTwin has been true to the
underground vibe and he's with us. The Dj line up represents a
cross section of our styles, each of them respected. Frankie Bones,
legendary hardcore from Brooklyn; Keven Sauderson, a father of the
detroit techno scene; Doc Martin; fierceness personified from
LA/SF;Little Louis Vega has been house since before it was house
and Dimitry, from Dee-lite has been with us since our days at The
Red Zone and The World. DJs Louis and Alex Paterson represent some
of the best of the UK scene.

The Drop Collective with Liquid Sky Music (Soul Slinger) will
showcase new talent. Breakbeat and Jungle Vibes will close this
mutha event on Sunday.......Monday........whenever.......:)


NOW THE IMPORTANT PART--YOUR INVOLVEMENT  PART ONE

We are the next generation, right? We must show the rock-n-roll
folk what's up for the NEXT 25 YEARS and we MUST COME TOGETHER in
our love for electronic dance music and in the spirit of PLUR and
community support the future sounds. One of our goals has always
been to expand into mainstream (just enough) to "convert" heads
open the doors of consciousness, art and the spirit of community.


YOUR INVOLVEMENT PART TWO

If you are from the first Woodstock, or that generation of love,
you have the most crucial role of all. See, our generation looks
back at all the nostalgia, hype, myth, and the hopes and dreams of
an era of great social change.  But look at the 80's, look at what
hasn't changed. NOW we all could have a second chance, a second
revolution with your guidance and love. TEACH YOUR CHILDREN WELL,
teach us the whole deal and TOGETHER, IT WILL HAPPEN!
What will happen, you ask? Remember you are the baby boomers,
right?  Well we are the Babies of the Baby Boomers, so there's MORE
of us PLUS Ya'll. So what could happen....Legal Hemp, A different
government, an environmental political party,a sexual revolution?
I don't know. What I do know is that our generation is partly lost,
definitely confused, and we could use some guidance from those
who've been through a little bit more.

One last point, 25 years ago Woodstock peaked and probably hurt a
growing festival movement that basically died in Amerikka. It has
been thriving in EUROPE for years, and with the help of The Techno
scene, maybe, just maybe, Woodstock 2 could help launch another
wave of festivals here to spread the vibe 90's style and bridge the
barriers of racism, abuse, and empower a whole generation.
Woodstock '94 will define our generation and its the ideal vehicle
to introduce electronic dance music to a broad audience. It's set
to be the largest rave ever with 250,000 expected to attend
(175,000 tickets sold as of today) and millions more attending
virtually on PPV and on the net.

Thanks for listening to my rave :)
peace
Scotto
************************end scotto text**********************

So I go away to watch howard on letterman, and the next thing i
know the boys is gobbling up bandwidth like its goin outta styleee.
That's all for now (z'nuff z 'nuff, right) you can mail me at The
Well (woof@well.sf.ca.us) or at Panix (woof@panix.com).

Virtually
woof

Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.9/8.6.5) id OAA01090; Tue, 9 Aug 1994 14:48:38 -0700
Received: from nexsys.nexsys.net by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.9/8.6.5) with ESMTP id OAA01085; Tue, 9 Aug 1994 14:48:29 -0700
