Date: Tue, 9 Aug 1994 14:47:19 -0700
From: geoffw@nexsys.net (Geoff White)
Message-Id: <199408092147.OAA15650@nexsys.nexsys.net>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Results of the Raving and Sexual love survey
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


Here are the results of a survey that I posted several months ago to the list.
Just to remind everyone, here is the original post...



	It seems that this subject has never really been explored
	here on sfraves but I think if there ever was a place to talk
	about raving and sex/love this would be it.  First a few qualifiers,
	I'm using the term sexualove to try to be a little more accurate
	and to also side step some flames.  Sexualove is that special energy
	that you feel for (an)other(s) that would or could reach expression
	in a physical (sexual) way.  It doesn't mean that you have to actually
	"have sex" (but it could) but it is a "deeper" feeling then just the
	"platonic" emotions that have readily been shared.

	My questions are:

	1) How has your sex/love life, capacity, expression, etc. changed
	since you have been raving?

	2) For people who are single, do you find it easier or harder to get
	into a sexualove relationship now that you are a raver?

	3) For people in committed relationships, how has raving changed your
	sexualove cycles/behavior?

	4) Is making love to another raver "different" than making love to
	a "non-raver"?

	5) Does the Eros that is generated at some parties (like a Wicked)
	excite you or is it a turn off?

	6) Since you have become a raver, do you think that you are more or less
	open to exploring other sexualove lifestyles then the one you are
	currently practicing?

	7) Do you think ravers are more tolerant of other people's sexualove
	preferences?

	8) If you are at a party and the music is _really_ goin-off and
	a friend comes up to you (that you've wanted for sometime, I
	might add) and wants you to go with them to the chill-out room
	(obviously to make- out); do you go with them or do you stay on the
	dance-floor?

	9) For those of you who trance, how has this affected your sexualove
	life?  Do you enter trance states more easily while making love?  Does
	it get in the way of meeting perspective partners at a party (as in
	you look pretty funny with your eyes crossed :)

	10) How many of you now (or have) made love to music (house or
	otherwise) and how has this experience affected you?


I know some of these questions are pretty intimate, you can use some 
anonymous mailers to reply, if you don't want anyone to know who you are.

All in all 16 people actually replied with answers:

11  Males
3   females
2   I couldn't tell from the post


Here are some excerpts that don't quit fit anywhere else...

The year I was a heavy raver, I wasn't really
trying to use raves as a hunting ground for babes... and in
fact I think I was really relieved at the relatively
a-sexual quality of raves.  I'd spent a few years hanging
around in the club scene, and the intense defensiveness of
women in that meat-market type scene could really be a drag.
One of the cool things about raves is that people seemed
more focused on a "just be where you are" kind of attitude,
and not so much worrying about where they're going to wind
up that night. 

One way you might look at it, if you've got your love
phasers focused on just one person, you don't get to
experience and add to the group vibe that raves are about. 

If this is true, then what it really means is that raving by
itself can't really be a complete existence in itself.
There's got to be something else you're into, some other
social structures you're involved with.  It is a shame that
what you might call the existing courtship customs of this
culture are so inadequate, but it is a young culture after
all... only several decades since the death of the
Fifties...

========

Personally, one of the great draws of techno/rave music has been the tantric
rush I get from the big sub-bass slam beat. When I am dancing or listening
and move into a trance state, it seems to be always more grounded in the
earthy/sexual side of the spirit/soul than the lofty/religious ecstacy of
perhaps the Sufi trance dancers. Actually, I'm not that sure that these mind
sets are really that far apart, both being expressions of love and devotion
in their own ways...

As for making love to trance/dance/techno, I have unfortunately found few
partners in the last 20 years or so who were as interested as I in bedding
down to Nusrat Fateh Ali Khan, or Music for Airports, or any of the many
others disks in the library of this sort...(one girlfriend even complained
that Gershwin's "Rhapsody in Blue" had too come off the turntable one evening
because it was 'too compelling'...funny, I thought that was the whole point
of having the stereo on whilst in bed...


=======

Hi Geoff,
  I'm sorry I didn't answer your questionairre..
i've been way busy..
But just an observation..A lot of the current crop of ravers seem
almost asexual compared to the pre 1992 bunch.Sexual energy was
the rule,not the exception then.. now.. well..
Maybye I havn't been going out enough,but sometimes I'd rather
go out to a non-rave type club.. The ravers are too involved
with trying to out-cool each other now.. This didnt used to be so.
-C.

========

Here are some choice answers:

> 	1) How has your sex/love life, capacity, expression, etc. changed
> 	since you have been raving?

1.  Raving has definitely been a major part of the unfolding
of my expression of love, agape as well as eros.  In fact,
the Platonic kind of love engendered in both MDMA and the
virtual ecstasy of the vibe at good parties and the Apollonian
and Dionysian revelry unite to make all of us at these
celebrations realize our godliness or lighbody spirituality
in a world in which these aspects of "love" are too often
fragmented or even absent from our lives.  So I would call my
experiences evolutionary, having their roots in my being as well
as in my earliest religious experiences.

----
Not to sound trite, but I've found that I tend to beat match during
intercourse.  No really!  Matching my body's rocking and thrusting
movements with my partner's.  I guess raving has given me a greater
sense of beat and timing.  Other aspects of sex as covered in this
question remain unchanged from before when I raved.
----
1. Raving has definitely opened my mind towards sexuality. Although I am
still a straight male, I feel totally at ease with anyone's sexual
"expressions" at raves or anywhere else. Of course, Eros can bend anyone's
guidelines and rules...



>        2) For people who are single, do you find it easier or harder to get
>        into a sexualove relationship now that you are a raver?

2. It's much easier to get into a sexualove relationship. I've met some very
openly sexual lovers through the whole rave thing. Some very adventuresome,
passionate people, too.
----
For me it is difficult to say, as it really hasn't happened much (I
don't really pursue it, but I'm not unreceptive to it either). But I'd
say I'm a lot less hung up about feeling and getting intimate with
people.

>        3) For people in committed relationships, how has raving changed your
>        sexualove cycles/behavior?

My last boyfriend and I raved nearly every weekend.  It did have an effect
on our sex life . . . we'd have sex a lot less because we were always 
tired from being up all night.  When we both still did drugs, we'd take
acid, stay up all night,  and then after a rave we'd have breakfast,
take a shower, and have sex, and eventually fall asleep.  


>        4) Is making love to another raver "different" than making love to
>        a "non-raver"?

have only had this experience with one woman, so can't really generalize. but
i would say that the love-making was different, a bit more of a 'meeting' of th
  souls.



>	5) Does the Eros that is generated at some parties (like a Wicked)
>	excite you or is it a turn off?


Eros is a turn-on for me a lot of the time. Not in a way that makes me
want to pick up someone, but more in a way that adds a slight sexual
"taste" to the whole trance/vibe/music experience. It encourages me to
stay in touch with the sexual part of myself and acknowledge it in
others. The wholeness of our existence includes sexuality, and this
seems to carry it over into the rave experience. It's very nice.
Perhaps someday some of the "sexual good vibes" from a party might
carry over into a more private experience.



>        6) Since you have become a raver, do you think that you are more or les
>        open to exploring other sexualove lifestyles then the one you are
>        currently practicing?

I have thought about other sexlove lifestyles, and I don't mind the
thoughts,  I just don't know if I will act on them...
----


>        7) Do you think ravers are more tolerant of other people's sexualove
>        preferences?

i don't think ravers are that different. my experience with ravers is mostly
here in the bay area, where there is a more tolerant attitude in general.



>        8) If you are at a party and the music is _really_ goin-off and
>        a friend comes up to you (that you've wanted for sometime, I
>        might add) and wants you to go with them to the chill-out room
>        (obviously to make- out); do you go with them or do you stay on the
>        dance-floor?

>       9) For those of you who trance, how has this affected your sexualove
>       life?  Do you enter trance states more easily while making love?  Does
>       it get in the way of meeting perspective partners at a party (as in
>       you look pretty funny with your eyes crossed :)

i think that trancing has affected ALL my life, sex included. it seems to
allow me to connect to the whole world in new/different/unexpexted ways.
it has affected my sex life in my desire to travel with my lover to that
place 'in between' sexually. as for interferring with meeting people, on the
contrary, i think trancing has helped in making me more sensitive to other
people's vibes.

>        10) How many of you now (or have) made love to music (house or
>        otherwise) and how has this experience affected you?

10. I love getting down with the real deep stuff. Rave is fun; hardcore is
great if you have the stamina. But my favorite sexy music is actually deep
stuff like Massive Attack, One Dove... things that sound sexy with plenty o'
groove! It's gotta be deep and/or hard - just like the sex itself!

---------- Forwarded message ----------
From: Troy Sheets <tsheets@chaph.usc.edu>
Subject: The Future of Rave Culture...
Date: Mon, 8 Aug 1994 00:11:51 -0700 (PDT)

	I just got back from Sunset and I have to say that this is 
simply the coolest twist on raving.  There, at the Berkeley Marina, 
there was so much vibe, so much love, that you could almost
see it like a cloud above you.  Everyone there was simply "into" it.
I don't think I have ever been to an event where I have seen so many
positive, happy, smiling people.  The music system, the DJ, the location,
everything seemed virtually perfect.  I really think that this is what
raving should evolve into, a daytime activity.
	During the day everyone is just so much more awake, alive. 
There at the Marina, people would walk by and they would be just
in awe at what they were seeing:  about 100 young people thoroughly
enjoying themselves in a peaceful, positive way.  (Rave PR would be
no problem if they were all during the day!).  Okay, I'll stop 
commenting on this event.  All I can say is, check it out!
	Logistics:  We had to leave early, much to my dismay, because
someone in our party was just too cold.  If you don't plan on dancing
the whole time, then bring some VERY warm clothes (big jackets
were being worn by a lot of people).  If there are any people on the 
net who are involved with the Pacific Soundsystem, please e-mail me.

-troy

>But just an observation..A lot of the current crop of ravers seem
>almost asexual compared to the pre-1992 bunch. Sexual energy was
>the rule, not the exception then.. now.. well..

asexuality and ambiguity is fun
rawer blatant sexual energy is fun
any form of sexual energy as inspiration seems fair game

note, however, that I would make a distinction between 
overt sexuality as an energy source or cool body trip
and getting hit-on ala meat market style 

also, this *really* seems to go with the music which sometimes
draws on an aggressive feeling, or maybe a silly/fuzzy bear
feeling, or whatever
personally, I am a real sucker 
for a low down sweaty groove ...

>Maybe I havn't been going out enough, but sometimes I'd rather
>go out to a non-rave type club.. The ravers are too involved
>with trying to out-cool each other now.. This didnt used to be so.
>-C.

it strikes me, sometimes, as out-cooling at being not cool
an "i am a serious raver" syndrome
true to the underground shit
don't clutter me

I like rave tourists who maybe just dropped by after a cocktail party
They are there to have fun -  just like the beyond e hardcore til dawn
folks are.  Bring them in.  Use them.

I like poking fun.  Dancing fools.  Self-mockery is ok. 
I like a room full of bad ass motherfuckers ready to go OUT 
I like the Shit right there, right now, whatever it is I am
gonna make it happen on the Fly  
I am gonna take it, and Spin it, and throw it back
I am going to speak when I have something to say
You do what you want, what you can, When you can
this is the Timing - the collaboration
and you Know 
that everyone else Knows
how really really Cool you are

Love ya,
Dave

>From: Troy Sheets <tsheets@chaph.usc.edu>
>Subject: The Future of Rave Culture...
>Date: Mon, 8 Aug 1994 00:11:51 -0700 (PDT)
>
> I just got back from Sunset and I have to say that this is 
>simply the coolest twist on raving.   I really think that this is what
>raving should evolve into, a daytime activity.
> During the day everyone is just so much more awake, alive. 
>There at the Marina, people would walk by and they would be just
>in awe at what they were seeing:  about 100 young people thoroughly
>enjoying themselves in a peaceful, positive way.  (Rave PR would be
>no problem if they were all during the day!).

I really think this is true.  Although for most people who don't rave, 
there is a fear of "abandon", of letting go, nevertheless they could be 
tricked into it :-) if the other aspects were accessible to them.

However, I only know [personally] one other person (outside of those met at 
raves or in rave-culture) who is at all willing or capable of doing 
anything between midnight and dawn (other than being asleep at home :-) ).
 
While it is true that the 3 hours before dawn is the best time for trance-
inducing activities, nonetheless if extending rave culture to others is a 
consideration, then perhaps Troy is right that more daytime events are 
needed.  Perhaps "In the Light" could be held more often?
respect to all,

Ken            ken@snowcrest.net   (primary address)
               (if no answer, try ken.stuart@tigerteam.org )

Hello Brian,

It seems that in my posts about DJs and events, most people reacted more to 
the concept of pigeonholing them with one or two words, rather than the 
concept of giving people more information about events.

This must have been due to my use of language, since there have been many 
posts on sfraves calling for more information about events.

Ultimately, I'm not at all interested in reducing things to one or two 
words - maybe I'm still not used to cheap 650MB disk drives :-).

So, perhaps the ftp site could have a directory for events, with sub-
directories for each name (Basics, Wicked, etc.) containing reviews and 
experiences that have been posted to sfraves.

So, for example, someone who reads the bare bones listing for the recent 
"Anthem of the Sun" would have somewhere to look for a description that 
would help them to evaluate which event to choose for that night.
respect to all,

Ken            ken@snowcrest.net   (primary address)
               (if no answer, try ken.stuart@tigerteam.org )

i get a sneaking suspicion (as does comrade Penna) that Ken Stuart 
<ken@snowcrest.net> has not been to a rave.  this is a damn shame, 
because he is missing out on a lifestyle that he is obviously curious 
about because he subscribes to sfraves.  If Ken Stuart 
<ken@snowcrest.net> chooses to continue on this path, a no growth 
situation will continue and stagnation will occur.  it will be much like 
the rest of america that watches television to try to get all their 
information.  it is much easier to go eat a burger king everyday and sit 
at home and watch television and use the computer and other electronic 
media as a substitute for seeing the real thing.  

however, i hope that Ken Stuart <ken@snowcrest.net> will choose a 
different pathway, one that is much happier and will lead to much more 
spiritual, emotional, and physical growth.  if Ken Stuart 
<ken@snowcrest.net> chooses to make it down to where Tony V Garcia 
<deepfog@cats.ucsc.edu> exists in harmony with the ocean, Tony V Garcia
<deepfog@cats.ucsc.edu> will TREAT Ken Stuart <ken@snowcrest.net> to his 
first rave.  and provided he is a nice person and is NOT a COP, he will 
even allow him to trance, which in my opinion, is exactly what Ken Stuart 
<ken@snowcrest.net> needs, but is hiding from that fact and denying that 
it can help him in any way.  

well, ken, now there are no excuses.  dont' bother responding to this 
with an argument on every line.  if you don't want to go to a rave, don't 
even bother responding to this post, because you will be wasting my time 
and your time and about 900 other people's time.  

Tony V Garcia <deepfog@cats.ucsc.edu>

I don't think Ken is wasting anyone's time. If he has or hasn't been
to a rave is irrelevant. If you _must_ judge what he says, then judge
it on the strength of content, and not on who you believe him to be.

If we take the position that someone who hasn't had "the experience"
doesn't have something worthwhile to say, then we potentially turn a
deaf ear to wisdom.

Ken has made some valid points; I also think he displays a
"non-insider" perspective sometimes, and might benefit from a
first-hand experience. But let's not demand it as a condition for
considering what he says.

Sean

From: lxfogel@srv.PacBell.COM (Lee Fogel)
Message-Id: <9408102320.AA01481@pbssi.srv.PacBell.COM>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Re: Event database?
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

 "Ken Stuart" writes:
 > So, for example, someone who reads the bare bones listing for the recent 
 > "Anthem of the Sun" would have somewhere to look for a description that 
 > would help them to evaluate which event to choose for that night.

If you are referring to a previous "Anthem of the Sun" party, I think
it happened a year ago, at a different venue, with some different DJs and
a *completely* different outcome that this year's version.  I've been to
Basics parties at the Richmond Civic Center, the Stone, the Trocadero,
and at an armory, and as far as I'm concerned, they were *very* different
parties: Being at one (let alone reading about one) would not have
prepared me for the next one.  I could say something similar about Wickeds
also.

When I first started raving about 3 years ago, I was greatly disturbed
at the unpredictability of the experience.  Not being able to know where
I was going until just hours before going out was abhorrant to me.  After
a while, you do pick up an intuitive sense of direction, but there still 
aren't *any* garauntees as to what kind of an rave you can expect on any
given night.  I think clubs can give you that kind of predictability,
but for me, an almost hopeless control freak, the chaos of raving has been
very liberating, teaching me to live more in the Now instead of worrying
and trying to predict what will be.  Raving taught me to take risks, to
let go of expectations, and to be prepared to be surprised or disappointed.
And if I just went to the parties that suited my tastes 3 years ago, I may 
have never learned and discovered other kinds of parties that I *thought* 
I would never be able to enjoy.    
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
Lee Fogel/\/\/\/\/\eVerything/\Is/\possiBlE/\/\/\/\/\lxfogel@srv.pacbell.com
____________________________________________________________________________

Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

On Wed, 10 Aug 1994, Sean Casey wrote:
> "Ken Stuart" writes:
>  > So, for example, someone who reads the bare bones listing for the recent 
>  > "Anthem of the Sun" would have somewhere to look for a description that 
>  > would help them to evaluate which event to choose for that night.
>  > respect to all,
> 
> I think this would be a great idea. Collect reviews and make them
> available via FTP or WWW. Then newbies (and us oldbies) could browse
> them and find out what other people thought.

The answer is even better.  I'm working on creating hypermail versions of the
sfraves archives, as well as implementing a fast WAIS-like (but not wais,
something better called glimpse) keyword search, so you can look for "Wicked"
for example and get back every post that had that term in it.  I dunno that I
could do it very easily through FTP, and I think the number of people with
FTP access but without access to even a rudimentary WWW browser like Lynx is
vanishingly small. 

	Brian

On Wed, 10 Aug 94 18:49:48 EDT, Sean Casey wrote:

>I don't think Ken is wasting anyone's time. If he has or hasn't been
>to a rave is irrelevant. If you _must_ judge what he says, then judge
>it on the strength of content, and not on who you believe him to be.
>
>If we take the position that someone who hasn't had "the experience"
>doesn't have something worthwhile to say, then we potentially turn a
>deaf ear to wisdom.
>
>Ken has made some valid points; I also think he displays a
>"non-insider" perspective sometimes, and might benefit from a
>first-hand experience. But let's not demand it as a condition for
>considering what he says.

Thank you.

I would only like to add that first-hand experience does not necessarily 
produce an "insider" perspective.

And, is the insider/non-insider dichotomy really in line with the rave 
perspective?  Or is it that we feel unity only with those who happen to be 
there?
respect to all,

Ken            ken@snowcrest.net   (primary address)
               (if no answer, try ken.stuart@tigerteam.org )

On Wed, 10 Aug 94 16:20:53 PDT, Lee Fogel wrote:

> "Ken Stuart" writes:
> > So, for example, someone who reads the bare bones listing for the recent 
> > "Anthem of the Sun" would have somewhere to look for a description that 
> > would help them to evaluate which event to choose for that night.
>
>If you are referring to a previous "Anthem of the Sun" party, I think
>it happened a year ago, at a different venue, with some different DJs and
>a *completely* different outcome that this year's version.  I've been to
>Basics parties at the Richmond Civic Center, the Stone, the Trocadero,
>and at an armory, and as far as I'm concerned, they were *very* different
>parties: Being at one (let alone reading about one) would not have
>prepared me for the next one.  I could say something similar about Wickeds
>also.

Thanks for your reasoned reply.

However, isn't something being said by the promoter when he uses the same 
name?  There is an implicit claim of continuity.  Hence, reading an sfraves 
post about the previous occurrence of that event should at least tell one 
what the promoter is trying to tell us it will be like.

And, if the review of the previous "Anthem of the Sun" says "... first DJ 
started spinning at midnight...", then one at least knows that there is no 
real "Sun" aspect, despite the name :-) .

>When I first started raving about 3 years ago, I was greatly disturbed
>at the unpredictability of the experience.

That's not much of a problem for me, I can't even predict if my car will 
get there. :-)  

>Lee Fogel/\/\/\/\/\eVerything/\Is/\possiBlE/\/\/\/\/\lxfogel@srv.pacbell.com
respect to all,

Ken            ken@snowcrest.net   (primary address)
               (if no answer, try ken.stuart@tigerteam.org )

From: anthrax@uclink.berkeley.edu (Ann Elizabeth Loraine)
Message-Id: <199408111740.KAA17762@uclink.berkeley.edu>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: last weekend
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


Hi!  the sunset party was really great:  those of you who got there early
got to hear Gavin Hardkiss' ambient set...he doesn't dj hardly at all &
so you guys pat yourselves on the back for getting to hear something really
special.  I'm so bummed i missed it!

I am a big fan of the Hardkisses in general- i'm hoping they'll keep doing
stuff in the "scene" like playing these littler parties...Robbie Hardkiss
spun sunday, too...he is the shit.  It was soooo nice!  His music makes me
feel all mintyfresh/grungyfunky.  

I'm very glad to see Galen is playing Friends and Family this Saturday.  You
guys that haven't heard him and who like a technoey sound will probably
enjoy it.  He does the faster shade of a house.  Does anybody else out there
feel the way I do?: that Galen's sets make your brain as well as your
body move?

Yes, it's true...i'm in the cult o' dj's.  'cause they are artists!  give
a dj a crowd, a setting, a musical problem (like...play ambient & then
make a transition into house...for example!) ...and watch what goes down.


The New Moon party went off at a location on Lower Haight.  The site 
fit not too many people & so it was a smallish party.  Lotsa of the 
same people from previous parties showed, which was very nice.  Also some
folks from all over the place.  One guy from LA brought party favors-
basically stuff he picked up off the ground and then embellished with
crystals, stick-on rhinestones, etc.  He spins ambient & hopefully will
be able to come up again to do so soon!

I just want to say that the people who were there were so incredibly
cool...respectful of the space, open-minded, friendly, enlightened, cute
/angelic.  The ages were pretty much mixed, but as usual there were a 
lot of younger people...i am so incredibly proud of this generation of
people coming up.  they get a lot of sh*t in the media that they don't
deserve.

the space is a basement gallery that is slowly being fixed up to 
resemble the ancient city of Atlantis!  (or so it seemed to me..) the
front room was painted blue & had artificial fish hanging from the
ceiling.  there was also a huge fish tank as well as a large orb lit
from within.  the dance area was smallish, but adequate for the crowd.
we set up foam and cushions in another room where people chilled out.
smoking was allowed outside by the back door.

i talked a lot with ishmael, one of the guys that donated the space.  he
was very much into the idea of ambient music stimulating thought, slowing
people down, encouraging reflection and meditation.  he was soooo
cool to let us also do dance music, even though he could have been in
trouble with the authorities because of noise complaints.  i heard
you can get a $300 fine if you disturb the peace too often in SF.  is
(i just heard that somewhere...)

quotes from Ishmael:  "Cats have more chakras than humans"
			"the youth need to slow down"

ain't it the truth!  but imho, the youth need to DANCE!

(and dance they did!)

Thanks thanks thanks go out to Ishmael, Bryce for spinning & bringing
Metrovision & just generally being incredibly cool, as always, Sean
for bringing fans, Maui for being there & dancing her butt off, Harlan
for the lights, Gregg Helt for organizing & bringing foam & blankets,
Philip for DATing.  you guys are what make it happen!

love,

annthrax

Just got back from the Oasis party and I must say there were lots of 
people there, and on a wednesday, allright!  If you called the info line, 
didn't it seem like the guy kept on going, and going and even still 
going? 
I had a good time seeing the crowd grow as time went on and there were 
even a few shouts going out now and then later into the night, it was a 
good club-type-general-carefree-feeling-with-the-feeling-someone's-
watching you drinking a Samuel Adams... Visuals were good a la slides 
through a colorwheel amd various disco strobes and spots made sure you 
couldn't easily kick back and watch.  Free water at le bar! with ice and 
a straw even!  Such a deal.  and it was free to get in, too!  Is this a 
regular Oasis thing on wednesdays?

I heard that drip-a-drip song again.  It always tweaks my melon just a bit!
I met Harry Who for the first time and he gave me all these flyers for 
Groove Kitchen and Pure Space tonight in SF.  Hey Harry, thanks for 
saying hi, what is your e-mail address?

All in all an excellent weeknight-club-rave-thing.  ...go SJRaves!
willis
walrus@quack.kfu.com

Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


> Yes, it's true...i'm in the cult o' dj's.  'cause they are artists!  give
> a dj a crowd, a setting, a musical problem (like...play ambient & then
> make a transition into house...for example!) ...and watch what goes down.

I'll just take this little opportunity to throw in a plug for my roommate's
new CD ("Let the Magic Flow" by Deluxe).  It's half ambient and half dance,
and the tracks are all mixed together.  It goes back and forth between ambient
and dance and back to ambient and back to dance again.

The CD isn't out yet.  The release date is "around Labor Day".

(A number of people have asked me when we'll be coming out with some new
Ultraviolet Catastrophe material.  This CD is aobut as close as you'll get.
It's 99% Jeff, but Jon D and I both made small contributions as well.)

From: csc@pilot.njin.net (Sean Casey)
Message-Id: <9408112058.AA18113@pilot.njin.net>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Sunset party and NMR
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

As Ann said, both these parties were really nice. The weather was
perfect for the Sunset party. There were about 40-60 people there
sharing smiles and a good time. Oh I do love parties like that :).

The NMR went really well in the lower Haight. Music selection was a
bit eclectic :), but the basic groove was there and smiles and
dancing were shared by all. Very trippy space! Kudos to Bryce for
bringing the sound, to Harlan for his excellent (and excellently
appropriate) lights, and for the altar and munchies provided by Gregg
and Ann.

My Fans from Hell (sm) performed well in their second party test,
evacuating most of the smoke and providing a minor hurricane for the
dance floor :). Check em out at Komotion this Saturday. "High Velocity
Air Circulator" (ahem) at Price Club for $40. These are seriously
powerful fans with a 5 year warranty at a great price. I love these
things and I highly recommend getting a couple if you throw indoor
parties.

See you all Saturday! I'm spinning! Wheeeee.... :)

Sean

Derek's out of town this week so he asked me to pass this along.
It looks like QUITE a busy weekend - two on Friday and five parties on 
Saturday (including at least three outdoor parties) so there should be NO 
excuse to not get out and boogie.  Friends and Family has become the
quasi-formal SFR get-together and collaborative venture, so come on down 
and meet the family :)  

Have fun!

	Brian, reprising the role...

From: csc@pilot.njin.net (Sean Casey)
Message-Id: <9408112311.AA22573@pilot.njin.net>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: If you're thinking of going to F&F III...
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

A few words of advice:

Say hi to me! I'll be wearing my white T-shirt with a _big_ Bach on
the front and back. I'm tall, thin, and smile too much :). And I know
lots of people, so if you're new to this, I'll take you around and
introduce you to some very nice people. And I'll be *real* easy to
find between 10 and 11 :) :) :).

Wear very light clothes!!!  The last F&F was insane with about 200
people shakin it inside most of the night.  We're going to have major
fannage, but it's still going to get **hot** in there--expect it and
prepare. At the very least, bring shorts.  Water is _free_, so drink
all you want, we'll pour more :).

F&F II filled up really fast! We got back after dinner at about 9:45
and there were already 10 or 20 people dancing. The place was packed
by 11:30. So you might want to come out early...

Bring toys, bubbles, paints, lights, slinkies, munchies, blo-pops,
anything you want.

As the last time: $3, all ages, ins&outs, free water, lots of good
attitude, and some really great DJing. (I haven't heard Jon Drukman or
Ethan spin in quite a while. I can't wait :). And we're setting up SO
early that everything should be right on time.

Remember, light (or no) clothes...

See you there!

Sean

On Thu, 11 Aug 1994, Sean Casey wrote:
> I don't know how it would fit in with current plans, but it'd be kind
> of nice to be able to search specifically for reviews...

Agreed - but unless someone wants to sift through the archives going
"this is a review" and extracting them, being able to keyword search
for "review" or "Wicked" is the next best thing.  Besides, many reviews 
turn into full threads on subtopics, and many posts are compound reviews, 
and many posts are not entirely reviews but talk about events, etc...

Sameer - I know about and appreciate the hypermail archive you have
running at c2; I want to put past archives under this as well as 
the keyword search mechanism.

From sfraves-owner  Fri Aug 12 12:44:43 1994
Return-Path: owner-sfraves
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.9/8.6.5) id MAA19411; Fri, 12 Aug 1994 12:44:43 -0700
Received: from relay1.UU.NET by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.9/8.6.5) with ESMTP id MAA19404; Fri, 12 Aug 1994 12:44:36 -0700
Received: from sco.sco.COM by relay1.UU.NET with SMTP 
	id QQxcre23491; Fri, 12 Aug 1994 15:44:02 -0400
Received: from moscow.sco.COM by sco.sco.COM
	id ab21898; Fri, 12 Aug 94 13:40:17 PDT
Received: by moscow.sco.com id aa23731; 12 Aug 94 12:44 PDT
From: Andrew Knutsen <andrewk@sco.COM>
To: Jay_Kravitz@laobridge.ucop.edu, sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: New Music for Jay
X-Mailer: SCO Portfolio 2.0
Date: Fri, 12 Aug 1994 12:43:55 -0700 (PDT)
Message-ID:  <9408121244.aa23725@moscow.sco.com>
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


> Suggestions for possible places to get them are also helpful.  Although I have
> most of the recent postings on great places to buy music, I would appreciate
> some direction.  Thanks. ;-)

        Try telnet to cdconnection.com and cdeurope.com.  They have
about 300,000 titles between them -- 100,000 domestic and 200,000 european
(the european listings are about twice as expensive and include a lot
of singles, cassettes and vinyl).  They like VISA.  I've bought about
150-200 discs from the domestic side and been happy with the service.
You can even ftp the domestic database.

        I just went through the stuff mentioned in the alt.raves "favorites"
thread, and ordered about 15 of them.  Its worth checking the domestic for
things you find on the european because of the price difference.

Andrew

PS they also have modem access, with lots of local numbers.
AK
-----------------------------------------
Andrew Knutsen            andrewk@sco.com
Santa Cruz Operation      (408) 427-7538

Precedence: bulk


	This mail is from Andrew Morin of EPIC Productions:

--------------------------------------------------------------------------

	Having visited Arizona up to August 10 this is the scoop so far:

	The organizers of the World Unity Festival are presently in disarray.
There are conflicts among many of those who are working, thus far for no
pay, on the event and the main person organizing the festival is under
intense stress as things fail to come together.  It just feels like a
period when organizing the world on this level just isn't working out
well for many.  In any case, the festival does not at this time have a
site.  Both the Sky Dome at the University which was to be the site for
the two day concert on Sat.  amd Sun.  August 27 and 28, as well as a
site for the week long free portion of the event have not been secured.
With the conflicts amongst the ranks of the organizers as well a s the
problem with sites I just don't see how things are going to come
together properly given that only ten days remaining to the official
opening date of the event on August 22.

	With the Unity Festival having such severe problems it appears
very problematic to attempt the rave.  At best it would be a one night
event given that it would need to be guerrilla.  The bottom line at this
point is that several thousands of people are going to be showing up in
northern Arizona for an event that may not come off at all.  The
enterprising raver could bring a sound system and DJs down and probably
put on a party, but there is trouble in the air because of the
disorganized state of things down there.  EPIC and Fraser Clark are
keeping our options open.  We will probably be attending Narnia in
northern San Diego County.  If the Unity Festival organizers have
pulled off a miracle,  we might then head to Arizona to do the
guerrilla.  I'll keep you posted on the ever shifting sands of the south
west.

Andrew Morin, EPIC Productions

Precedence: bulk


I haven't seen any articles on the topic, so I figured I'd be the first to
   draw attention to the lamitude of ws94.  Like many of you, I've followed
   this obviously mainstream, commcerialized, overhyped, etc. mega-event
   from a distance.  These qualities are not themselves indicative of
   a non-happening devoid of the community feelings that we know well as
   part of sfr - but let's face it:  when you grab a random sample of
   people booked to see the bands that are playing ws94, promoted on
   televison, etc. - you're getting a pretty unexceptional mix of people,
   and the crowds have never had a great deal of spirit, community, or
   otherwise egoless, open, unselfish motives.  From what I've read of the
   original, it's what made it exceptional.

Anyway, the main thrust of this is to perhaps masturbate as I share the
   sentiment that if the Saugerites folk really want to experience the
   feelings that the original ws goers felt, they should hit an sfrave
   (like F+F or LA, not Sharon...).  I need not preach to this crowd about
   vibe - you enlightened me.  Regurgitation is for the classroom and the
   bathroom.

Obviously, this is set against the more cynical backdrop of the 90s, as
   opposed to the comparatively cheery optimism of the 60s, brimming with
   anything-is-possible ideals rather than, it-should-be-possible-why-isn't- 
   it-happening ideals... I think it's safe to say that most people prefer
   the realism, even if it's coupled with frustration.  The sfravers all
   have day jobs and make no pretense that the scene is about anything
   other than having a harmless good time, and promoting good will.

On a concluding note, those of you with access should check out today's
   (sat) New York Times, and its article(s) on the saugerites event.  In
   the inner page is a terrific (I mean that both ways) photo of three guys
   snapping photos and leering at a topless woman (her back to the nyt camera).
   There are two women in the background staring at her like she's crazy.
   Pictures say a thousand words, and that photo easily replaces this review.

peace, vibe, and community
adam

and making a fake bubble? - Bucky Fuller)

further, that nature is not irrational

Virtual communities are not like real life communities.
There are more fantasies and projections.
It is a step beyond the telephone - which is hard enough
for me to talk on.  Subtleties are lost.  Body language. 

I am not going to pick up your mail or feed your dog
I don't have jumper cables

I do not really care about you
other than the loss I might experience
if you were to stop posting
sorta like a power outage during my favorite tv show
my concern goes as far as my desire to be entertained by you 

One thing virtual communities 
have in common with real communities
is the occasional 
Psycho Neighbor

watch out,

On Sat, 13 Aug 1994, David Alves wrote:
> Virtual communities are not like real life communities.
> There are more fantasies and projections.

Fantasies and projections don't happen in real life, too.  Look at anyone 
who idolizes someone else they hang around.

> It is a step beyond the telephone - which is hard enough
> for me to talk on.  Subtleties are lost.  Body language. 

New subtleties are created.  Language becomes *very* important - 
being able to express yourself explicitly becomes the order of the day.  
Real-life subtleties that shouldn't matter (color of your skin, social 
status, hair color, etc) are lost.

> I am not going to pick up your mail or feed your dog
> I don't have jumper cables

I don't know my neighbors, really, and have never asked them to watch my 
mail or feed the pets.  I rely on others on the net in a neighborly sense 
to a much greater degree than I rely on those who live in close proximity 
to me.

> I do not really care about you
> other than the loss I might experience
> if you were to stop posting
> sorta like a power outage during my favorite tv show
> my concern goes as far as my desire to be entertained by you 

Hmm... I wish I could impress upon you how strongly connected I feel to 
other people I share the Internet with, but it's a personal thing I suppose.

> One thing virtual communities 
> have in common with real communities
> is the occasional 
> Psycho Neighbor

This is true :):)

Read "Virtual Communities" by Howard Rheingold.  Or even SFRaves archives 
from late 92 or so :)

	Brian

From sfraves-owner  Sat Aug 13 22:15:40 1994
Return-Path: owner-sfraves
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.9/8.6.5) id WAA04813; Sat, 13 Aug 1994 22:15:40 -0700
Received: from scruz.net by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.9/8.6.5) with ESMTP id WAA04808; Sat, 13 Aug 1994 22:15:37 -0700
Received: from cruzio.com by scruz.net (8.3/1.34)
	id WAA22799; Sat, 13 Aug 1994 22:15:28 -0700
Subject: What Is *Language* in the Virtual and Physical Worlds?
To: brian@hyperreal.com
Date: Sat, 13 Aug 94 22:15:22 PDT
From: William Penna <wpenna@cruzio.com>
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
In-Reply-To: <Pine.3.89.9408131708.D1132-0100000@taz.hyperreal.com>; from "Brian Behlendorf" at Aug 13, 94 5:53 pm
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.3 PL0]
Message-ID:  <9408132215.aa03881@cruzio.com>
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Hi Brian and other virtual folx--

In his Re: Virtualness post, Brian sez:

> New subtleties are created.  Language becomes *very* important -
> being able to express yourself explicitly becomes the order of the day.
> Real-life subtleties that shouldn't matter (color of your skin, social
> status, hair color, etc) are lost.

If there's one thing I've learned about language it's that
virtually *everything* is language: those "subtleties that 
shouldn't matter" are ever-present even in the VR world of
cyber communication. In place of "color of your skin,
social status, hair color, etc.," we have spelling, organization,
form of discourse (mediation, argumentation, narrative,
abstract synthesis, etc.), conceptualization of one's realtion
with "the world" and others, point of view which *reflects*
color of your skin, hair color, social status, etc.

In other words, we *never* get away from those subtleties
that *you* say "shouldn't matter" because what we say and how
we say it are further abstractions of, to some degree or other, all
of them.  So it's very important to get to know each other's
context to get the best possible communication.

Which brings me back to Ken Stuart, who continuously argues that
it's not important for him to meet us at raves.  My answer is that
to the extent that context is missing, communication is less complete.
While your hair color may be of little import, I don't believe
in "shouldn'ts" and I know enough of the human condition that we
can say "shouldn't" as often as we want and we will not wipe away
that importance, lesser or greater that it may be in each communicAa-      
tions situation we have face-to-face.  "Should" and "shouldn't"
do not exist, and invoking them can be dangerous.

Of course, what you meant came from what I interpret as good
intention, largely because I know you.  I know you are not
trying to impose a moral order on us, but rather expressing 
your desire for clear communication somehow based on a standard
of explicit expression, whatever that is.  Sounds simple,
but it is eeven *more* difficult in the world of virtual
communities, where our abstraction  of printed language is
based on a more abstract concept of who we're communicating
with than it is in the physical world.  Example: look at how
David and Brian, Will and Ken conceptualize VR communication
*so* differently! In physical communication *all* of our
physical instrumentalities come into play during the 
communications process; in VR they are contracted into a
very few.  If Rheingold ignores or skims over this all-important
difference between the two communications media, his discussion
has little or no value. The medium *is* both the message and
the massage, and attempts to over-simplify this will not
shed light on how communication takes place and what some of
the most basic filters are!

This topic comes up *so* often and--in my view as a student of
communications-- is so often (usually out of a perceived need
to soothe flamers) over-simplified that we spin our wheels over 
and over about it.

What do *you* think?

ciao,
Will

-- 
Will Penna               408.423 8907         wpenna@cruzio.com
The world reflects what you need to see, not only what you want to see.
ILLUMINATIONS  Stephen C.Paul & Gary Max Collins  HarperSanFrancisco  1991

On Sat, 13 Aug 1994, David Alves wrote:

> 
> Virtual communities are not like real life communities.
> There are more fantasies and projections.
> It is a step beyond the telephone - which is hard enough
> for me to talk on.  Subtleties are lost.  Body language. 

 I disaggre...  If you've ever been on a MOO for a couple weeks you've 
seen that, like many things, when one thing is taken away, one or more 
things apper to take its place.. In the case of virtual communities that 
would be your typing skill, and vocabulary, etc.... 
 
> I am not going to pick up your mail or feed your dog
> I don't have jumper cables

 You don't have someone to feed your dog or read your mail, rather you 
have a mail sifting program, and maybe someone to log on for you while 
your on vacation so your mail doesn't overflow...  YOu don't have jumper 
cables, but when you have a system crash your have virus programs...
 
> I do not really care about you
> other than the loss I might experience
> if you were to stop posting
> sorta like a power outage during my favorite tv show
> my concern goes as far as my desire to be entertained by you 

 Not true, as i interpritate it, i some people on this mailing list left, or
some of my MOOing buddies stopped logging on, i feel the same as if my 
best freind moved, or stopped talking to me... I don't know about you, 
but just because their virtual doesn't mean their anyless real...

> One thing virtual communities 
> have in common with real communities
> is the occasional 
> Psycho Neighbor

 hah....  this is true...  But in real communities you kan't delete your 
neighbors house... 

> 
> watch out,
> Dave
 
 As they say on NBC, and all thoughs news broadcasts, "If you wouldn't 
let your child walk down a dark alley, at night, you probly shouldn't let 
them login."   Watch your back is more like it, don't watch your TV...

benr.
daaryon

RADIO! RADIO!   -  Status Report 1

What???: An SFR picnic , with music provided by SFR DJs , and simultaneous
         local broadcast by FM stereo micro-transmitter.
Where: South Bay city of Sunnyvale , Sunnyvale Baylands Park , the Owl Burrow 
        picnic area .
When: Saturday , Aug. 20th , from 1PM to ?? ( no later than 8PM is suggested,
       as vehicles must leave the park by 8:30PM ).
Directions: To be supplied later this week - at the intersection of Lawrence 
            Expressway and Highway 237.

Site amenities : One barbecue pit with a 20" x 70" grilling area . Water 
  faucets and drains. Electrical outlets. Recycling bins. Restrooms and pay 
  phones.  Big playhouse with slide for those SFRavers with kids. Big meadow 
  nearby - nice steady afternoon breeze for kite flying! 

   Stroll around the park and see the wonders (?) of the nearby salt marsh 
  and estuary. However ,alcohol is allowed within the bounds of the picnic 
  area only - no staggering around the park with a brewskie in your hand .


REQUEST FOR STUFF: I will be bringing some ice cream and/or sherbert packed 
in dry ice for the kids ( and for the adults too ! ). The spot that I'm 
thinking of for setting up the mixer has some shade in the afternoon, so I 
don't think we need a canopy. Other than that, I'm hoping that folks will 
volunteer to bring stuff -

Table for mixer and turntables.

Charcoal for the barbecue ( I think two large bags should be enough - could 
those folks who are going to bring something to grill please email me , so I 
can estimate how much charcoal to get ).

Food and drink - How do folks want to do this - bring your own food & drink , 
or do a shared potluck kind of thing? I'm willing to buy some bags of ice to 
keep the soda cold , if we're sharing .

                 That's if for now!
                 Larry Ching / larryc@netcom.com

RADIO! RADIO! - Directions to Sunnyvale Baylands Park

General notes: 

 There is a huge softball complex called Twin Creeks located right next to 
Sunnyvale Baylands Park. There should be enough signs to tell you which 
one you're at. The entrance of Sunnyvale Baylands Park is at the intersection 
of Moffet Park Drive and Caribbean Drive ; the main part of the park is at 
the southeast quadrant of the Caribbean Drive/Lawrence Expressway/
HW 237 intersection.

 Parking at Sunnyvale Baylands Park is $3.00 per vehicle. Cars are allowed
in the park until 8:30PM , the park itself closes at 9PM.

FROM THE SAN FRANCISCO PENINSULA :
First , get to HW 237 -

  HW 280 - South , past Palo Alto . Take the HW 85 exit , North to Mtn. View . 
Drive past El Camino and take the HW 237/HW101 South exit. You will then
be on HW 237 , East. 

 HW 101 - South , past Mountain View to Sunnyvale. Take the Alviso / 
Milpitas exit to HW 237 East. 

 Once on HW 237 East,  drive past Fair Oaks Ave. and take the Lawrence
Expressway/Caribbean Drive exit - choose the Caribbean Drive branch of
the exit. Stay in the right hand lane on Caribbean Drive - the park entrance 
is the first right turn as soon as you drive over HW 237.  After the toll
booth , take the right hand drive to the last picnic area , called Owl Burrow.

FROM THE EAST BAY:
>From HW 880 - Drive south on HW 880 towards San Jose and Milpitas. At
Milpitas, take the Alviso Rd./Calaveras Blvd. exit to HW 237 West . Drive
towards Mountain View and Sunnyvale . Use the Lawrence Expressway/
Caribbean Drive exit , taking the first Caribbean Drive branchoff. The
entrance to the park will be the first right turn after the on-ramp . After 
the toll booth , take the right hand drive to the last picnic area , called 
Owl Burrow.

LOCAL DIRECTIONS:
Assuming you know how to get to either Mathilda Ave. , Fair Oaks Ave. ,
Wolfe Road, or Lawrence Expressway , drive up any of them towards the 
bay.  Mathilda Ave. intersects HW 237 - take the HW 237 East exit , and
drive to the Caribbean Drive offramp. Wolf Road merges into Fair Oaks Ave ; 
take the HW 237 East exit , and use the  Caribbean Drive exit . Lawrence 
Expressway becomes Caribbean Drive at HW 237 - the entrance to the park 
will be on the right after HW 237.


Hope to see you there!
														Larry Ching/larryc@netcom.com

Weeeeeee, `didn't expect to get a free sauna thrown in with the deal, and
what a deal it was...

Sean Casey debut: Five stars; Check it out if you get a chance.
Nice well blended set. Sean has more pitty on us melting dancers than
most dj's. He would pump us up with some fast house beats for a few minutes
and then let off the steam only to hit us again once we caught our breath.
Other dj's to this of course, but Sean struck me as being especially good
at it in terms of both blending and in choosing how long to let the fast
and slow sections last. Maybe J.S.Bach was helping out.

Lee was great too (that was Lee, right?). Does anyone know what the track was 
with the very heavy drum mix where the vocal sample says 'wasted' or 'busted' 
or 'breakdown' or '?' at the end of every eight bars? That track is a drug.
Beware.

It's probably been said before, but the people at the F&F productions are
really friendly; that goes for the crowd as well as the people running the
show. Everyone on the floor knows how to get down too. I can't wait for the
next one!

-dmi




From sfraves-owner  Sun Aug 14 16:28:28 1994

	id QAA19775; Sun, 14 Aug 1994 16:23:25 -0700
Message-Id: <199408142323.QAA19775@holonet.net>
Subject: Re: Sex, drugs and democracy
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Date: Sun, 14 Aug 94 16:23:23 PDT
From: "David M. Ilstrup" <dmi@holonet.net>
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Susie says:
>last night i went to go see a movie called sex drugs and democracy....i 
>think it is a really interesting film that portrays dutch society as a 
>place where people can coexist and tolerate each other and their personal 
>choices.....from the movie promo...
>
>they even have a part of the film where they talk about raves as a safe 
>self contained place to intoxicate people....

I definitely want to see this.

Interestingly enough the house club I was at in A'dam last February is
called RoXY. Can't say what the real underground parties are like, since
neither I nor any friends that live in the Netherlands have found one yet,
but this place was really going off. The best part was actually the crowd;
lots of eye contact, smiling, wiggling, and very little inhibition.
Heel gezellig!

I don't know if they went into official policy very much in the movie, but
you should know that house parties *are* being cracked down on in Holland.
Drug use is tolerated, but it is not *accepted*, and it is not technically 
legal.

There are a lot of ambiguities in the Netherlands between the written law
and the way it is enforced, but the general pattern seems to be that if
something is discrete and happens in a well defined social setting that
does not produce 'casualties' (e.g. addicts, deaths, violence, non-functional
people) then it is tolerated.

All that aside, Holland is a great place to go out in. You can stay out until
about any hour you choose; no need to drive and if you can't get a train or
a bus to where you want to go, just hop on a bike to get where you want to
be (the county is *flat*). Many is the time we peddled the route from Leiden
to Katwijk at 3 in the morning. The people are very mellow and friendly too,
especially if you speak a little Dutch.

Zet de kleine blomtjes uit!

-dmi

	Yet another perfect event.
	I LOVE the heat. it really keeps the posers away and leaves only the
	dedicated people.

	Sean Casey rocked the house. Lee took us deeeeeeep into the LEEsound.
	Ethan danced us into oblivion. John D put a fist of beats through my
	mind. 

	Planet 6 sound had a great set- live flute!!!!
	HDW of course brought us into the jungles of his mind and then Ovid	
	stepped in and dropped some thoughts.
	
	BPM/0 really had a great sound- they used the EBOW on a GUITAR to
	give that endless sustain...

	Mousen did a three source mix and had great sound.

	It was PACKED and everyone had a blast. I really like Kommotion and
	their staff. Everyone was cool on the street in front and we weren't
	hassled even ONCE.

	Hats off to all the SFRaves crew for yet another awesome event.

	I really enjoyed the minimal setup- no huge buckets of toys and
	cables everywhere. It makes setup and takedown easy and I could
	relax knowing that people wouldn't trip over cables.

	Our Weird Blinking Lights set was completely fun- its the first time
	all three of us played an SFRaves event and it was great. I hoped 
	you enjoyed it.

Wow sfraves, we all did it AGAIN!  From careful planning and set up
to people going all out to dance and have fun, the group of us
contributed in ways huge and small to make the best party I've been
to in a while!

I only wish I had the same stamina I did two years ago when dancing
all night was not a problem.  Maybe the fact that I used to sleep till
5pm the day before a party had something to do with it? :-)

Anyway, Brian and I arrived around 11:30 to find Komotion full and
bopping in high gear.  None of this "fashionably late" stuff, the
Friends and Family know that when the music starts the party starts.
I'm sorry I missed Sean's debut, I could tell by the mood on the floor
when I got there that it must have been killer.

I tried to save myself for Ethan, but when Lee got into that sequence
of tracks that had a local maximum at "Robot Man" I was totally sucked
into the dance.  In case anyone is wondering, I am the woman who was
running around with the inflatable giraffe.  Her name is Georgina, and
she came to me at a great party I went to two years ago.  I figured
that since she hadn't been out in two years last night would be a good
time. :-)

When Ethan got going I was proud to join the legion of 
sfraverbabesinblacksportsbras . . . hey, maybe we can convince Ameba to
design something that will glow under black light?  Every time I hear
Ethan spin he plays mostly different music from the time before.  And
although I was expecting one thing but got another, I'm all the more
happier because Ethan's impeccable taste in music and supurb mixing
skills gave me ears a total treat.

The visuals in the main room were incredibly cool.  I saw animated
images based on Escher drawings, psychedelic fractals, and (my
favorite) a set of patterns that looked like Oriental rugs.

The chill hall seemed to work better this time.  I especially enjoyed
the pair consisting of an ambient DJ and a guy playing dreamy feedback
electric guitar a la Robin Guthrie.  

Gush gush gush.  It was so cool seeing so many old friends and even
cooler meeting new people.  Of all the things I've done in conjunction
with the rave scene the one thing that brings me more joy than all the
others is meeting net people and seeing them out at a great party.
Special hugs go out to Kia and Susie, since many people were confusing
the three of us with each other all night. :-)

Ok, let's keep the vibe alive -- everyone come to "Radio Radio" next
Saturday afternoon and you know we'll have a great time.  Bring your
friends and family, too!

Thanks for the great time everyone, especially the F&F production crew.

Laura

Incredible! Awsome! A Spiritual Experience!

It is difficult to put into words the feelings experienced at FFIII.  The
energy and the spirit of the crowd, the people you meet, The Family
Atmosphere is really special and unique.

I missed Sean's set but got to meet him. A very warm and friendly guy he
is.  Lee was already seriously into his set when I hit the dance floor.
Great music again.  To me nothing beats Ethan for a hard trance hypnotising
set.  He is incredibly good at taking you one step higher into never, never
land.  At one point the crowd was so driven by the music it seemed like
everyone started to clap their hands all at the same time to the beat of
the music.  The energy was just overwhelming.
Thanks to Steve for notifying me that WBL was going to perform their set in
the chill room (I never would have left the dance floor).  Yes I finally
got to hear them and what a trip it was.  An incredible journey into their
eerie ambient world.  -"Steve did I really hear some BPMs here and there
through your set?"

To me the crowd is what makes F&F so special.  Especially the warm smiles,
the truly  piercing eye contacts, the feeling that everyone is experiencing
a magical journey.  Someone (I did not ask his name) got this great body
paint job.  He looked wild!  What did you think of Laura's pet
Giraff...soooo cute.

Again a party like this would not be so perfectly put together without the
people behind it. Thanks to Ethan, Bryce (sorry I missed your ambient set)
and everyone else involved.  The visuals were just awsome, much better than
I've seen in many expensive Clubs.

I could go on, and on, and on........

I can't wait for the next one.

Denis, ravnbird@crl.com

Denis,  ravnbird@crl.com

From: deaks@netcom.com (Ernie Deakyne)
Message-Id: <199408150334.UAA02983@netcom11.netcom.com>
Subject: PHAT as PH**K Weekend report! :>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Date: Sun, 14 Aug 1994 20:34:27 -0700 (PDT)
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL23]
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

Precedence: bulk

   This was offically my last weekend of summer.  I'm moving up to USF in 
a week, so you'll soon  be seeing a lot more of me :)  anyways...

   The partying started off Friday night down here in Monterey.  After 
the success of the last Cloud Factory party, and not having talked to 
Scott or anyone for two weeks, I wasn't sure how well this one was going 
to go off.  My fears were soon calmed after I found out we had an amazing 
site in a canyon, and the weather was absoloutly perfect.  We had our 
black lights, but the shooting stars provided a once in a lifetime light 
show.

   We had to break a few locks to get on to the property and even with 
nearly 50 or more cars pouring down this deserted road, we never once had 
problems with the authorities :)

   A large crowd from Monterey showed up and many thanks to those who 
came down from Santa Cruz at 4 am.  The party peaked with about 150 
people and I would say 200+ came throughout the night.  The musical 
selection encompassed the entire spectrum from house to trance to 
breakbeat, unfortunatley, we didn't get it on DAT this time.. Oh well :)

   Kudos to Bryce for deciding at the last minute to make the long drive 
down here and join us!  We had a nice breakfast in Salinas after we 
packed everything up around 7:30am and then we all (almost all :) slept 
to 5pm...

   At which point it was time to head of up to F&F !!!  Almost the entire 
Cloud Factory posse made the trip up and we had an incredible time 
sharing and providing energy.  I was very impressed with Sean C's set, he 
played some fierce tribal/trance/progressive stuff which made me dance my 
ass off.  

   Lee started out a bit slower and gave people a chance to recover from 
Sean's fast set but after about 20 minutes he had the crowd dancing like 
mad to his classic acid trax :) .. I loved dancing above the crowd in the 
corner, you can see all the bodies moving to the rhythm and absorb all 
that energy and then send it back out to them!

   Ethan tweaked my head HARD!  I haven't danced that hard in a while.  
Amazing stuff.

   I lost track of the DJ's after that and spent a lot of time talking 
with my friends and hanging out in the chill room.  My only disapointment 
was that I didn't spend much time meeting new people, but rather I hung 
out with friends I won't be seeing for a long time... But that's OK since 
I'll be living with y'all real soon :>

   Huge Hugs to Bryce and Ethan and everyone else involved!

Peace, rave and happiness! 

 -Ernie

Hi All-

I wish I could have been with you all at FF3 but work & circumstance have 
me in L.A.

Not to fear. I still got a dose of some serious music. While you all were 
sweatin away at Kommotion I was waiting to get in to the Shark Club in 
downtown to L.A. to hear Frankie Bones (NY), Skylab 2000, Thee-O & Eli Star.
I had to wait to 3am which was kind of difficult but it ended up being 
worth it.

Frankie Bones was quite good (though a bit too much ego) but Thee-O and 
Eli Star (both L.A. dj's) were fucking AMAZINg. 

The music was from another planet. Eli Star worked the floor with serious 
psychedelic ambient trance acid house until 10AM. 

The best religious experience I've had in a long time.

Though L.A. is pretty fucked up  (like everywhere else) it has got some 
serious energy and mind blowing music.

C-YA soon in SF

peace------------------------------OUT------------------------->>>>>>>>>>>>>!!
Ronan

On Sat, 13 Aug 1994, David Alves wrote:

> Virtual communities are not like real life communities.
> There are more fantasies and projections.

> [...various basically true statements deleted...]

> I am not going to pick up your mail or feed your dog
> I don't have jumper cables
> 
> I do not really care about you
-------------
yeah, but shee-it, have heart, and check this out:

1.  my buddy Tonette's little girls were flower girls
    in my and Leslie's wedding; I met Tonette on funky-music,
    an email list just like this

2.  spent last tues night in LA with my pal AdW, backstage
    watching Public Enemy do a non-public show; I met AdW
    on funky-music and he is now a part of the musical projects
    I do an a very close friend.

3.  I work w/ a friend, one Niels, er, uh, hmmm... can't remember
    his last name...maybe some of you know him?!?!?!  he's another
    good friend...guess where i met him?  ding-ding-ding-ding!!!!
    YES!, that's right, another cyberpal  (sorry, cn't rezist..;-)

nutcases are even safer and more entertaining, just don't give them
your address!  really tho, if you think about it, were really dealing
w/ each others minds which has a nice kinda egalitarianism to it, you
don't base things on anything other than what someone "says", using
*this* medium.  when you get to know someone over the net their personality
tends to leak through the things they say.  sure some nut could invent
a persona to do evil shit and use the net to hide who they really were,
but the chances that something they did would appear inauthentic are
quite large, IMHO, i've seen people try to front on the net and it's
usually pretty obvious.

so i don't mean to detract, you *should* be careful, but i want to
counter the warning with optimism, i've got a slew of wonderful
friends i met on the net and wouldn't want anyone to think it has
to remain superficial...although, a deeper level of bonding occurred
w/ most of my net friends when we met in *real  life*, it now occurs
to me...

lat,

*

I couldn't wait for saterday, so me + friends checked out
Mother Earth Sound System's party in the East Bay.  This was really
a great, great party.  The sound system was very nice.  The location
was a wonderful, isolated park that was on the shore of an east
bay inlet, and had a wonderful view of thousands of Oakland's 
brightest sodium-vapor lights.  All this party could have used
was a few more people.  The MESS folks are a very cool family
who are extremely friendly to new comers.  Support 'em!  

	FFIII:  One word: WOW!  Ovid:  You are probably one of the
few people who understands physics enough to truly relate
science to spirituality.  Don't miss the opportunity to talk with
this guy.  Resonate:  Where can I get myself a Realistic synthesizer?
	Regarding Laura's comments on sfraverbabes:  (Allow my
primal male instinct to invade a bit)  with or without shirts, you're
all HOT! and I love you ALL!  You're blasting the mainstream impression that
internet users are white, nerdy males.  You're the
coolest girls around (and ya'll can dance!)
	
	Anyone have any insider info on Futur?  Will this be hip or hype?

-troy

 On this weekend of the comercialized Woodstock anniversary - I want to
 mention that F&FIII had all the vibes and most of the activities of the
 original...

 There were great tunes spinning all night - with the introduction of new
 talent - great job Sean !
 There were black lights, strobes, lasers, video visions everywhere - with
 many people sporting trippy black light artwork.
 There was a "camping area" on the main stage.
 There was shared food and plenty of free water. 
 There were periodic rain showers in the form of someone spraying the crowd
 with water.
 There was ambience abounding in an ambient room that worked better this
 time.
 
 OK so there wasn't any nude bathing and the press hype was noteably 
 missing and it did pass by a bit faster than an entire weekend but I
 can guarentee that F&F III had all the best vibes of any! "magical,
 mystical" rockout ever produced !  

 If you missed Woodstock maybe you were young or not even here yet :-)
 If you missed F&F I & II we were warming up...
 If you missed last night you missed THE WOODSTOCK 94 of SF !!!
 ( Where were you Crunch ? )


 And it all came off because of many, many people's pitching in a lot or
 a little and of course, because everyone showed up "in the flesh"...

 Which takes me to my next post...

 Mike (WOW am I impressed what happened) Clay

Subject: Virtual Community NOT!!!!
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Date: Sun, 14 Aug 1994 23:18:28 -0700 (PDT)
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL23]
MIME-Version: 1.0

Precedence: bulk


 I've noticed a few posting of late about the "virtual community" and how
 we don't have to help each other. We are just here for entertainment and
 if we left it would be like an interruption in a TV show. ( Boy IMHO is that
 person lost - or perhaps I read wrong and it's a joke. )

 WE ARE NOT A VIRTUAL COMMUNITY. Read that twice. 
 We are a REAL community LINKED by virtual means. Thus, if I want to talk
 with one of you - I can do so day or night at my leasure. I don't have to
 drive from my San Mateo home to the city to be in touch but I am in touch
 with real people ( not some entertaining TV shows! ). F&F III PROVED that 
 and it was BETTER - FAR BETTER - than the recent Come Unity or Wicked -
 IMHO (and yes I was at both!). 

 I do notice that some people do treat people they meet on-line like 
 entertainment. They flame, they insult, they don't ask questions first
 and so on - these are virtual people to them. If that's the way you want
 your world so be it.  But consider well....

 1) politicians treat people like "virtual vote machines". They respond
    when they must as far as they must but people they make laws for (OR
    AGAINST) are often NOT REAL to them. (Think about many drug laws are
    they sensitive to real people?) 

 2) IRS treats people like "virtual money machines". They respond as long
    as it's in their favor to do so.

 3) Businesses often treat people like "virtual consumers". We don't have
    to sell you stuff AND give you support AND service do we ? 

  I could go on - but you get the point. If you like the way situations
 like 1 -3 play out, then go ahead and join them as:

 4) People who treat on-line people as "virtual people". I don't have to
    be concerned about your feelings or help you since you are not part
    of MY REAL COMMUNITY. IMO if you do that, you just became one of the
    situations above and I don't want to hear you bitching about how 
    everyone around you doesn't care Etc.

 In the meantime if you do need your tire changed, or a ride Etc. I'll
 be more than willing to do what I can for the REAL community I read
 but who I talk with virtually.


 PS If you want to know what a virtual community is get SIM CITY or better
    yet Little Computer People. Those are truly virtual. The rest of us are
    REAL - even if we speak virtually......


  My more than $.02

 MIKE (YES I'M REALLY HERE*) CLAY


* And from what I experienced last night so are a LOT of other people!!!!

From: anthrax@uclink.berkeley.edu (Ann Elizabeth Loraine)

ooooo...this is such an interesting thread....

yo, Will..you say that the language we use must necessarily reflect the
cateogries to which we belong in the "real" world.  that our choices for
punctuation, the typos we leave behind, our grammar, emerge out of our
"real" personalities.  

by the same token, couldn't those of us who are particularly skillful with
language, those of us who understand its slipperynesses, synthesize whatever
virtual persona we want?  (i ain't no such wizard, by the way!) what i mean
is, language doesn't necessarily have to have any logical, self-evident
thing about it that marks it as coming from one person and not another.  
hence your suspicions concerning Ken's having been to a rave.

It is tempting to take your teasing (?) as  cold text without feeling
behind it.  don't you think it's part of the fun of the virtual universe
to allow such abstract concepts as "Ken" to exist, to play, to cause 
trouble, to grow, to observe & enjoy?  yet if you hadn't had this debate,
i would have never thought about the fact that i know lots of the "posters"
just through what they say here & not from parties.

you are all spirits who speak through my little Mac Plus!  now go shake
your booties, all of you!  

-anthrax


PS  Oh my god, the sunset party was FABULOUS.  Friends n' Family was so
incredibly filled up with the neatest people!  Who named this one?  You
are a genius.  'cause that's exactly what it was!  yay yay ya! thankyou
for such a great party!

From: Fred Heutte <phred@well.sf.ca.us>
Message-Id: <199408150841.BAA29901@well.sf.ca.us>

Subject: F&F&F

Friends & Family & FUN!

Komotion is such a great space, it's not perfect and doesn't have to be
. . . . it was hot in the big room but not completely unbearable
(I never sweated like I did at Heaven in Detroit when Cajmere and Dajae
performed) . . . . I thought *all* the DJs and performers were top 
notch, if anything the hallway crew was even more impressive, in part
because most ambient/chill spaces are so damn unclear on the concept
(e.g., the event in portland last weekend where the "ambient" was
so loud you didn't even want to be in the same room) . . . . the
dayglo paints and other fun stuff really made the space come alive . . . .
I concurred with Bryce that it was great to see some kids early on,
they looked like they were having fun with face painting and Gak . . . 
I'm really sorry I didn't stay until the end, both 'cause I missed
Giamma's set and helping on cleanup, but I was pure exhausted after
zooming down from Portland on 4 hours of sleep, a nice visit to
Gaia Mantra, two hours spinning at Ameba and another (unofficial)
hour to warm up before Sean came on, which was great because I finally
got to hear how it sounds with a decently loud system from behind
the wheelz of steel; I didn't really have a set selected so I just
tossed in the deep house I had in the record bag (knowing full well
the wondrous onslaught of trance about to unfold :) . . . . it was
a real hoot to give the folks at the bar my copy of Monk with the
really weird story about another event that supposedly occurred at
Komotion a while back . . . . i really liked turning loose to the
cavalcade of 303ish stuff all night . . . i was going to go to
Sunset this evening but got involved in really long listening 
session at Tweekin' and ended up NOT going to the Jerry Garcia
show at the Warfield (many miracle seekers out on Market), and
totally unexpectedly ended up at Bimbo's on Columbus watching
Gato Barbieri tonight (the first time I saw him was in 1978!),
then had a GREAT cannoli at one of the cafes so this weekend
definitely turned out ALL ACES and thanks to you all sfraves,
yer the greatest!

From: csc@pilot.njin.net (Sean Casey)

Subject: F&FIII - Wow!

Wow! What a party!

Once again everyone came and donated their sweat and ability and made
a wonderful party happen. A ton of thanks and love to everyone that
helped and to those that brought their smiles and good vibes.

The visuals were just excellent. I really liked the trippy Friends and
Family rainbow color-cycled stuff. Cool :). This time I tried varying
the lighting at times through the night, and it seemed to charge the
crowd. Once again, cool :).

The ambient room music was wonderful, and I'm often iffy about ambient
room music. Every time I walked through it was something new and
interesting. Often I'd hear this really neat stuff, and realize "oh
wow, this is live" :). It sounded that good.  I heard a lot of really
beautiful ethereal pieces that snagged me and I'd have to stay a
while.

The dance music was fucking _killer_. I thought Lee and Ethan played
some of the best sets I've ever heard.  They were just dead on in the
groove, and the progression was wonderful. The crowd was thrashed. I
don't know how many people I talked to who begged for mercy. And I've
never heard so much hootin and hollerin at one of our parties :). 

I had SO much fun spinning for you!!! You all were so nice and so
supportive that any nervousness I had went away in no time and all
there was left was the will to thrash :). And I made lots of goofs
(and learned lots of lessons ;)), but looking out there and seeing all
those smiles I just laughed it off and jammed on.  You made it
wonderful for me :).

Thanks to everyone who put their effort into making this party happen,
and thanks to YOU for bringing your good attitude and shakin booty to
this party. Your smiles and good vibe took this party into the
stratosphere. Wow.

Next time :)

Sean

PS - Once again, $3 bought you: killer ambient & dance, live
performances, free water, free fruit, visuals, lasers, ins & outs,
hassle free promoters & door people with _good_attitudes_, 2
bathrooms, body paints, a great sound system at a perfect volume
level, and about 8000 smiles :). Shop and compare.

PPS - How hot did it get? At center of the dance floor during peak, 91
degrees, 94% humidity. Whew! We told you :). But people were chugging
the free water like crazy, and as far as I know there were no
problems.

>[...]  and he REFUSES TO APPEAR IN THE FLESH?!?!?  Ba-by,
> you gots to wonder about that!!!  someone who refuses to "be real",
> why?  are you a narc or a nerd, ken?  we'll likely figure it out by and

I wanted to stay out of this, but I'm finding myself getting annoyed
at some of the antagonism here.  That someone behaves a little differently 
than us and doesn't seem to be conforming to some unwritten law
concerning SFRaver social intercourse is no reason to spew suspicion
and derision in hir direction.  Ken has never really "refused" to do 
anything.  He just doesn't come much, that's all.  Before I started 
raving, I was not much of a socialite either, shying away from most social 
situations, especially ones that had an air of cliquishness and 
advertised rejection towards nonconformists.

I agree that because understanding raving is primarily experiential, his
perspective comes across as rather uninformed at times.  But I don't see 
how *challenging* him to participate and putting him on the defensive is
constructive for anyone.  

Anyway: kudos to Ethan & co. for another successful Ph&Ph!  Sunset was
Great too.  Coming next: FMR, Future, Boogie Buffet... Things seem to be 
*really* picking up around here. d:-)

Subject: Woodstock & MTV
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com (sfraves@hyperreal.com)
