X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.3 PL11]

in the delerium of the heat, i watched the MTV coverage of
woodstock yesterday, mostly hoping to see some coverage of ravestock

as my boss just put it:
"People keep saying that this cant possibly be the first one,
this is all about money and commercialism, but so was the first one.
The bands played expecting to get paid, and the promoter was planning
on making a lot of money, and everyone went there to listen
to some music while getting high and getting laid.  I really 
dont see that much of a difference, except that the first time,
they werent able to keep people out."

Really, i have to agree.. Quite frankly, woodstock looked like fun.
Running around in the mud for three days with seemingly friendly
people and little violence, being able to check out some cool
but probably far from top of the line VR stuff, listening to
a lot of cool music, sounds like fun. Forget the relationship
to the first one, hell forget the first one altogether,
its mostly a myth anyway.  After that, its just a big party,
like any european festival, just that theirs tend to be a bit cheaper
and probably dont have a day long wait to get out.

Funny things about woodstock '94 as seen through MTV:

People saying "There is such diverse group of people here:
old hippies, young hippies, ravers, etc etc."
and they were showing pictures of such people as the person was listing them:
Old White Hippie, Young White Hippie, White Raver, White etc etc.

Green Day being interviewed, TWICE. Okay it was one interview in two parts,
but they totally blew of Chris COnnely in the first part,
so i dont know why they did teh second part cuz it only got worse.
They basicaly sat there making wierd faces at teh camera every once in awhile
or just sitting there looking at the ground, whil saying 
that the wanted to be the next sha na na and saying 
"Actually i think we will just get up and tell everyone *bleep*" to which 
Chris responded "Well Country Joe already led the Fish cheer"

Green Day also looked like they were having the most fun..
while Trent Reznor got much muddier, green day was actually playing
their instruments and it looked like they (NiN) were all too
wasted to know what was going on

there was some other wierd stuff.. but ObKennedy.

Kennedy was a DJ in LA called the Virgin Kennedy, so it
might have been a reference to that.  Yes from what i hear/read
she is really conservative, but really.. who cares.

The rave coverage was totally lame, but if MTV wanted something
better they would have gotten it. For the most part, i thought
it was kinda funny, but it had nothing to do with ravestock.

Kennedy is actually the only thing that made it worthwhile.
It was kinda wierd how they stuck the two really stupid VJ's together
out in the mess, and had connely and tabitha sorenberger together
as the slightly intellectual banter VJS, 
and rakkman and kennedy and allison as teh disenfrachised type VJ's
who rag on MTV and all teh other VJ's and woodstock altogether.
Listening to Kennedy and Allisons side comments made it somewhat bearable.
Especially after that one idiot said "Man.. theres even deerS at woodstock"
and then it switched over to them and they said "DeerS??" and laughed
(he's not an idiot cuz he doesnt know the plural of deer,
but little intelligence was displayed throughout his ramblings)

 ,
dana

"I used to eat leaves and rocks and stuff cause the cat ate wierd things"

To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Reply-To: asah@cs.Berkeley.EDU
Subject: Woodchlock'94 part Duh.  awesome weekend- snapshot.
Date: Mon, 15 Aug 94 12:20:00 -0700
X-Mts: smtp
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

One for the I-told-you-so dept.  Check out the full page inside spread in
   today's NY Times... the photographer who took the headline shot is a
   genius: although the caption describes the scene as the remains of the
   concert and the bodies standing, huddled stragglers amidst the pouring
   rain, mud and hell -- what it really looks like is a scene straight out
   of a {Rwanda, Ehtiopia, ...} encampment.  The accompanying articles
   compare the concert to Spring Break, compelte with topless,
   baseball-capped guys, "Co-Ed Naked Rugby" tshirts, etc.  Two women who
   went painted themselves after going topless, stood for photo-ops and it
   was estimated that 5,000 gawkers took them up on the offer.

I feel bad for the folks who feel as we do, but don't have access to
   something like F+F3 (whose awesomeness has been amply captured in the
   continuous stream of posts - DJs: you are god(dess)like.  May your
   happiness repay you for your deeds)  Imagine these less-fortunate, who
   wish to trance, feel vibe, experience... - and whose only chance to get
   away from the folks for a weekend, camp out and community - is to drop
   $135 at some sleezy promoter, stand in mile-long lines to go to the
   bathroom, and otherwise lose horribly.  I feel worse for the people who
   didn't know better and walked away thinking they had been part of
   something big (as opposed to just being part of something large).

I hope I'm not bitching/preaching to the choir here, but please understand:
   as a relatively recent arrival to the bay area, I can safely safe that
   the vast majority of our beloved country is not like this.  And, now
   knowing the difference, it pains me to think of friends and family who
   don't.  And we should care: mandatory sentencing, possession seizure,
   random testing, etc. are voted on the national level, which makes the
   bay area count as a handful of votes.  A largely irresponsuble group of
   people such as what descended on Saugerities is not only silly and
   stupid, but also ammunition for the conservative set who see the entire
   lot of us as irresponsible "kids" (ie. under 30) who need to be
   protected from ourselves, who need to be stopped from influencing their
   children, who need to grow up, etc.  Trust me: most of the country
   wouldn't believe you if you said that you've met lots of people who've
   repeated done {x,l,...} and hold day jobs other than pumping gas.

But I don't want to end of a sorrowful note: this was a very awesome
   weekend, punctuates beautifully by fnf3, by the people, the music, and
   the feelings.

later,
adam

The little bit of Woodstock coverage I saw on MTV was about par for
the course.  MTV has never ever risen above the on the air content-
to-volume quotient of its earliest jocks (remember Martha Quinn and
J.J. Jackson, anyone?).  Kennedy is a particular horror; she's a
Lake Oswego, Oregon (we call it Lake El Swanko here) Young Republican
type, totally self-absorbed.  Borrowing the old Dorothy Parker jibe,
she has Personality, but it runs all the way from A to B.  I heard
about one on air bit she did waking people up in their tents. 
Probably thought she was Making Their Day.  I would have rubbed her
self-reverential face in some mud.  

>From M's report on the Well, it looks like The Orb stole the show,
they played nearly three hours on saturday morning and did You Know
What that anyone who as experienced the sunrise PLUR vibe knows about :)

We had a great time at F&F and I didn't miss Woodschlock one little bit.

phred

Well, I may be crotchety
or lost or just a big meanie
but I didn't intend to get in over my head
on this virtualness idea

There is a difference between just knowing 
someone virtually and knowing them in person.

I like this list which is nothing but the people on it.
I don't think it is so Exotic.  It is the lost art of
letter writing but sped up a little bit and with the twist
of jumping right in with hundreds of mostly anonymous pals.
I guess I relate pure virtualness to a degree of anonymity.
Having only your words to move past this.

TV is too passive and didn't work so well.
My call to be entertained stands.

******* 

I went to Sunset yesterday.  I'd guess at least a 100+ people.
I thought I would just drop by for a little bit but stayed until
9 or 10.  The music was good - somehow accessable, not so hard -
perfect for a balmy afternoon.  That hill is amazing.  It was very
cool to look up at everyone dancing and enjoying the view.

Someone needs to bring a big flag and a horse 
and just Conquer that baby ...
for the Nation, man

Dave

hi y'all,
just saw 's,d &D' and really liked it! there are several comments i want to
make: i thought the movie eschewed the political and focused too much
on the personal. it is hard to see from the movie that one reason for
teh kulture which developed in hollnad is the result of HUNDREDS of years
of democracy - yes, holland's democracy is older the the us! i think it is
from something like 1580's; dutch folx, help me out on this! so it is not
something built overnight.
the other question i had, as applied to us, is whether the dutch experiment
would also work on a larger scale. holland has 50 mil. people, us 250.
also, the size of holland - tiny- compared to that of us, might mitigate
against the development of such a culture, a participatory culture, with
tons of interactions between people. what do other people think ?
take care/shalom
ovid

	I would like to report some quick status on MESS.  Myself and my friend
	Rob arrived shortly after midnight.  They were still setting up and
there
	was about 20 people there.  At around 12:45 the music was going.
	The site was enclosed by trees on one side and water on the other.  The
	dance area was on grass which was both a blessing and a disaster.  The
	grass absorbed the energy while dancing which made it easy on the
	knees but hard to keep going for long periods of time.

	The good features of this event were the positive attitude, smiles and
	etcetera.  The sound system was perfectly balanced between highs and
lows
	and very clear.  Mother nature had a show of her own for us, residual
	meteors showered over us while we danced.  I brought a blanket
	and layed on the ground and watched.  At one point I found myself
	on a dock in the water and there were three women on the dock next
	to the one I was on.  One of the women saw a shooting star, having made
	all the wished she could think of then offered to make one for me.  I
	made my wish and threw it over to her.  People had brought a very
	fun dog and everyone was playing and running with the dog.  In all
	I met about a dozen new folks and hope to run into them at future
	events.

	In all a very touching evening and some really great music.

	Ron.

We started 1 1/2 hours early! Starting setup 4-5 hours early is a
*great* way to reduce stress if you're throwing an event.  Not only
that, but the DJs get to spin longer :) and people who show up early
get music from minute one.

In my last post I forgot to mention the Komotion people, who are a
dream to work with. What a great collective!

I'll have to join the chorus and say that F&F3 was AWESOME!!  The music was
great (especially Sean and Lee and Ethan - you guys were INTENSE!) and I've
never danced so hard or sweated so much in my life.. :)  The vibe was
incredible, lots of smiles and laughs everywhere, and hugs from people I
don't even know.. :)

The chill room was great, even if it was sort of narrow and lots of people
were (ick) smoking in there.. But the live ambient stuff going on made it
totally worth it!  The blacklight art project went pretty well, too.. Thanks
to Bryce for providing the paints and the tarp!  

I saw lots of happy faces (lots of them new) and people who might be signing
up to this list because of the party, too..  Phred and I were working the 
door for a little bit so the Komotion guys could get out and dance and we
were getting compliments left and right, as well as questions and lots of
interest!

I had a wonderful time, and I'm definitely proud of being an
sfraverbabeinablacksportsbra after this event!  Every time I go to an
sfraves party, I'm always looking forward to the next one.. They just keep
getting better!

Hugs to everyone..

k

P.S. If you didn't know, I was the one who looks like susie from behind and
was dressed kinda like Laura..  Pretty soon I think nobody's going to be
able to tell us sfravergurls apart!  :)

Hi Folx--

EVERYTHING has already been said (now that Sean's
added bit about the Komotion folx came through) about
the perfection called F & F III (and--echoing Mike Clay--
where *were* you, Crunchie?! Hope all is well!  You 
*weren't* at Woodschlock, were yuh?  Guys in our gen
know better than *that,* don't we?).

Thanks to all the folx who put in sooooo much love,
devotion and just plain hard work into F&FIII--it proved
once again that whatever goes around comes around...and
in this post-Celestine Prophecy world it's happening 
increasingly simultaneously!

Thanks to all the folx who either put up with or did not
put up with my gestalt with Ken. By pushing our buttons
as far as they will go we find out a lot about ourselves.
Mike Clay (again) is right when he says that we are *not*
a virtual community but the virtual extension of a real
(actual) community.  Through threads like Ken and I and       
others have had we have an opportunity to learn a great
deal. I won't tell you what I learned because that's not
the same as what you learned--and in this case may not even
be relevant to what you learned.  The gestalt is over.

ciao fer niao,
Willi

        julie@wizards.austin.ibm.com, goldman@linc.cis.upenn.edu,
        mariposa@nobozo.cs.berkeley.edu, quip@crl.com,
        muir@remarque.berkeley.edu, golding@hpl.hp.com, sbarr@cs.sunysb.edu
Reply-To: asah@cs.Berkeley.EDU
Subject: consulting?
Date: Mon, 15 Aug 94 16:41:50 -0700
X-Mts: smtp
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

q: A friend of mine and i were debating the merits of apple's high
   consultant/employee ratio (>30%).  I expessed the viewpoint I've been
   taught, that the high consultant rates make it a financial lose in the
   steady state (ie. one year of paying a consultant is more expensive than
   one year of paying an employee).  He instead suggested that this isn't
   the case, which is not unreasonable given the math of my own
   experiences.  When asking the obvious question about why everyone
   doesn't use lots of consultants, he suggested lower morale and team
   building issues as being important.

   Simultaneously, we were talking about the smallness of the bay area
   computing world.  This then prompted me to ask: Wouldn't the
   company-of-consultants model work well if consultants were expected to
   interact with full timers and each other, and to treat their employment
   as a short duration full-time employment.  Consider:

1. "Permanent" employees average two years at a company in computers.  Even
   in other fields, people typically don't get (real) raises- they find a
   new employer and renegotiate.  Successful promotions tend to be closer to
   re-hirings rather than pay-for-experience.  The exception is the
   extortion-based raise tied to indispensibility.

2. My own experiences are that, in this industry and in 1994, full timers
   don't really form deep relationships with a company, permanent or
   temporary.  At the last company I worked for, I was definitely a
   consultant, but I formed much closer relationships with the company and
   with my coworkers than many of the lifers.  I still keep in close
   contact, and it's understood that there's a small (but real) chance that
   I'll someday work for them or otherwise do business with them again.

3. As a matter of job security, I think people are starting to realize that
   there really isn't any de facto security: you're paid for your skills
   set and it's your job to continuously upgrade them and to stay marketable.
   And I also think that people are learning to relax about this and not
   lose sleep that they'll lose their job (permanently) tomorrow.  It takes
   years for a skill to be unmarketable.  It takes far less time to acquire
   new skills.

4. Team building is not as long term or important as it's given credit for.
   While I know of folks who stick around for the atmosphere, the fact is
   that 20K pay raises lure away amazing numbers of talented people
   (especially within a geographic area).  This is quite apart from the
   greater mobility that greater connectivity has brought us.  It's been my
   own experience that teams that last five years are rare, and like war,
   they lose steam after 5-7 at the most... This easily fits into the
   model, since 5 years is basically a small number of contract renewals,
   and it makes it much easier for everyone when the team does break up:
   you see it coming months before the first key person drops.

   Anyway, you can see the direction I'm heading: wouldn't it be an overall
   win for many (most?) people to be consultants.  As I understand it, more
   than 30% of Apple are consultants.  While astronomical by today's
   standards, this seems like a reasonable figure in the proposed model.
   Here are some of the ramifications I've thought of.  Please add:

 - the smallish community would get even more tightly knit, since you'd
   have worked with many more people during your lifetime.  Again, from
   experience, it's kind of neat to shuffle around a bit and get
   opportunities to work with extraordinary and talented people, and not
   stay holed up with one set of senior folks too long.  Senior folks seem
   to like to see periodic shuffling in the ranks as well, with junior
   members sticking around for a few years before taking more senior
   positions elsewhere.  In time, six degrees of separation would become
   two.  The last few times I've met new people in the cs community out
   here, I've had no trouble tracking down a reference with one or two
   phone calls and/or email.

 - the health insurance issues change somewhat, since people would pick
   his/her own, and it wouldn't be tied to your employer- since if people
   shuffle companies every 6mon-2yrs, it doesn't make sense to tie the
   group plan to the company.

   It also means that the HMOs etc. are under the gun of real competition
   from the customers directly, instead of from management...

 - None of this excludes the possibility of signing five- and ten- year
   contracts for senior folks who've really settled down.  In this way,
   it's like those neomarriage things where people marry for ten years at a
   time, sometimes going off with other partners for a while and coming
   back later.  Key idea: one (set of) relationship(s) is rarely forever,
   and it often makes sense to circulate a little, for variety, to learn...

 - Companies themselves would (I think) do better by having more outside
   experience circulating through.  It's not bad now, but the entire
   concept of rigid corporate culture (eg. HP's hardware centric stance)
   cannot be good for competitiveness.  Obviously, companies would be more
   nimble during recessions and company-specific downturns.  In reality, I
   think it's clear that if a company can't afford the employees, layoffs
   happen anyway, so the morale argument here is a bit flimsy, no?

 - Clearly, this would work better for some jobs than others.  Senior
   researchers often work on projects lasting a decade or more, with few
   noteworthy intermediate results.  Some even include physical constraints
   (ie. archeology), so clearly corporate or government sponsorship is
   necessary: in the extreme case, spies aren't going to start working for
   other governments every six months, and astronauts aren't going to work
   for fly for the "other" NASA :-)

 - I would think this interacts nicely with the emerging telecommuting and
   "virtual office" culture, since remote consulting would boil down to
   whose internal email and news you receive, and which videoconferences
   you attend.  Working for a new company would amount to negotiating a
   contract, getting on their net, and reading a company FAQ-like
   background sheet on the permanent and current set of employees, and
   reading a month's worth of back email (to get up on the current topics
   of conversation).

Questions:
 - what are the real numbers here?  What are the financial implications of
   converting a salaried position into a contracted position?  what other
   morale-related issues have I missed?
 - what other implications can you think of?

Your thoughts appreciated.  Please respond to the entire cc: and To: list
   if you do.

Thanks again,
adam

ps. This started because the person with whom I had the original
    conversation was buying a pair of concert tickets from me... and he
    turned out to have previously worked two cubicles away from a friend of
    mine.  I'd say "how unusual", but it really happens all the time now.


From sfraves-owner  Mon Aug 15 18:20:30 1994

From: brycer@ultima.org (Bryce Ryan)

Date: Mon, 15 Aug 1994 16:33:52 -0700 (PDT)

Precedence: bulk

Greetings!  I had a GREAT time at Friends and Family.  My good time is
directly attributable to all of you on the list who shared in the creation
of this marvellous rave, and all our new friends and family who visited
with us once again.

at best, i can only recall a montage of a very few high points for me during
this one, because there were so many.  the graffiti walls in the hall and
loo lounge, especially the phrase "eat more pork rinds".  i also remember 
the psychedelic sun on the plastic. i remember the diffraction pattern
of the laser shifting on the zodiac poster as it wafted in the breeze,
a red dot shifting over the face of the moon.  i remember several children
running from one end of the space to the other, laughing, asking questions,
being body painted.  i remember hearing and dancing to many of my favorite
tunes.  i remember ethan's day-glo boxers with smiley faces :)  i remember
it being so hot and humid that i /had/ to take off my shirt (a first to
me--i guess i can call myself a "shirtless male hunter-gatherer" now :) ).
i remember people yelling on the DJs as they made mix after mix after
incredible mix.  i remember a woman who gave out beautifully gift wrapped
sacks of candy.  i remember awesome live music in the multimedia lounge.
i remember loaning my car to one of the folks from komotion so they could
get more things to drinks, and thinking how great that we were so many so
early in the evening.  i remember being so excited when it seemed so early,
and there were folks lined up waiting to get in, and seeing them come in,
and not having met many of them before.  i remember talking with friends
(so many smiling people!) on the sidewalk.

i had a wonderful time, and i'm so glad to hear from many of you that you
enjoyed yourselves, too!
--

your day to day when you get the chance, cuz it definitely feels
good!  meanwhile, i'll try to keep unwarranted smart remarks to

From: lxfogel@srv.PacBell.COM (Lee Fogel)
Message-Id: <9408152315.AA04019@pbssi.srv.PacBell.COM>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Re: Woodstock & MTV
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

I didn't go, but I watched some of the MTV coverage, chatted on the
woodstock IRC channel, perused the Well's woodstock WWW page, listened
to some bits on scrambled payperview.  I even watched some chunks of the 
original on PBS, for perspective.  Why?  Well how often does a *party* get
so much attention?  It sure beat coverage of OJ saga.  The event was 
important simply because there was so much attention focused on it.

First of all, it was clear that this was a completely mainstream america
event.  There were families there, yuppies & their kids, teenages from
suburbia; ie. everyone's next door neighbor & coworker, along with a 
handful of contrived weirdos from last years halloween parade. 

Drugs: There were two big issues here.  The first one was the outright
banning of alchohol.  Plenty got in, but alchohol seemed to be more
feared by the promoters than *anything* despite it's legal and 
socially-sanctioned status.  The second issue was that, of course, lot's 
of people were doing lot's of drugs.  It was reported in a rather ho hum 
manner - this was "woodstock" afterall - but there was a refreshing
lack of hysteria about it.  And with nearly zero security and a third
of a million people crowded together in near anarchy, nothing too terrible 
resulted.  Amazing.

There was a rave.  Didn't get much coverage, but it happened, and 
amazingly enough, everyone survived that too.  Maybe the next time an 
ambitious promoter tries to get a site together for a Megarave somewhere, 
local officials might be just a little less frightened of the concept.

Tamara whines:
>I found that to be so evil, all of these people continually saying, "it's
>all about coming together, no matter who you are, in the spirit of unity."
>No. It was all about having enough money to be there and be cool.

Yeah, people went there to be cool, but they *did* come together.  And
from what I could see, most seemed to be having fun and there seemed to be
a positive vibe.  Considering 100,000 people got in for free, anyone who 
wanted to haul there asses up there could of gotten in.  All you needed
was some awareness, a friend with a car, the willingess to endure... kinda 
like getting to an FMR.

The promoters never pretended that this was not a commercial event.  The
amount of cynicism surrounding it was enormous, but the party went off 
anyway.  When a successful party happens in relative harmony with the
surroundings community, it helps the cause of parties everywhere.  
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
Lee Fogel/\/\/\/\/\eVerything/\Is/\possiBlE/\/\/\/\/\lxfogel@srv.pacbell.com
____________________________________________________________________________

 
 





A few points that might be relevant to us, as ravers:

First of all, it was clear that this was a ma

Many, many heartfelt thanks to everyone that helped make this party go as
totally off as it did; it was so fucking great to be at a *rave* again! One
of the better nights of my entire life. Thank you!

Everyone was fantastic, but highlights of the night, for me, were: 

Sean Casey's amazing set; forget debut, this was one of the best sets I've
ever heard -- period. 

Giamma *mixing in* from CD to Jon D's last record. Blew a fair number of
minds I'd say. Hot shit Giamma; not to mention the rest of his set --
totally amazing. 

Visuals. I just *cannot* say enough about what Michael Clay and his friend
Jim did. Best viusals I've ever seen. There was an amazing sequence (all
night really :) of 3-4 image composites featuring european architecture.
One had a 3 spired cathedral overlayed with 3 angels, overlayed with some
lotus-like floral stuff in the middle...in the morning the words 'friends
and family' spiraled of into psychedelia, followed by 'rave on', 'love on'.
Yet again, an amazing talent right in our midst. Hats off to you Michael.

The energy. The people. I saw people there I haven't seen at a rave in
*years*. Big smiles, hugs all night, totally entirely positive. Not even
one remotely negative thing happened to me all night.

I thought the multimedia, ambient chill-whatever worked especially well
this time too. Not only was it really beautiful in there (somehow it felt
like dawn all night) but the sound isolation was really adequate and the
wildly eclectic variety of fine music that went down was just great. Fine
job everyone. 

And the graffiti, legendary. Best inscription of the night: 

eat more pork rinds +)

Hats off to all the folks at Komotion too. What a great group of people;
volunteers actually showed up *in the morning* to help us clean up and coil
muddy cables... Class act, start to finish.

And the kids...  :)   :)   :) boy did they have fun! All painted up and
just running all over. Right on.

 :)

Budget for the party:

 - promotion:        $30
 - u-haul:           $31
 - fans:             $50
 - misc. supplies:   $30
 - fruit:            $33
 - breakfast for 8:  $50

 - total:            $224 :)


The next F&F will be Saturday, September 24th. Bryce is going to 
coordinate this one as I will be getting to know the newest memeber of 
my friends and family :)

lots of love, and thanks again!
ethan

On Mon, 15 Aug 1994, Lee Fogel wrote, quoting Tamara:
> >I found that to be so evil, all of these people continually saying, "it's
> >all about coming together, no matter who you are, in the spirit of unity."
> >No. It was all about having enough money to be there and be cool.
> 
> Yeah, people went there to be cool, but they *did* come together.  And
> from what I could see, most seemed to be having fun and there seemed to be
> a positive vibe.  Considering 100,000 people got in for free, anyone who 
> wanted to haul there asses up there could of gotten in.  All you needed
> was some awareness, a friend with a car, the willingess to endure... kinda 
> like getting to an FMR.

Er, if I had paid $135 for entry tix plus everything else to get to the
event, I probably would have made damn sure I thought I was having fun,
despite anything to the contrary.  Meaning, the psychology of "we've
committed the time and energy to have fun now, so we're going to have fun
now..." is apparently very prevalent in modern day America.  You don't have
to be a conspiracy theorist to see that this is how modern media creates its
own news now - people have become way too malleable.  Woodstock '69 wasn't
designed to be great, it just sort of happened to have been great through
accident.  "This Generation's Woodstock" would have had to have been a mostly
spontaneous gesture - I submit that the most successful era of the FMR's (end
of 92 to end of 93) were mini-woodstocks for our generation.

	Brian

> she has Personality, but it runs all the way from A to B.  I heard
> about one on air bit she did waking people up in their tents. 
> Probably thought she was Making Their Day.  I would have rubbed her
> self-reverential face in some mud.  

  While attending a BBQ with a friend last saturday i caught Kennedy's
interviews.  She was incessently rude and would zip open
the tents of people who were sleeping stick the camera's lights and her
microphone in the person's face and expect them to say something. I was
amazed no one said anything nasty to her, but then again that might've
been edited out. After doing this her report continued on the sense that
"Well if its late and everyone is asleep lets check out the rave!" 
  So she then went over to the ravestock event and attempted to ask
this one particularly e'ing chap how he was doing.  He responded by just
dancing along and staring out at the camera with a smile.

  At this particular point i was enjoying the coverage and blurted out:
"Hah! He's e'ing his ba*ls off!"

later scoulded by my friend for the comment ;)

My mailer says that Fred Heutte said:
> 
> And finally, of course, a big thanks to Ethan and Bryce!  Now before
> you boys start with the "aw shux" routine, I think it's perfectly
> appropriate to take some credit.  You say you can't do it without us,
> but we LOVE to do it with you!

thanks so much, phred, and thank you /all/, sfraves!  it really is an "aw
shux" kinda thing...i know that i do work on these things, and it's really
nice that everyone appreciates that work.  but, really, i don't do any more
than i can, and only with the talents that i possess.  i truly and honestly
believe that i am just another partygoer.  it wouldn't be a party of the
magnitude and quality we just experienced without you all, and without
everyone who came, or talked with us about what they like and don't like
about parties, or those who threw parties we went to and liked or didn't
like.  Friends and Family is an important nexus in our community, and i
want it to continue being a confluence of as many people, ideas, visions,
experiences, and friends and families:  in that way, i believe, lies the
self-refreshing, ever-morphing, always creative matrix our hyper-circle of
friends and family expresses itself in.  

thanks to all of you who acknowledge my contribution to friends and family,
and other events.  in acknowledging my contribution, you are (in my view)
acknowledging those very same qualities in yourselves.  Bravo/brava
everyone!  we sure can throw a great party!
--

Well, I just *had* to write about this party-- even if I do have to log 
on here in Davis to do it. (Thank you, Peter, for loaning me that 
laptop-- just gotta get a female-female converter...)

Sean got me cranked.

Lee got me flying.

Ethan killed me and wiped the floor with me.


The atmosphere wasn't just warm in temperature -- i'm still *totally* 
high off the vibe that was just rushing through the place :) :) :)

I met a *record* number of people from the list! I even got to talk with 
alot of folks at some length, a rare thing and a good one. :)

It was also wonderful to find out that there are *so many* folks who are 
still into YSH.  :) :) :)

Yeah, there were a heck of alot of us sfraverbabesinblacksportsbras, 
weren't there?

per minute, at 2400 baud, I'm going to have to conclude later.

to Ethan, Bryce, Sean, myself, Matt, Greg, Mike (visuals) and Keith 
(Komotion) for their wonderful energy and dedication to sfr and to each

On Mon, 15 Aug 1994 16:11:20 -0700 (PD, Tenderloin Waxx wrote:

>even if ken *is* a lurking police officer...
>[which i confess i really think is unlikely, and insignificant]

Okay, let's clear this up (especially since this was the very first point 
of contention weeks ago :-) ).

[Paranoia mode on]

You cannot tell who is an undercover police officer.

Either on the net OR in person.

Sometimes, you might be able to tell that someone IS an undercover police 
officer, either if they are inept or if they don't care whether you know.

However, just because you once identified one or think you identified one, 
doesn't mean that those same patterns would apply to all others.

Even watching someone "rave" or pop an E is no guarantee, because the mind 
can always think something like "I did it for my country and the children" 
or some such silly rationalization.

So, you never can tell.  You might even be married to one. :-)

I'd like to say "And by the way, I'm not a police officer", but it really 
doesn't help you, because you could always think "maybe he's lying".

And, from my perspective, anyone else on sfraves or in any club could be a 
police officer.

It's just like secret agents, you can't tell if they're a double agent or 
a double-double agent. :-)

[Paranoia mode off]

So, big deal.

Remember that police officers are human beings just like anyone else.

>From some posts here, it seems that a warm rational conversation 
which appeals to the police officers as being part of "us" rather than 
"them" has some times been very effective in getting lenient treatment (as 
well as preventing "us" from creating a mental "them").

So, keeping putting flowers in the gun barrels. :-)

-
respect to all,

Ken            ken@snowcrest.net   (primary address)
               (if no answer, try ken.stuart@tigerteam.org )

Hey Jack,

A couple tracks to get you started:

Robot Man "Do Da Doo--Plastikman's Acid House remix." This the track that 
I played that Laura mentioned earlier. Also, check out anything else by 
Richard Hawtin/Plastikman which includes....

Fuse "Substance Abuse." Older track that you should still be able to find 
lying around.

Bobby Konders "Nervous Acid" You should be able to find bootlegs of this 
classic in record stores. 

Astral Matrix "High Tide" Spankin new track that roars! Pretty simple, 
but effective.

Saint Etienne "Like a Motorway--David Holmes/Dust Brothers remix." Two 
different styles, both wicked (technically, I would only consider the 
Holmes mix "acid".)

Project 4007 "It's our turn DJ Duke remixes." Floor burner. Check out the 
"DJ Duke Acid Groove." The only down side to this song is that was released 
about six months ago and probably been played thrice daily since.

Hardfloor--anything by this group, but listen first to "Aceperience" and
their remix of Robert Armani's "Circus Bells" on Robert Armani's double
pack remix album. 

Phuture--anything by them, but especially "We are phuture," "Acid Trax,"
and maybe the latest--"Mental Breakdown." Phuture is basically DJ Pierre
and Roy Davis, two pioneers of the 303 sound. I'm a bit disappointed in
most of the newer releases of Phuture since they only seem to be collages
of the older tracks. But if you can't find the older tracks, the newer
ones are as good as any. 

Underground Resistance-- "Acid Rain (1-3)" More 303s than you can 
hallucinate.

A few names to look out for:
Sven Vath, Caspar Pound, Ege Bam Yasi, Aphrohead, Acid Junkies, and Niko.

Some Labels to pay attention to:
Plus8, Strictly Rhythm (for your Acid house needs--one warning, though: 
this label also release a lot of main stream house as well....), 
Djax-up-beats, Trax, Eye-q, Harthouse, Labworks, and many of the smaller 
Detroit and Chicago labels, i.e. Definitive, Emotive, Nugroove, etc....

Have fun.
Lee

> -------------------------
> seaking of 303's, any of you got any 12" reccomendations for 303
> drenched acid tracks?  i missed sat. (i've been going to sleep
> and getting up *early* these days), but have noticed that there
> are some serious acid masters developing from the list.  any of you
> be kind enough to direct me to the *shit*?  i wanna get some acid,
> boy...

Brian says:
>  You don't have
> to be a conspiracy theorist to see that this is how modern media creates its
> own news now - people have become way too malleable. 

This is true.  However, in the case of "Woodshlock"/"Greedstock"'94, I 
found the media prepublicity to be enormously cynical and negative.
If we want to talk about being "cool"; slamming Woodstock '94, and the 
capitalistic/MTV angle seems to have been the cool thing to do for the 
past couple of months, and still is I suppose.  Talk about an obvious 
target.  But hey, I was as cynical as anyone, and I still wouldn't have 
paid to go.    

> Woodstock '69 wasn't
> designed to be great, it just sort of happened to have been great through
> accident.

Woodstock '94 was designed to be great (I guess) and therefore seemed 
doomed to fail.  The fact that it succeeded at all was largely an accident, 
IMO.  A shitload of people (nonravers, nonPLUR devotees) came together with 
minimal authoritarian structure and uncomfortable accomodations.  They 
managed to coexist in relative harmony for the sake of music and the chance 
to share in a unique experience.  I'm having a hard time seeing the "evil" 
in it, that's all.
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
Lee Fogel/\/\/\/\/\eVerything/\Is/\possiBlE/\/\/\/\/\lxfogel@srv.pacbell.com
____________________________________________________________________________

> Brian says:
> >  You don't have
> > to be a conspiracy theorist to see that this is how modern media creates 
its
> > own news now - people have become way too malleable. 
> 
> This is true.  However, in the case of "Woodshlock"/"Greedstock"'94, I 
> found the media prepublicity to be enormously cynical and negative.
> If we want to talk about being "cool"; slamming Woodstock '94, and the 
> capitalistic/MTV angle seems to have been the cool thing to do for the 
> past couple of months, and still is I suppose.  Talk about an obvious 
> target.  But hey, I was as cynical as anyone, and I still wouldn't have 
> paid to go.    

The thing that I'm still waiting to hear reported is how symbolic 
Woodstock 94 is of the entire generational issue.  All of the cynical 
press coverage is along the lines of "it was better when we were young.
Kids today are so capitalistic and shallow."

But -- these are the same people who did the original Woodstock, a symbol
of the peace and love non-materialistic 60s generation, who are now trying
their best to gouge $100 from their own children in generation X, then 
blame us for destroying one of their most loved icons.   



Rodney

>I just want to add another note of thanks to Michael and jim for the
>visuals.  Best I've seen at *any* party in a good long while.  And
>the F&F logo was Rilly Kewl!  The peak moment was during Sean's set

>matched *perfectly* with the mood of the music without it being
>clash-bang-destructo, more like a different version of that famous
>loop of the milk drop.

That was from the awesome film Koyanisquattsi (my contribution to the
nights visuals :) by Goddfrey Reggio (with soundtrack by Phillip Glass,
perhaps one of *the* most sampled musicians in techno; the vapor space
intro for example...) Michael also added real time effects to it later in
the evening as well. There are long slow motion shots of people walking up
the street in las vegas...he kind of solarized this close up of an old man
turning and looking deep into the camera..his face kind of bubbled and
flared....

+)

Lee's suggestions were pretty exhaustive but....

Keep your eyes open for work by Random XS (on DJAX), *great* new acid. Also
most stuff on Important Records (German) especially Acrid Abeyance...this
stuff can get *real* hard :) Similarly the Psycho Tribes (Labworks,
Germany) label has got loads of excellent deep trancy acid...

One of my all time favorites in the classic acid house vein has got to be
"Land of Confusion", by Armando...I've got it on Warehouse but I think the
remixes of it are available as DJAX-UP 155...Also in the acid house vain
check out the Baker Track series by Rodney Baker on Rockin House...Minimal
but great mixing tools. On the minimal tip good acid coming out of Italy as
well, check out Acid Tools/Randmoizer (A/B side) on Muzak...

I just love acid fiends :)

Oh yeah, MUST HAVE: The Two Full Moons and a Trout Remixes, double pack by
Union Jack on Rising High (another great label)... my favorite record(s)
over the last couple months :) 

see ya
ethan

My mailer says that ethan miller said:
> 
> Oh yeah, MUST HAVE: The Two Full Moons and a Trout Remixes, double pack by
> Union Jack on Rising High (another great label)... my favorite record(s)
> over the last couple months :) 
> 
i second this, and lee's suggestions, too.  I would like to add my personal
favorite 303 based EP:  TTB002, by Richard Brown.  This looks like an indie
release.  I picked it up in SD, and have heard reports it showed up in 
Primal.  3 of the 4 tracks are outstanding: TTB303, Flange-o-matic, and
Electronics for Dogs.  Buy this record if you see it!  i have heard reports
of a TTB003 out that is a wanker, so watch out.

Also, i recommend Generation of Sound's "Feel It", and Solar Quest, both
on Chocci's Chewns.  Outstanding 303.  Solar Quest has a track that has a
303 sounding like bagpipes!

And, if you can only buy one thing, get the Plastikman double EP:  this is
an oldie, but an absolute classic.  Be on the lookout for the ElektroStatik
EP as well...my favorite Hawtin tracks.

Also, an older set of releases are on the Edge label, often seen in BPM,
and in Orange County.  #5 and 9 are awesome.
-- 
----Bryce Ryan------------AMBIANCE-----------------brycer@ultima.org-------

Brian Behlendorf said:

> Er, if I had paid $135 for entry tix plus everything else to get to the
> event, I probably would have made damn sure I thought I was having fun,
> despite anything to the contrary.  Meaning, the psychology of "we've
> committed the time and energy to have fun now, so we're going to have fun
> now..." is apparently very prevalent in modern day America.  

Ummm.. i dunno i have paid 20 bucks and driven for
3 hours through the middle of nowhere to get to a party more than a few times.
And you know...  very few people there seemed to have an attitude of
"well dammit, i've gone through this much trouble, im going to force myself
to have fun" 
it was either one of bitching and moaning about the whole thing
or they were having fun...
but unless it was a subconscious thing...

most of the people i know who say that whole "im going to enjyo myself"
thing, spend their whole time saying that and bitching
about why all the reasons why they are going to just go and
have a good time

> You don't have
> to be a conspiracy theorist to see that this is how modern media creates its
> own news now - people have become way too malleable.  Woodstock '69 wasn't
> designed to be great, it just sort of happened to have been great through
> accident.  "This Generation's Woodstock" would have had to have been a mostly
> spontaneous gesture - I submit that the most successful era of the FMR's (end
> of 92 to end of 93) were mini-woodstocks for our generation.

Woodstock '69 WAS designed to be great, its just that
it turned out to be great in a different way than it was planned.

Woodstock '69 and '94 are quite similar in the way the completely
trashed the environment just to have a good time.  BUT i bet
the clean up from 94 will be a hell of a lot better than 69.

Woodstock '69 was a bunch of kids ripping off a promoter,
land owner and a bunch of artists while trashing the environment
all in the name of peace and love.  (IMNSHO :) 

To me, a mini-woodstock would be a few thousand people rushing a concert/party
and getting in for free so that the promoter couldnt afford
to pay anyone but the artists still performed and people had a great time.

Although i think some of the FMR's were getting kinda close to that
about the environment and all, the FMR's were intended to be free.
(Speaking of which, i really hope the Sunset crew is taking
care of the Marina or other places they use.)

Im sorry, but i just dont think of Woodstock as something to live up to..
actually i dont think we shoudl be trying to duplicate anything in the past
its just way too much of Gen X type thing to do :)

The idea of throwing a party on the beach where a few hundred or thousand
people get together and dance and have fun and whatever isnt really a new
idea, im sure the people who came down the bearing strait 
beat us to that idea a hell of a long time ago,
but i dont see the need to compare to those parties anymore
than i do to see a comparison to woodstock

they had fun
we're having fun, i hope :)

 ,
dana

"If we were meant to rave naked, we would have been born that way."

From: brycer@ultima.org (Bryce Ryan)
Subject: Launch Pad in the news
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Date: Tue, 16 Aug 1994 12:16:30 -0700 (PDT)
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL23]
Content-Type: text
Content-Length: 1588

Precedence: bulk

Recently seen in _Urb Massv_:

"And now, a quick story.  If i was going to call this something, i'd call 
it 'the overachiever,' but i won't. 

"A few Saturdays ago, a friend came and picked me up about 3 in the morning.
I knew he was coming, so i had some cocktails waiting.  I'll call him 'Alex'.
We had some drinks, then decided to hit a few clubs and check out an
outlaw called Launc Pad, put on, incidentally, by the S.F.Net [sic],
some computer deal i know nothing about [sic :)].  So we swing by Funky
Buddha up on Broadway, then Release, then down Third St. to the bay for
Launch Pad.  As we're walking down the path to get to the party, we can start
to hear the music and make out people dancing and milling about.  We get a
little closer and i see that 1) the DJ is an old, old friend of mine, and
2) there's a large contraption standing next to him.  I'll call the DJ
'Buck'.  So we come up to Buck and I realize that he's lugged a Reel To Reel
Tape Player all the way down a dirt path and set it up in this cold field at 
5 in the morning and is mixing (not easy do to off a reel, especially with
frozen hands) to about 15 kids as the sun comes up over San Francisco Bay!
What kind of devotion is that?!  I couldn't believe it.  So we had a good
laugh, dug the party, and then headed home for a breakfast of bong hits
and Heineken before sending Buck and his Reel off to play at Light-n-Up.
Now that's dedication!  The End.

"OK. Maybe you had to be there, but that shit was /funny/!"

by "Toph"
-- 
----Bryce Ryan------------AMBIANCE-----------------brycer@ultima.org-------

---------- Forwarded message ----------

Subject: Josh Wink

HI..this is my first post to this list (i'm not even subscribed yet)...i 
just wanted to say one thing..i talked to one of my favorite East Coast DJ'
s this weekend, Josh Wink, and he mentioned that he was spinning at a 
rave in SF this Saturday, the 20th. I *URGE* all lovers of tribal, trance 
and fonkay house to go see this *incredible* DJ. He just rules. 
Also, many of you who know me know that i'm moving out to the BAy area 
soon...well, me, handi and doug should be out there by the end of the month.
But that's a different subject...GO SEE JOSH WINK!

---------- Forwarded message ----------
From: mjpfister@ucdavis.edu
Date: Tue, 16 Aug 1994 01:06:26 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: Re: F&F&F/303 acid

On Mon, 15 Aug 1994, Laura La Gassa wrote:

> On the techno end of the acid spectrum, I suggest anything from the
> English label "Chocci's Chewns."  Killer.  And it's pressed on bright
> red vinyl.
> 
> Laura
> 
Incidentally, if you happen to find yourself in London in the near future 
with a fixin' for some new vinyl, you should visit Choci himself at his 
store (also called Choci's Chewns). Choci will ask you for a couple songs 
you like, estimate your style, and then procede to start slam-mixing 
large amounts of vinyl in that you'll find to your liking, while dancing 
about, whooping, and jumping off the walls. Energetic hardly is 
a discriptive enough word. Loony is almost a better discription, but only 
a sane man would stock such music. Lots of hard trance, acid, and gabber.
The stores a bit hard to find, it's essntially a basement in an alley off 
of soho. (the address: The Basement, 9-12 St Annes Ct. (Off Wardour ST.) 
London, W1V 3AX.) Highly recommended, and has the least attitude of any 
of the DJ shops in London.
---->Marc

Since it's praising Choci time, I may as well add my favorites.... Look
out for "Acid crumble" parts 1 and 2, and the latest release--Sound
Foundation's "Worship--the twisted mix." The first two may be hard to find
as they've been out for a while now, but they're worth it if you can get
your hands on them.

Samalll parties seem to be in this summer as ocmpared to last summer when 
they seemed to be a bitg hardert o find.  I liked friends and family 3, 
but laura la gasssa was nowhere to be found!  well, i dont' know what she 
looks like, so that was no help.  also, i was lookfing for "Susan R. 
Kameny", who was also nowhere to be found.  So after long seconds of deep 
depression, i danced my fingers off on what I call the mezzanine level, 
but what most people call the "sweatbox"   did maui say it was like 95 
degrees in there?  i believe tath was true.  

boing, im  on bart...........emb.......oakland.......berkeley
took the 51A instead of the M...............walked the rest of the way

Sunset was definitely alive this weekend.  There I meccad with the wind, 
the grass, the dirt, and the trees.  i reverted back to my primal being 
and for one minute in my life, forgot about the 99 cent whopper, which if 
you eat enough of them, can cost you 99 dollars at Jenny Craig.  So the 
moral of this story is if Sunset can make me forget about consumer 
products all the way until the sun goes down, something must be good.  I 
looked up that hill and saw a nationof ravers.  i heard some local kids 
as they were l3evingsay "yo man, i come here every sunday>"  

maybe we could set up one of these little sunset parties on the white 
house lawn.  



From sfraves-owner  Tue Aug 16 14:22:15 1994

From: Ben Rockwood <benr@solano.community.net>
Subject: Amdient Radio Shows
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Message-ID: <Pine.3.89.9408161402.A2039-0100000@solano.community.net>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

I mentioned this awhile back, but i'm doing it again now that i know more 
about it....   

            Ambient Radio Shows on KWOD 106.5 FM (Sacramento)
           ---------------------------------------------------

Sunday Night -    10p - 12   :  Ambience; a purly ambient radio show, 
playing everything from Less House Hippy, to KMFDM, to Seefeel, to the 
Orb, a good show for listening to selected tracks, and new stuff...

Sunday Night -    12 - 2a    :  David X's Ambient Mix; The somewhat well 
know DJ in sac-town, plays a full 2 hour live mix on the air...  
Excellent show if you enjoy light mixes, and all that stuff...

Monday Night -    12 - 2a    :  the Mix Show; If you like club going, but 
just kan't get out of the office, or just don't feel like making that 
drive down to SC, this is the show for you !!!  I listen to it each week, 
and often times record it...  Featuring local, and passing DJ's, that all 
of us know and love... Last week they played a set from DJdan's 
performance at one of the local klubs earlier that week...  This show is 
a must, and is the best on the air !!!


More info as i get it....

On Tue, 16 Aug 1994, John Draper wrote:
> I'm getting triplicate copies of everything in the SFRaves mailing list,
> so when the hyperreal machine was taken off line,   something happened,
> that one should look at and try and fix.

The only thing I could see causing that is the fact that when I take 
hyperreal down and back up, it restarts the sendmail queues it was 
working on, which can result in a few people (evidently hitting netcom 
users) getting messages delivered both times.  It's now up at its new 
place and happy and stable, so that shouldn't happen much anymore.  
Nothing "happened" when I moved it.  If I notice anything else unusual (I 
haven't) I'll fix it and let you all know.  Thanks for your patience.

	Brian

Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Russian River rave report
-------------------------

  Sorry for being late with the report,  but due to power outage and the
heat wave,    I couldn't get on the computer any sooner.  And especially
sorry I missed F&F III.

  On the way up to Healdsburg,  I met Radion who invited us to a Thai Chi
party out near the Russian river.    WOW!! I was really getting INTO this
Thai Chi stuff BIG TIME,  really enjoyed it,  dispite the fearce heat.

  After that,  we took a great swim in the river before heading to the
Groove Kitchen site.     We arrive just after dark,   and the music was
a mellow Acid Jazz,   as we started to get in the mood for serious dancing.

  After about 10 pm,  the music picked up,   although not at full volume,
was just barely adequate for dancing,   but they kept it up all night.

  The place was really beautiful,   very warm evening,  up in the high
80's.    About 250 people showed up,  and it had a flavor like the rainbow
gathering with lots of small encamplemts.    We set up camp,   and I made
a great Chill out area to go to when I wanted to stretch out after dancing.

   All throughout the evening,  the sound was nudged up until the camp
owners complained,   then it had to get turned down.   Once they left,
the sound went back up again,   with more and more people dancing.

   About 6 am,  Marky Mark took over the turntables,  and the volume started
to get turned way up,   as the energy level increased,  and people woke up,
in the morning,  things were really hopping.

   Down by the river,  there was this eary fog that clung along the banks,
making the scene almost prehistoric with the moss hanging from the trees,
I almost expected to see a T' rex stomping around out there.

   As the morning progressed,  the energy and joy levels were of the likes
I haven't seen in a long time.    Radion was dancing like there was no
tommorrow,  with the biggest smile I have ever seen, and it just spread
around the group until I was laughing so hard I could hardly dance.
By that time,   about 50 - 70 people were kicking up a storm BIG TIME
as Marky spun the most incredable trance set I've heard in a very long 
time.    There were a lot of bystanders looking on shaking their heads
as we went apeshit hopping around the dance area.   When Jeno went on,
everyone went berserk.

   Even in the morning, just as the sun was coming up,   the temperature
was still a balmy 70 degrees,   very calm,  no wind and the eary fog 
clinging around the river banks.

   About 10 am or so,   we were told to turn the music down again,   then
we had free hot cakes and food and took a break from dancing.

   While kicking back in the warm weather,   the sound crew moved the speakers
to overlook the cliffs and face the river,   as people were starting to swim.

   As the music started up again,   I warmed up dancing,  in anticipation of
jumping in the river.    WOW!!   Dancing and swimming are such a GREAT 
combination,  especially as I was dancing in the water,  swerling around to
the music.   WOW!!...  I finally figured out some new swimming motions and
movements that put me in a super trancey state,  as I was taking advantage
of the ever present currents moving me down river,  then going back up stream
again,  swimming to the music.    Acid Jazz is perfect for dancing, while
in the water....  as I made slow direction changes and flips underwater to
the music.     I could even hear the music while underwater....  What a trip!!
I'll never forget the experience.    

   Later in the afternoon,   after the music changed to slower acid jazz, more
and more people were in the river,  covering themselves totally in mud.    Aaron,
my friend looked like the "Swamp thing" as he sported a pineapple leaves on his
head,  covered completly in mud.    Lots of people were totally covered in mud
which served to protect them from the fearce sun.    By the afternoon,  the
temperature was about 105 degrees,   most everyone was dancing in the river by
that time.

   About 5 pm,  the camp owners forced us to shut down the music,   but out 
popped the boom boxes,  so the music never really stopped.    

   I met some people from India (Goa) who had some killer tapes from the
legendary Goa raves.    We had a killer dinner that evening,   and hung around
and enjoyed the very warm evening before heading back Sunday evening.

   For those at Freinds and Family III,   I'm sorry to have missed hearing
Sean spin,   but I know I'll get more of a chance at a later time.    But,
I much prefer outdoor events where I can escape the constant cigerette
smoke totally.    This is the first time where I haven't felt the sickening
dizzyness on a Monday,  like I do,  after I've been cooped up in a stuffy 
and hot room,  doing aeroboc dancing,  sucking in the poisons.     So,  for
those wondering where I was this weekend,    you all know.    Again!!  I
couldn't be in two places at once,   but perhaps I can make F&F IV.

Peace
CC

UPDATE! on InterLAB rave/techno net-musician compilation
----------------------------------------------------------------------

  so far we've received more than a dozen submissions and we are
  getting tons of support from already established musicians,
  labels and distributors! the general response to the idea has
  been nothing but positive and so we are very excited to get this
  project underway. to follow are some important notes that should
  answer some of the questions people have been asking about us...
  if you have ANY other questions, please e-mail us (please note
  our new address below)...

  					acidophile & modE
					 InterLAB rekkids

  SUBMISSION INFO
  ---------------------------------------------------------------
  we expect to release the compilation in late september, so get
  your submissions to us soon. send them to:

				InterLAB rekkids
				2582 stowell unit S
				milwaukee WI 53211

  all formats acceptable (cassette, DAT, vinyl, or even VHS).
  please include all vitals including booking info if any. of
  course you must include an e-mail address...


  MORE INFO ON RELEASE
  ---------------------------------------------------------------
  the compilation will contain approx. 90 minutes of original
  material by net-musicians ONLY. (our label will always be for
  net-musicians ONLY). the tape will be DIGITALLY MASTERED and
  will be available for $5 including postage. the tape will be
  distributed over the net as well as at events/parties and any
  interested retail outlets. but it will never cost more than
  $5. the object here is not to make money, but to get the power
  of the net surging through as many of us as possible and to
  work with musicians on upcoming InterLAB releases on vinyl.
  initially 500 copies will be made available and then copies
  will be made on a per order basis. extra copies will also be
  made for promotional purposes. let us know if you need more
  release details. in late september we will post track listings
  along with ordering details. 

		WE ARE STILL ACCEPTING SUBMISSIONS!!!  
  

  ADDRESS CHANGE
  ---------------------------------------------------------------
  we now have a seperate address for InterLAB, so please take
  note of our new address:

                        InterLAB@Mtech.csd.uwm.edu


  InterLAB MAILING-LIST
  ---------------------------------------------------------------
  to be sure you dont miss future details about this and other
  InterLAB releases you may want to be added to our mailing list.
  dont worry, its not gonna stuff-up your mailbox! just e-mail
  us if you want to subscribe...


  peace/respect/unity through dance...


  acidophile & modE                                          InterLAB rekkids
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
						   InterLAB@Mtech.csd.uwm.edu

							  2582 stowell unit S
							  milwwaukee wi 53211
								 414.964.7590

Greetings, Ravers!

I know it's very soon, and the sweat from F&F^3 has barely been cleaned off,
but it's surprisingly soon to our next date at Komotion: Saturday, September
24th.  I'd like to ask you all a few questions, so you can help set me in
the right direction to help organize the next one.  Thanks in advance for
your time!

1).  Do you want another one? Is September 24 a good date?
2).  What theme would you like?  I've had a vision of doing an ambient oriented
     thing in the big room, but i will be happy to provide what the consensus
     desires.  I can provide an ambient fix in other ways :)
3).  What needs to be improved for the next one?  What wasn't there that you
     would like to experience? What was there that you want to stay for the
     next one?
4).  How can you assist us?
5).  How can we assist you?

Again, many thanks!
-- 
----Bryce Ryan------------AMBIANCE-----------------brycer@ultima.org-------

Anyone who is going or is thinking about going to Arizona for the World 
Unity Festival is welcomed to join us for a casual meeting this thursday 
at 6:00 pm at 960 Oak between Pierce and Scott.this could be a good 
opportunity for people who are looking for rides to hook up with people 
who have room in their vehicles.We'll also be discussing the realities of 
setting up sound system(s) somewhere in the area,so fellow mobile dance 
fanatics are also welcome.the meeting may also be attended on IRC 
channel# QuangYin, as we will have a terminal hooked up in the room.

PLEASE NOTE:this is not a "zippie" meeting.this meeting will be attended 
by members of Food Not Bombs,Global Peace Walk,T.A.Z.(traveling 
autonomous zone),Urban Nomads,Fraser Clark,etc...,anyone who considers 
themselves to be a "zippie" is certainly welcome also.

p.s.-----f&f m3 rocked out hard , although i didn't see any naked 
people--maybe they all went to Woodstock,man...

peace
aaron
communications advisor,

> 
> 1).  Do you want another one? Is September 24 a good date?

 Should be fine! 

> 2).  What theme would you like?  I've had a vision of doing an ambient oriented
>      thing in the big room, but i will be happy to provide what the consensus
>      desires.  I can provide an ambient fix in other ways :)

 Jim and I would love to play for a more ambient oriented event. Our music
 while it will have beats is not currently hardcore dance beat oriented - 
 more like something approaching the softer side of the Orb.
 Of course, I could understand if everyone wants only the "get down-go up
 party" from the onset. Another position might be to begin the evening
 ambient building up to an all out groove in the middle say 2:30-3:00 and
 then to go out that way or to bring things back to Earth in the morning
 say about 5:30. Of course, this would take a bit of coordinating between
 the music contributors but I'm sure that's possible too.

> 3).  What needs to be improved for the next one?  What wasn't there that you
>      would like to experience? What was there that you want to stay for the
>      next one?

 I'll pass - I'm not sure you can improve near perfection. The ventilation
 would really take an attic fan - and that would require roof alterations
 with $$, permits etc.

> 4).  How can you assist us?

 Can supply live music as Star Zeit - we assume our music is as good as our
 visuals. Can supply visuals. Can supply BOTH - obviously. Am discussing
 with Komotion on producing some visual segments with thier logos and themes
 "bouncing through" - perhaps to be used on the 24th?
 I have a video projector and screen with VCR. Also, have a small PA
 consisting of 2- 15" Cabs, 2- 12" Satellites with stands to raise them and
 a 250 watt per side amp.

> 5).  How can we assist you?

 Let me know what assistance is needed and whether I should begin working
 up some visuals, music or both.

Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

IMHO

>1).  Do you want another one? Is September 24 a good date?

Absolutely! As far as the date is concerned I'm sure everyone will have
their own opinion for a favorite day or week but you ultimately have to
make the decision. (For instance I would prefer a different weekend because
on a holiday weekend too many friends come in town or too many people go
out of town.  The next weekend is no good either 'cause I'll be in SD....it
is just impossible to accomodate everyone.)

>2).  What theme would you like?  I've had a vision of doing an ambient oriented
>     thing in the big room, but i will be happy to provide what the consensus
>     desires.  I can provide an ambient fix in other ways :)

I think an ambient ORIENTED thing would be a GREAT idea.  First I think it
would be almost impossible to recreate F&F^3 in it's feel and energy except
to duplicate it exactly using the same formula.  By having something
completely different you will cultivate a different energy bringing out
various moods in people's personality.  Having been to both "Ambience"
performances at King Street (not trying to compare or influence), I felt
that both parties were very condusive to meeting and talking more with new
aquaintences. I feel that it would be better to have a variety of ambient
music including some with beat because it breaks the heavyness/seriousness
that ambience can create.  Pete Namlook did it very well in his live
performance by bringing in a drum loop that people started to sway to.
Same with Young American Primitive who did a very upbeat ambient set at the
second "Ambience" Party.

>3).  What needs to be improved for the next one?  What wasn't there that you
>     would like to experience? What was there that you want to stay for the
>     next one?

Again, I thought the visuals were incredible at F&F^3 a deffinite keep.  As
far as the heat goes, I personally don't mind it for dancing, but for an
ambient party it may be difficult to sit through.


It could be interresting to see or read how this will develop.  I do not
have any specific talent in how to help (I'm just a succer for great music)
but all the same I would enjoy helping if I fit anywhere.


Denis,  ravnbird@crl.com

On Wed, 17 Aug 1994 12:01:33 -0700 (PD, Michael E. Clay wrote:

>> Hello,
>> 
>> I was logged on to CDC (Compact Disc Connection) and they have listed:
>> 
>> Steve Hillage - Rainbow Dome Music    $13.13
>> 
>> so it seems to be still available.
>> 
>  What/Who/Where is this CDC ? Their prices seem good - logged on ? Are
>  they on the NET?  What's the scoop? 
>
>  From one who wants to know:  Mike Clay
>
>
> PS You can post to the group if others might like to know. I forgot to
>   cc to them... :-)

Okay (although this information gets posted often to alt.rave...).

Compact Disc Connection is a company that has modem phone numbers all over 
the US, although they are right here in the Bay Area.

You can logon to their system at (408)985-8982 (8N1, 9600 baud max.).

Or you can telnet to cdconnection.com (199.35.15.2).

They have an on-line catalog listing 90,000 CDs, including most domestic 
CDs and some imports.  They stock NOTHING, but order from their suppliers 
several times a week.  Hence they have no warehouse or inventory costs.

I've used them several times, with no problems.  They managed to fill 
every request, except for one CD was out of stock at all their suppliers - 
pretty good overall.  If you order $100 or more, shipping is free.  If 
they can't fill a request, then the shipping charge is only that 
percentage of what they fill (ie if they fill 3 out of 4, then they only 
charge you 75% of the usual shipping charge).  Naturally, they use credit 
card for payment.

What they DON'T carry, you can usually get from EAR/Rational Music, which 
is at   angst@xmission.com   , who specializes in techno & alternative 
stuff, including imports (mostly CDs, btw).

-
respect to all,

Ken            ken@snowcrest.net   (primary address)
               (if no answer, try ken.stuart@tigerteam.org )

Thanks.  And let me know if you are going.  I haven't met a SFraver I haven't
liked yet.

-troy

RADIO! RADIO! Status Report 2

 DJ schedule - This is the DJ sequence so far:

 Bryce :    Setup to 2PM
 Laura :    2PM to 3PM
 Harrywho : 3PM to 4PM
 JSL :      4PM to 5PM
 Talizman : 5PM to 6PM
 Deaks :    6PM to 7PM
 ???? :     7PM to end ... ( Open slot , but read below ) 

 Speaking of the end ... if folks are going to other things Saturday
night , then maybe 7PM is a more realistic ending than 8PM , if not
sooner. Depends on how many folks are left by then. 8PM is the absolute
end time , to give time for cleanup and breaking down the sound system. 

 
 Getting to Sunnyvale Baylands Park from Santa Cruz: I guess I forgot 
the folks coming from the coast! Take HW 17/880 from Santa Cruz ,
through the mountains and hills to Los Gatos and San Jose. Take HW 280
north towards San Francisco , and take the Lawrence Expressway exit
and head north/east towards the bay on Lawrence. After driving  about 
five miles , you'll reach the HW237 overpass. Once over HW 237 , the 
park entrance is at the right. After the toll booth, take
the right hand driveway to the end , to the picnic site called Owl
Burrow.

 Who's Who ??? - My wife Mary and I have designed some RADIO! RADIO! 
name tags for those who show up - match faces to names! They'll be
luggage-style tags , 2.5" by 3.5" .
 We'll need some markers so folks can sign and decorate their name
tags - any volunteers? If ya' got day-glo , even better! 

 Food & drink - Only two replies so far on my question about potluck 
vs bring-yer-own ... more info please!

 Table - I think I can convert my Black & Decker workbench into a table
for the mixer and turntables. I just gotta get busy with some wood
and nails ... Of course , if someone has a handy table with at least
19" by 60" dimensions , it would save me some sawing ...

 Canopy - I am going to call the park tomorrow and ask them if they
will allow me to tie ropes to their picnic roof beams. If so , a 
windbreak/sunshade canopy can be simple done with some rope and a
big tarp.


	That's it for now - 
			Larry Ching/larryc@netcom.com

From sfraves-owner  Thu Aug 18 01:44:10 1994
