From: Fred Heutte <phred@well.sf.ca.us>
Message-Id: <199408180843.BAA00641@well.sf.ca.us>
To: dcraves@auvm.american.edu, ne-raves@umdd.umd.edu, nw-raves@wimsey.bc.ca,
        sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: UK Criminal Justice Bill: Repression of Raves
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


The Criminal Justice Bill now before Parliament in the United Kingdom
is partly a political response to the social backlash against the spreading
of 'rave culture'.  In its typically heavy-handed way, as so often
during the dead-hand rule of the Tories, it tries to deal with societal
change through repression.  The provisions banning outdoor unlicensed
raves would be instantly tossed out as unconstitutional in the United
States due to the specificity of language about the definition of the
prohibited music and special treatment under the law for a particular
class of people (those attending outdoor raves).

But the provisions concerning the seizure of property, including audio
equipment and vehicles, are well within the bounds of current American
law, as evidenced by computer seizures in the various high-profile
"hacker" shutdown operations and the more widespread seizure of property
under the revised drug laws *prior to conviction or even indictment*,
and regardless of whether legal proceedings continue following the
seizures.

So I think we in the States have to pay attention to the course of the
Criminal Justice Bill, not only for any outdoor parties we may be
attending or involved with, but because this represents potential future
pressure on our rights under the continually eroding and nearly forgotten
Fourth Amendment to the US Constitution.

I grabbed this text off the uk-dance mailing list.  A second large rally
(following the one last month) is scheduled this Sunday in London,
running from Hyde Park to Trafalgar Square.  The turnout will no doubt
be more impressive even than the last one.

I'll try to fill in on developments as they occur, but I'd appreciate
info and thoughts from any of our UK friends here.

phred

---------------------------------------------------------------------------

Sections 53-56 of the Criminal Justice Bill

Powers in relation to raves

53.--(1) This section applies to a gathering on land in the open air of
         100 or more persons (whether or not trespassers) at which amplified
         music is played during the night (with or without intermissions)
         and is such as, by reason of its loudness and duration and the time
         at which it is played, is likely to cause serious distress to the
         inhabitants of the locality; and for this purpose--

         (a) such a gathering continues during intermissions in the music
             and, where the gathering extends over several days, throughout
             the period during which amplified music is played at night (with
             or without intermissions); and

         (b) "music" includes sounds wholly or predominantly characterised
             by the emission of a succession of repetitive beats.

     (2) If a police officer of at least the rank of superintendent reasonably
         believes that ten or more persons are present on land in the open
         air--

         (a) making preparations for the holding there of a gathering to
             which this section applies,
         (b) waiting for such a gathering to begin there, or
         (c) attending such a gathering which is in progress,

         he may give a direction that those persons and any other persons who
         come to attend the gathering are to leave the land and remove any
         vehicles or other property which they have with them on the land.

     (3) A direction under subsection (2) above, if not communicated to the
         persons referred to in subsection (2) by the police officer giving the
         direction, may be communicated to them by any constable at the scene.

     (4) Persons shall be treated as having had a direction under subsection
         (2) above communicated to them if reasonable steps have been taken to
         bring it to their attention.

     (5) A direction under subsection (2) above does not apply to an exempt
         person.

     (6) If a person knowing that a direction has been given which applies
         to him--

         (a) fails to leave the land as soon as reasonably practicable, or

         (b) having left again enters the land within the period of 7 days
             beginning with the day on which the direction was given,

         he commits an offence and is liable on summary conviction to
         imprisonment for a term not exceeding three months or a fine not
         exceeding level 4 on the standard scale, or both.

     (7) In proceedings for an offence under this section it is a defence for
         the accused to show that he had a reasonable excuse for failing to
         leave the land as soon as reasonably practicable or, as the case may
         be, for again entering the land.

     (8) A constable in uniform who reasonably suspects that a person is
         committing an offence under this section may arrest him without a
         warrant.

     (9) This section does not apply to a gathering licensed by an
         entertainment licence.

    (10) In this section--

         "entertainment licence" means a licence granted by a local authority
         under--

         (a) Schedule 12 to the London Government Act 1963;

         (b) section 3 of the Private Places of Entertainment (Licensing)
             1967 c. 19. Act 1967; or

         (c) Schedule 1 to the Local Government (Miscellaneous Provisions)
             Act 1982;

         "exempt persons", in relation to land (or any gathering on land),
         means the occupier, any member of his family and any employee
         or agent of his and any person whose home is situated on the
         land;

         "land in the open air" includes a place partly open to the air;

         "local authority" means--

         (a) in Greater London, a London borough council or the
             Common Council of the City of London;

         (b) outside Greater London, a district council or the council of
             the Isles of Scilly; and

         "occupier" and "vehicle" have the same meaning as in section 51.


54.--(1) If a police officer of at least the rank of superintendent
         reasonably believes that circumstances exist in relation to any
         land which would justify the giving of a direction under section 53
         in relation to a gathering to which that section applies he may
         authorise any constable to enter the land for any of the purposes
         specified in subsection (2) below.

      (2) Those purposes are--

          (a) to ascertain whether such circumstances exist; and

          (b) to exercise any power conferred on a constable by section 53 or
              subsection (4) below.

      (3) A constable who is so authorised to enter land for any purpose may
          enter the land without a warrant.

      (4) If a direction has been given under section 53 and a constable
          reasonably suspects that any person to whom the direction applies has
          failed without reasonable excuse to remove any vehicle or sound
          equipment on the land which appears to the constable to belong to him
          or to be in his possession or under his control, the constable may
          seize and retain that vehicle or sound equipment.

      (5) Subsection (4) above does not authorise the seizure of any vehicle
          or sound equipment of an exempt person.

      (6) In this section--

          "exempt person" has the same meaning as in section 53;

          "sound equipment" means equipment designed or adapted for
          amplifying music and any equipment suitable for use in
          connection with such equipment, and "music" has the same
          meaning as in section 53; and

          "vehicle" has the same meaning as in section 51.


55.--(1) If a constable in uniform reasonably believes that a person is
         on his way to a gathering to which section 53 applies in relation
         to which a direction under section 53(2) is in force, he may,
         subject to subsections (2) and (3) below--

         (a) stop that person, and

         (b) direct him not to proceed in the direction of the gathering.

     (2) The power conferred by this section may only be exercised at a
         place within 5 miles of the boundary of the site of the gathering.

     (3) No direction may be given under this section to an exempt person.

     (4) In this section, "exempt person" has the same meaning as in section
         53.


56.--(1) Where a person is convicted of an offence under section 53 in
         relation to a gathering to which that section applies and the court
         is satisfied that any sound equipment which has been seized from him
         under section 54(4) or which was in his possession or under his
         control at the relevant time has been used at the gathering the
         court may make an order for forfeiture under this subsection in
         respect of that property.

     (2) The court may make an order under subsection (1) above whether
         or not it also deals with the offender in respect of the offence in
         any other way and without regard to any restrictions on forfeiture
         in any enactment.

     (3) In considering whether to make an order under subsection (1)
         above in respect of any property a court shall have regard--

         (a) to the value of the property; and
         (b) to the likely financial and other effects on the offender of the
             making of the order (taken together with any other order that
             the court contemplates making).

     (4) An order under subsection (1) above shall operate to deprive the
         offender of his rights, if any, in the property to which it relates,
         and the property shall (if not already in their possession) be taken
         into the possession of the police.

     (5) Where any property has been forfeited under subsection (1) above,
         a magistrates' court may, on application by a claimant of the
         property, other than the offender from whom it was forfeited under
         subsection (1) above, make an order for delivery of the property
         to the applicant if it appears to the court that he is the owner
         of the property.

     (6) No application shall be made under subsection (S) above by any
         claimant of the property after the expiration of 6 months from the
         date on which an order under subsection (1) above was made in
         respect of the property.

     (7) No such application shall succeed unless the claimant satisfies the
         court either that he had not consented to the offender having
         possession of the property or that he did not know, and had no
         reason to suspect, that the property was likely to be used at a
         gathering to which section 53 applies.

     (8) An order under subsection (5) above shall not affect the right of any
         person to take, within the period of 6 months from the date of an
         order under subsection (5) above, proceedings for the recovery of the
         property from the person in possession of it in pursuance of the
         order, but on the expiration of that period the right shall cease.

     (9) The Secretary of State may make regulations for the disposal of
         property, and for the application of the proceeds of sale of property,
         forfeited under subsection (1) above where no application by a
         claimant of the property under subsection (5) above has been made
         within the period specified in subsection (6) above or no such
         application has succeeded.

    (10) The regulations may also provide for the investment of money and
         for the audit of accounts.

    (11) The power to make regulations under subsection (9) above shall be
         exercisable by statutory instrument which shall be subject to
         annulment in pursuance of a resolution of either House of Parliament.

    (12) In this section--

         "relevant time", in relation to a person convicted of an offence under
         section 53, means the time of his arrest for the offence or of the
         issue of a summons in respect of it;

         "sound equipment" has the same meaning as in section 54.


   Retention and charges for seized property

57.--(1) Any vehicles which have been seized and removed by a
         constable under section 52(1) or 54(4) may be retained in accordance
         with regulations made by the Secretary of State under subsection (3)
         below.

     (2) Any sound equipment which has been seized and removed by a
         constable under section 54(4) may be retained until the conclusion of
         proceedings against the person from whom it was seized for an offence
         under section 53.

     (3) The Secretary of State may make regulations--

         (a) regulating the retention and safe keeping and the disposal and
             the destruction in prescribed circumstances of vehicles; and

         (b) prescribing charges in respect of the removal, retention, disposal
             and destruction of vehicles.

      (4) Any authority shall be entitled to recover from a person from
          whom a vehicle has been seized such charges as may be prescribed in
          respect of the removal, retention, disposal and destruction of the
          vehicle by the authority.

      (5) Regulations under subsection (3) above may make different
          provisions for different classes of vehicles.

      (6) Any charges under subsection (4) above shall be recoverable as a
          simple contract debt.

      (7) Any authority having custody of vehicles under regulations under
          subsection (3) above shall be entitled to retain custody until any
          charges under subsection (43 are paid.

      (8) The power to make regulations under subsection (3) above shall be
          exercisable by statutory instrument which shall be subject to
          annulment in pursuance of a resolution of either House of Parliament.

      (9) In this section--

          "conclusion of proceedings" against a person means--

            (a) his being sentenced or otherwise dealt with for the
                offence or his acquittal;

            (b) the discontinuance of the proceedings; or

            (c) the decision not to prosecute him,

           whichever is the earlier;

           "sound equipment" has the same meaning as in section S4; and

           "vehicle" has the same meaning as in section 51.

Just got back from Buzz at San Jose Oasis and it was definitely alive.  
Plenty of house and lots of free waterrrr. The one really cool thing 
about this is the "modern" room which has no ceiling and if you squint 
real hard you can see stars past the room and city lights.  It's a great 
place to cool off after doing the house-shuffle in the main room.  Though 
the music in this "modern" room leaves a bit to be desired there is 
definitely good energy there besides all the usual club gawkers and 
scammers : Tonight I saw a guy roller-dancing around a beer bottle, it 
was insane!
There is also this group of fellows, who frequent the club, and they do this 
type of dance which I can only describe as 
slow-motion-tae-kwon-do-breakdancing, it's really fun to watch.  There 
must be a name for this technique?
Next wednesday it's Julius Papp, Doran, and Tony, so my flyer says.

On Monday I've been going to Free Life, which is at Gregg's Bar in San 
Jose on Julian and Montgomery.  It truly is Free and it's hosted by Harry 
Who and Rick Preston.  The dance floor is small but it seems to be just 
right for the amount of people as the crowd can sometimes fill the whole 
place.  Plenty of blacklights here and so far lots of sweatin' to the beats.

Oh yeah.  Friends and Family really hit the spot! I think wearing cotton 
clothes was my mistake as I could almost wring the sweat out of it and it 
never seemed to dry... gotta get some polyester, man.  Maybe one thing 
that may or may not help for the next one is somehow get ALL of the fans 
off the floor and above the crowd so the wind doesn't just die after 
hitting a few happy people's legs.  Face level wind was very pleasant 
when I could work my way to that tall fan in front, and I never felt as 
if I was hogging the breeze.  SOmehow the vibe was so intense for me I 
gave it too much and tweaked my back again.  (the first time was of 
course also from an SFR event)  I had to leave early because I pretty much 
could no longer move without crying.  It heals quickly, but when it goes, 
it really goes.

I can bring food to RADIO! RADIO! and I have a 30" x 42" drafting table 
if that's usable.

-w

Studio Electronics in Encino (818-776-8104) does midi retrofits for
Minimoogs. Expect to pay an appendage or two though, 'cause they don't
come cheap. A friend of mine was quoted $1400 several months ago for a
Midimini. I think if you supply your own Mini, you might save $200-300. =)

Good luck,
Lee

I also had a great time at Buzz in San Jose last night.  It took
a little while for iut to pit to pick up, as the whole bar crowd stand
around and play pool people outnumbered the music music people,
but the visuals were great and when they finally turned on the intellibeams
I was able to lose myself in the trance.  Free entrance, free water..
perfect beat and the occasional great acid.  To those in the
Santa Cruz/San Jose area... I redccommend it.  If anybodsy y from Santa
Cruz wants a ride next week I will most likely be there again...
that is if I can still bnreathreathe after this intense weekend coming
up.
I really regret missing Friends & Family... 
i was even right there in San Francisco but I was with loser
friends who made me drive them back to Santa Cruz so we could
watch mvideos and go to bed early.  Curses.  I'll get them to a rave
someday, although it'll probably be with the head of a shotgun or
promises of millions of dollars... Curses. again.

See y'all later...
-john.

From: mjpfister@ucdavis.edu

Subject: Re: Friends and Family, Fourth Edition

On Wed, 17 Aug 1994, Michael E. Clay wrote:
> 
> > 2).  What theme would you like?  I've had a vision of doing an ambient oriented
> >      thing in the big room, but i will be happy to provide what the consensus
> >      desires.  I can provide an ambient fix in other ways :)
> 
>  Jim and I would love to play for a more ambient oriented event. Our music
>  while it will have beats is not currently hardcore dance beat oriented - 
>  more like something approaching the softer side of the Orb.
>  Of course, I could understand if everyone wants only the "get down-go up
>  party" from the onset. Another position might be to begin the evening
>  ambient building up to an all out groove in the middle say 2:30-3:00 and
>  then to go out that way or to bring things back to Earth in the morning
>  say about 5:30. Of course, this would take a bit of coordinating between
>  the music contributors but I'm sure that's possible too.
> 
> 
If we're going to slow this one down a bit (bpms, that is), i'd be happy 
to spin some slow, trippy acid jazz and dub. It might make a good segue 
between softer ambient stuff and full-out grooves. I was hoping to spin 
this sauturday at RadioRadio, but I doubt my work schedule will allow it.

---->Marc

Subject: This Week's SF Rave Guide!
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com (SFRaves)

This weekend is good for any of you who sleep at night - an SFR picnic
in the South Bay Saturday afternoon (Larry promises name tags, so you can
actually meet your favorite SFRavers :), and Boogie Buffet is back on
Sunday.  If you don't sleep, you can find the FMR late Friday night, and
check out Futur, with some kool out-of-town DJs.  Smart shoppers' tip - the
FMR is usually free, while Futur will be $15 or $20.  Also, tonight, you 
can get some of the Futur lineup at Pure Space for $5.  Questions?

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------- UPCOMING RAVES IN THE SF/BAY AREA ---------------------
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------

Friday, August 19th - FMR - keep 'em peeled...

Saturday, August 20th - "RADIO!RADIO!"
        an SFR picnic at the Owl Burrow picnic area of Sunnyvale Baylands Park.
        DJs HDW, Laura, Harry Who?, JSL, Talizman, Deaks
        Audio augmentation via micro FM stereo transmitter. Bring your radio!
        1pm-?? (8pm?)   [directions at bottom of calendar]

Saturday, August 20th - f u t u r
        presented by Funky Tekno Tribe, Organic, NASA & Smile-E Communications
        Jeno  Graeme  DJ Dan  DJ DB  DJ Joeski  Josh Wink
        + Air Liquide [no relation to Liquid Air -dc]
        Richmond Convention Center, 9pm-8am.  $15 before midnight.
        415.266.8215  415.267.6129  408.236.3790  916.484.3727

Sunday, August 21st - Boogie Buffet
        live broun fellinis
        John Howard  Spun  Charlotte  Neon Leon  Gavan  Rick Preston  Rafael
        10am->.  $4 w/invite.  1015 Folsom, SF.  415.522.9684

Sunday, August 21st - A Groovy Summer's Day
        featuring The Greyboy All-Stars
        DJs Kevin, Kirk, Gerry V, Greyboy, James
        3pm-10pm, the Phoenix Hotel (enter Ms.Pearl's), Eddy & Larkin, SF.
        Tix at Bulletproof (629 Haight) and BPO (1504 Haight)
        415.255.7168

Saturday, September 10th - Wicked
        Jeno  Garth  Markie  Thomas
        415.512.5713

Saturday, September 24th - Friends & Family IV
        stay tooned.

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------

Here are some weeklies, in the house/techno/acid jazz/etc vein.  Some
of them may have ended - let me know when that happens...

---------------------------- T h u r s d a y --------------------------------

Your Sisters' House - 9pm discussion - 10pm-4am funkygrooves - 415-435-7575
Universal Groove - $5. 415.281.5913  510.869.2727
Lift - Digit, David Harness & guests - $5, 21+, 55 Natoma, SF - 415.267.5984
        [8/18 - Chris Lum, Rolo, Aaron O]

        journees@netcom.com  408.236.2102  415.267.6974

        [8/18 - Robert Taylor (Dallas), Jeno, DB (NASA), Josh]

        369 S 1st St, San Jose.  9:30pm-2am. 21+, $5.  408.236.3787
Flour - Dani & Mark Farina - Deco, 510 Larkin @ Turk.  21+. 415.441.4007.
        (every other Thursday)
Better Living Through Chemistry - Carlos, Dutch, Christophe & guests
        18+ w/id, $5 w/can of food, $7 w/o.  415.615.8559
Kit Kat - 6th & Harrison (the End-Up) - 21+, $5 w/invite
Soul Purpose - live acid jazz and DJs - $5, 21+, Sound Factory, 525 Harrison. 
        415.905.8811    415.882.1178
        [8/18 - greyboy allstars,
         8/25 - Moonshine/Sound Assembly, 9/1 - Mo Wax, the Federation,
         9/8 - soul kitchen, slide 5, 9/15 - mesh of Mind]

        10pm-3am, 1st & 3rd Thursday each month. 415.435.7577

---------------------------- Radio/TV Shows ---------------------------------
Sunday mornings 1-3:30am - Minor Minor KALX 90.7 (Berkeley)
Sunday evening 9-11pm - Universal radio at 89.1 FM.  Trance dance
        and power house.  Guest DJs weekly (SF & East Bay)
Sunday night 10pm-2am - Ambience w/Michael Hayes & David X  KWOD 106.5 (Sac)
Sunday night 10pm - Flux Television, Viacom Channel 47 - Progressive house, 
        acid jazz and "alternative" music views. (415) 281-3377.
Mondays midnight-2am - "The Mix Show" KWOD 106.5(Sac) - lineup 916.551.0494
Tuesdays noon-3pm - "London Jamaica" w/Unknown KZSU 90.1 (Stanford)
Fridays 9pm-midnight - Andrew from Groove Merchant spins on KUSF 90.3 (SF)
weeknights ~9pm - the Modern Mix w/Steve Masters KITS 105.3 (SF)

If anyone has info on any other events, submit them! I can't possibly hope
to get all the info every week. 

Brian Behlendorf, bbehlen@soda.berkeley.edu, and

To: sfraves@hyperreal.com, sfraves-planners@hyperreal.com
Date: Sun, 14 Aug 1994 15:54:32 -0700 (PDT)

RADIO! RADIO! - Directions to Sunnyvale Baylands Park

General notes: 

 There is a huge softball complex called Twin Creeks located right next to 
Sunnyvale Baylands Park. There should be enough signs to tell you which 
one you're at. The entrance of Sunnyvale Baylands Park is at the intersection 
of Moffet Park Drive and Caribbean Drive ; the main part of the park is at 
the southeast quadrant of the Caribbean Drive/Lawrence Expressway/
HW 237 intersection.

 Parking at Sunnyvale Baylands Park is $3.00 per vehicle. Cars are allowed
in the park until 8:30PM , the park itself closes at 9PM.

FROM THE SAN FRANCISCO PENINSULA :
First , get to HW 237 -

  HW 280 - South , past Palo Alto . Take the HW 85 exit , North to Mtn. View . 
Drive past El Camino and take the HW 237/HW101 South exit. You will then
be on HW 237 , East. 

 HW 101 - South , past Mountain View to Sunnyvale. Take the Alviso / 
Milpitas exit to HW 237 East. 

 Once on HW 237 East,  drive past Fair Oaks Ave. and take the Lawrence
Expressway/Caribbean Drive exit - choose the Caribbean Drive branch of
the exit. Stay in the right hand lane on Caribbean Drive - the park entrance 
is the first right turn as soon as you drive over HW 237.  After the toll
booth , take the right hand drive to the last picnic area , called Owl Burrow.

FROM THE EAST BAY:
>From HW 880 - Drive south on HW 880 towards San Jose and Milpitas. At
Milpitas, take the Alviso Rd./Calaveras Blvd. exit to HW 237 West . Drive
towards Mountain View and Sunnyvale . Use the Lawrence Expressway/
Caribbean Drive exit , taking the first Caribbean Drive branchoff. The
entrance to the park will be the first right turn after the on-ramp . After 
the toll booth , take the right hand drive to the last picnic area , called 
Owl Burrow.

FROM Santa Cruz:
Take HW 17/880 from Santa Cruz ,
through the mountains and hills to Los Gatos and San Jose. Take HW 280
north towards San Francisco , and take the Lawrence Expressway exit
and head north/east towards the bay on Lawrence. After driving  about 
five miles , you'll reach the HW237 overpass. Once over HW 237 , the 
park entrance is at the right. After the toll booth, take
the right hand driveway to the end , to the picnic site called Owl
Burrow.

LOCAL DIRECTIONS:
Assuming you know how to get to either Mathilda Ave. , Fair Oaks Ave. ,
Wolfe Road, or Lawrence Expressway , drive up any of them towards the 
bay.  Mathilda Ave. intersects HW 237 - take the HW 237 East exit , and
drive to the Caribbean Drive offramp. Wolf Road merges into Fair Oaks Ave ; 
take the HW 237 East exit , and use the  Caribbean Drive exit . Lawrence 
Expressway becomes Caribbean Drive at HW 237 - the entrance to the park 
will be on the right after HW 237.

Hope to see you there!
														Larry Ching/larryc@netcom.com

                                                        INTERSTELLAR OUTBACK
                                                           THE CD COMPILATION

As the FREE party Interstellar Outback in Lexington, KY (August 26-28)
approaches
I am glad to announce the availability of an important fund-raiser for the
event.

A limited edition of 1,000 Compact Discs have been pressed TO be sold with
all profits
going to pay those nasty bills that are accumulating to produce the
Interstellar Outback party.
The CDs (73 minutes) will be sold for a limited time on the net for $10 plus
$1 shipping and
for $8 at the party (so it would actually save you money to go and have a
great time!!!).
Hows that for advertising skill:)

The CD includes a 4 color insert of the flyer and a WIDE variety of music
from those artist
(both DJs and Bands) that will be attending the party.  All tracks were
recorded digitally
and they're Phat!  There is a great representation of the RAVE scene here
with everything from
HardCore, Jungle, Trance, House, Acid, and Ambient.  Do yourself a favor and
those who have
worked to hard to produce all aspects of Interstellar Outback the party and
donated their time,
money and music for the CD.  Check it out.

Thanks,
EllisD

at

tribe

At first my thanks for bringing us F&F^3. I really had a very good time.
I arrived almost at the end of Sean set but I really liked what I heard.
Hope to hear more next time. Great music also with Lee, Ethan and Galen
and all of you in the ambient room. Good to see some old friends and make
new ones. Sorry I cound't hear John and Giamma but I had a long week and I
was quite tired.

And now it's time to think abuout the next one:

> 1).  Do you want another one? Is September 24 a good date?

	Yeah!!!! (: only another one ? :) Yeah! (: soo late ? :)

> 2).  What theme would you like?  I've had a vision of doing an ambient oriented
>      thing in the big room, but i will be happy to provide what the consensus
>      desires.  I can provide an ambient fix in other ways :)

	I like the idea of an ambient big room and I agree with the others
	who proposed "more than 0 bpm" music so that it still possible to
	dance, eventually followed by some more fast trancey stuff.

> 3).  What needs to be improved for the next one?  What wasn't there that you
>      would like to experience? What was there that you want to stay for the
>      next one?

	I really liked the videos/visuals of F&FIII, so go for it.
	An ambient night could be the occasion to experiment the collective
	art, argument of last month posting. One thing could be make a new
	SFR banner or a F&F banner (I remember my first SFR party, at the 
	basement at 1015 folsom, with this big sheet hanging on a wall, under
	black lights and everybody stopping there and painting).
	Another thing, probably more complex to organize could be a "musical" 
	experiment. I'm thinking of it as people bringing their instruments
	(it can be a flute, a wistle or just a noisy toy) and making 
	"arrangement" around the music the DJ is spinning (it need to be
	amplified but probably by a second source in a "protect environment"
	(but I think the stage, on the back of the main speakers should be
	fine).

> 4).  How can you assist us?
> 5).  How can we assist you?
	I can bring an instrument mixer, my bass and some other musical toys.

... 37 days left to FFIV (but only one to Radio! Radio! :)

Ciao,
	Raffaele

"RADIO! RADIO!"  -  Final Status Report on the SFRaves Picnic in 
 Sunnyvale Baylands Park

 Since most of you can only read your email at work , this will be the last
status report you get before the picnic ( unless I think of something
else ).  New items are at the beginning of this message , general points are 
repeated in the middle. I have some slightly improved directions to the park 
at the end .
    Larry Ching / larryc@netcom.com

-----------------------------------------------------------------------
New Items:

Closing DJ -  There may be a DJ for the 7PM to 8PM time slot - DJ Loren! No 
certain confirmation yet , but it looks good. I think he'll be the only non-
mailist DJ on Saturday. Many of you have heard him spin at MOTION and 
other events.

Food and Drink - Three people have volunteered to bring some extra food and
drink - thanks! I think most folks will be bringing their own food and drink - 
don't forget that we have a barbecue pit with a 20" x 70" grill. ( Actually ,
we have two pits , but since one is upwind of the DJ ... ) . By the way ,no 
offers  to bring charcoal yet - anybody?

Boozy Drink - Only alcoholic beverages allowed are beer and wine , and even 
then only in the Owl Burrow picnic area.

Park Stuff - 
 I forgot to mention - no pets allowed in the park. 
 There's always been a constant breeze blowing through the park in the 
afternoons that I've been there - if you've got a kite , bring it!
 Bring that sun blocker !

What's Yer Tag? - My wife Mary has designed a RADIO! RADIO! name badge that
we're going to laserprint on big tags - And Raffaele has got button blanks for
your decoration! So , bring those markers and get to it!

Setup - If anyone wants to help with setup , you're welcome! Setup will 
 start at12 noon .

-----------------------------------------------------------------------
General Notes: 

 Time: 1pm to ?? (8pm?)   .
 Audio augmentation via micro FM stereo transmitter. Bring your FM stereo 
   portable radio!
 DJs Bryce, Laura, Harry Who?, JSL, Talizman, Deaks, and maybe Loren.
 Ice cream and sherbert for the kids ( leftovers for the adults! )

----------------------------------------------------------------------

RADIO! RADIO! - Directions to Sunnyvale Baylands Park

 There is a huge softball complex called Twin Creeks located right next to 
Sunnyvale Baylands Park. There should be enough signs to tell you which 
one you're at. The entrance of Sunnyvale Baylands Park is at the intersection 
of Moffet Park Drive and Caribbean Drive ; the main part of the park is at 
the southeast quadrant of the Caribbean Drive/Lawrence Expressway/
HW 237 intersection.

 Parking at Sunnyvale Baylands Park is $3.00 per vehicle. Cars are allowed
in the park until 8:30PM , the park itself closes at 9PM.

FROM THE SAN FRANCISCO PENINSULA :
First , get to HW 237 -

  HW 280 - South , past Palo Alto . Take the HW 85 exit , North to Mtn. View . 
Drive past El Camino and take the HW 237/HW101 South exit. You will then
be on HW 237 , East. 

 HW 101 - South , past Mountain View to Sunnyvale. Take the Alviso / 
Milpitas exit to HW 237 East. 

 Once on HW 237 East,  drive past Fair Oaks Ave. and take the Lawrence
Expressway/Caribbean Drive exit - choose the Caribbean Drive branch of
the exit. Stay in the right hand lane on Caribbean Drive - the park entrance 
is the first right turn as soon as you drive over HW 237.  After the toll
booth , take the right hand drive to the last picnic area , called Owl Burrow.

FROM THE EAST BAY:
 From HW 880 - Drive south on HW 880 towards San Jose and Milpitas. At
Milpitas, take the Alviso Rd./Calaveras Blvd. exit to HW 237 West . Drive
towards Mountain View and Sunnyvale . Use the Lawrence Expressway/
Caribbean Drive exit , taking the first Caribbean Drive branchoff. The
entrance to the park will be the first right turn after the on-ramp . After 
the toll booth , take the right hand drive to the last picnic area , called 
Owl Burrow.

FROM SANTA CRUZ:
 Take HW 17/880 from Santa Cruz , through the mountains and hills to 
Los Gatos and San Jose. Take HW 280 north towards San Francisco , and 
take the Lawrence Expressway exit and head north/east towards the bay 
on Lawrence. After driving  about five miles , you'll reach the HW237 
overpass. Once over HW 237 , the park entrance is at the right. After the 
toll booth, take the right hand driveway to the end , to the picnic site 
called  Owl Burrow.

LOCAL DIRECTIONS:
 Assuming you know how to get to either Mathilda Ave. , Fair Oaks Ave. ,
Wolfe Road, or Lawrence Expressway , drive up any of them towards the 
bay.  
 Mathilda Ave. intersects HW 237 - take the HW 237 East exit , and
exit HW 237 at the Caribbean Drive offramp. 
 Wolf Road merges into Fair Oaks Ave ; take the HW 237 East exit , and use 
the Caribbean Drive exit . If you miss the entrance to HW 237 from Fair Oaks , 
take any right hand turn after you drive over HW 237 - you'll intersect 
Caribbean Drive. Turn right onto Caribbean Drive , and continue to Sunnyvale 
Baylands Park.
 Lawrence Expressway becomes Caribbean Drive at HW 237 - the entrance to 
the park will be on the right after HW 237.

Hope to see you there!
														Larry Ching/larryc@netcom.com

Date: Fri, 19 Aug 1994 20:17:58 -0400
From: e boy <u8x@access.digex.net>
To: Multiple recipients of list NE-RAVES <NE-RAVES@umdd.umd.edu>
Subject: mtv

hi all,
an intersting thing happened wednesday that i wanted to get some feedback on.

we drove to new york to pick up the emerald forest fliers, and stopped by
kier's house to show here what they looked like and to give her some.  we
were chillin for a while talking about the party and the question came up
about media coverage of the event.  she's doing a lot of interviews with
some of the more underground dance zines and she's been talking about the
"emrald forest moonrise gathering" in the interviews.  as it turns out,
there a lot of
people interested in coming to the event, and possibly doing some type of
feature story about it.  for us, it's an odd thing, and while unappealing
in many ways, still tantalizing for the international recognition that
this event would receive.  anyway, i think if mixmag, or djtimes, or
project x, or vibe, or urb wanted to do some type of story we probably
wouldn't have a problem with that.

however, that's not the funny thing.  what is is that kier got a call
from mtv, and they not only wanted to cover the event, they offered
promotion as in they would hype it up on the station prior to the party.

after about 5 seconds of thought, we all agreed that our answer would be
no.  so we told mtv in a nice way that they weren't invited.  i'm just
wondering what anyone might think of that decision...

as a side note, our policy for any jounalistic coverage would be
absolutely no
lighting is allowed at our parties other then what we provide
so there won't be any flash
camera's going off, or any film crews obnoxiously lighting up the dance
floor.

do you think the zine coverages would be cool?

any zines we should or shouldn't allow?

lonnie

(just wanting a bunch of $.02's to add up to a $10.00 decision
     we don't feel this should be just our call)

Greetings!

I have several things to pass on:

1)  There is a majordomo list on ultima.org specifically devoted to 
    discussion of this topic.  please feel free to subscribe, or get 
    more info:  majordomo@ultima.org, contents: help. the list is called
    oyster-gate :)

2)  each citation is, i assume US$270: mine was issued for this amount.

3) this is, IMNSHO, an outrageous fine, way out of line for the essentially
   victimless "crime" it was

4) a copy of relevant portions of the cited ordinance is available via
   anonymous ftp from ultima.org, directory pub/Oyster.Bay.Info

5) those wishing to appear in court must do so before September 19, 1994;
   however, you need not appear in Hayward, per the ordinance

6) this citation is for a misdemeanor, not a "mere" traffic-type ticket.
   although i am not entirely sure of the consequences of misdemeanors vs.
  "tickets" vs. felonies, i suspect it leaves a more permanent record than
  a generic parking ticket. the information mailed out to us does not 
  mention this fact :(
--

I really like this. It doesn't forbid reporting or picture taking,
just forbids that truly annoying bright light in your face, which can
be a BIG vibe killer under certain circumstances. Besides, anyone who
goes to the trouble of using a sensitive video camera or high speed
film will get a truer representation of what it's really like. Not to
mention possible consequences of having a conservative employer
watching you dance, soaked in sweat, with that trance look on your
face...

> Hey, I realize this isn't rave related, but this is big news..
> Take a look at http://marketplace.com/0/tia/tiahome.html
> A new program to multiplex SLIP over regular dialup account lines..
> 
> -Chris.
> 
	There is a package, called term (or term114/term115 or what is the
	latest version), that run in the same way and is public domain. 
	I'm using it under Linux, so I can run Mosaic on a standard dialup 
	connection or I can have multiple shells. I think it is installed 
	on netcom, but I'm using a private copy newer than what they have.
	The major drawback (but I think it is the same with this TIA tool)
	is that it run on Unixes only, so you have to have a Unix (or Linux,
	or whatever else is around) box. You get the sources and you find 
	binaries for Mosaic modified for term for some platforms (so you don't
	need to have the Motif libraries). 

	If you need more informations or you want to install it and need some
	help, feel free to drop me a mail.

Ciao,
	Raffaele

From: csc@pilot.njin.net (Sean Casey)
Message-Id: <9408200850.AA05152@pilot.njin.net>
To: brycer@ultima.org (Bryce Ryan)
Cc: oyster-gate@ultima.org, sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Liquid Leo citations
In-Reply-To: <m0qbjnZ-0005pbC@ultima.org>
References: <m0qbjnZ-0005pbC@ultima.org>
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

You might want to call the prosecutor's office and talk to them about
it. The "average" fine (that issued by the judge) could be a lot less
than the pre-pay, i.e. the judge may typically sentence such cases
lightly. Also find out court costs.

Someone very reasonable might also want to discuss it with the
prosecutor or judge and see if it can be dismissed. If there actually
was no sign (drive there during the day and take pictures -- even if
there is one it may not be very visible or visible at night), then
paint yourself as a bunch of people just looking for a place to play
music and dance without bothering anyone. Point out there was no
alcohol, no drugs, no litter (indeed you had trash bags and left the
place cleaner than when you found it), no destruction, no violence, no
graffiti, and otherwise nothing socially disturbing. Also offer to
pass the word around (like at places where one gets flyers) that there
is a curfew at that space and it should not be used.  You were acting
in good faith and thought you had found a place for your little
gathering where they could be outdoors (for free) without disturbing
anyone.  If you appear utterly responsible and regretful perhaps you
will get a token fine.  Someone who knows the judge better might be
able to tell you that.

You might also find out if there is a statute that requires curfews to
be clearly posted at parks and such. If so, and they weren't, your
lawyer could get all the tickets dismissed.

Suggestions:

-- See if there is a lawyer on the list, or a lawyer friend of someone
   on the list who might take the case pro-bono. They could spend one
   court date representing everyone.

-- If worst comes to worst, we might try raising some funds to help
   pay off the tickets. At around $5800 for the lot of you, that's
   pretty ambitious, but you might get enough to help a little.

-- At the very least, get some addresses...councilpeople, mayor,
   whatever, and we can start a letter writing campaign about the
   unfairness.

-- Character witnesses? Some very respectable people could testify
   that Liquid * parties are extremely responsible and that they don't
   believe you'd have been there if there had been a sign or any other
   reason to believe the land was off-limits after dark.

More ideas if I come up with them. I'll pledge $50 to a fund if it
comes to that.

Sean

From sfraves-owner  Sat Aug 20 03:46:20 1994

From: laura@taz.hyperreal.com (Laura La Gassa)
Date: Sat, 20 Aug 1994 03:46:17 PST
X-Mailer: Mail User's Shell (7.1.1 5/02/90)
To: oyster-gate@ultima.org, sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: oyster-gate / what to do?
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

I'm extremely upset by this, even more so because I wasn't there
with you all when it happened.  In fact, I'm wide awake now
writing this because I can't sleep from thinking about it.

I'm thinking that this whole thing is on par with what happened
two Halloween's ago with GRAVE in Minneapolis.  The party was
busted and every one of the several hundred people there was
charged with something like aiding and abetting the sale of
alcohol in an unlicensed establishment.  The fines were very
high, maybe $600 per person.  The final result was that the entire
case was dismised.

One of the first things that was done was that someone found a 
lawywer willing to represent the entire group.  The first thing
the lawyer did was tell everyone NOT to pay the fine in advance.
The lawyer had each person request an individual trial, that they 
NOT be processed as a group, and when the City of Minneapolis realized 
what a zoo that would be they droppped everything.

Failing that kind of approach, I'm wondering if the fine could
be reduced to something like $25 per person.  I spent a day in
traffic court watching people get their several-hundred dollar
speeding tickets reduced SUBSTANTIALLY.  A large number of people
at Liquid Leo are students and cannot afford the cruel and unusual
fine of $270, maybe the judge would take pity.

I feel so sick at heart about all this.  If it comes down to it I
will donate $270 to a fund to help people (especially the students)
pay their fines; but I don't think you all should just roll over and
pay up without trying to get things dropped or reduced first.

Laura

	id LAA14578; Sat, 20 Aug 1994 11:13:43 -0700
From: howard@netcom.com (Howard Berkey)

Subject: Re: SLIP without SLIP account!!
To: ccat@netcom.com (Chris Beaumont)
Date: Sat, 20 Aug 1994 11:13:43 -0700 (PDT)
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
In-Reply-To: <199408192317.QAA17880@netcom16.netcom.com> from "Chris Beaumont" at Aug 19, 94 04:17:37 pm
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL23]
MIME-Version: 1.0

Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Chris Beaumont sez:
> 
> Hey, I realize this isn't rave related, but this is big news..
> 
> Take a look at http://marketplace.com/0/tia/tiahome.html
> 
> A new program to multiplex SLIP over regular dialup account lines..
> 


I've been using tia for a couple days now, and for the most part I'm
impressed.  These guys will make tons of (well deserved) money.  It's
25 bucks per license, which is very affordable considering how much
the typical SLIP account costs at most sites (many have hourly rates).

It took me about an hour to set up (ordering is instantaneous w/ a
credit card... you download the SW from their site).  It requires
TCP/IP (of course) and some kind of SLIP software (I use InterSLIP
from InterCon).

There are a few drawbacks... Some software will not work with it (See
U See Me, for example), and netcom users cannot use it to read news
(netcom has some kind of facist policy of denying access to their nntp
server to people with lowly shell accounts... not a problem if you
have access to another nntp server), and I have yet to get eudora to
work quite right.  Prolly my fault.  Mosaic, fetch, Anarchie, and
others all work fine.

It's definantly worth checking out... in addition to the URL Chris
posted, you can telnet to marketplace.com to order.

I'd say it's definantly worth the $25, even after just trying it for 3
days or so.

-H-



-- 
:::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::
Howard Berkey                                             howard@netcom.com

BIG HUGE amounts of applause to Larry and Mary Ching for their
efforts organizing a stellar picnic.  The day was gorgeous, the
site was perfect except for a bit too much wind, the people were
great (it was really nice to see people like Jim and to meet his
wife Barbie and their new baby), the music was way nifty, and the
food was yummy!  And Raffaele's new SFR buttons were beautiful!  

My only regret is that I forgot to bring Georgina.  She would have
liked it. :-).  We *might* get out to Futur tonight, but I'm a
bit tired from being in the sun.  I remembered to put on sunblock,
but Brian is red as a lobster.

Score:  well-organized daytime picnics 10, falling in the poison oak
	in Santa Cruz 0  :-) ;-)

GO GO GO SFR . . . that friendly family feeling is really building!

Laura

> But without making this too pointed, Ken, once again you're presupposing
> and it's fairly apparent it would be helpful for you actually to *hear*
> some of this stuff?  Second best, to hear some tapes, I'd gladly dub a
> couple for you to give you the idea.
> 
> Jeno is from England.

Just for balance, I should point out that the phrase Ken used was also 
used in Ethan's post about how Friends and Family parties will always 
have one or two new DJ's in the lineup.

I think many of us have itchy trigger fingers these days.

	Brian

Just a pointer to the oyster-gate list . . . if you were at the party
and are concerned about the $270 fine and misdemeanor charge, please
get yourself on the oyster-gate list as that is where developments
will be posted first.

To subscribe -- mail majordomo@ultima.org and put

subscribe oyster-gate 

in the body of the message.

Thanks to Phred we are close to having either a lawyer or a contact for
a laywer.  I strongly suggest that you do not rush out to pay your fines
or arrange for time off for the court date until the lawyer has been
consulted.  There are several courses of action that could be taken; but
paying off the fine right away will be only admitting defeat when it could
be the case that the fine will be eliminated or reduced.  You might have
to end up going to court, but then again you might not -- it's too early
to tell right now without consulting with the laywer.

So please just hang tight and get yourself on the oyster-gate list to
stay abreast of the situation.

Laura

	Would it be inappropriate for me to make a partially
philsophical and partially commercial statement here? If so I
apologize.

Philosophy: Netcom has 30,000 users now. In my opinion that is *too
huge*. Net providers should be small and decentralized, serving their
local community, with a number of users that they can handle.  One of
the great things about the net is that it is decentralized. Tiny
providers all over can just start up and people can get connected
through a system in their own town. A system with a few dozen machines
in San Jose and POPs all over the country is so much like America
Online and Compu$erve that in my opinion it is antithetical to the
"spirit of the net".
	The fact that netcom is so huge is causing many these problems.
SunOS wasn't really meant for 30,000 users, really.

Commercial: There are those of us who are setting up small community
oriented public access net sites. I have set one up in Berkeley, I
think Bryce has set one up or is in the process of setting one up in
San Francisco.. We're offering network access for cheaper and in a
more personalized way than the giants, netcom, crl, etc.

	I urge you to support your local providers, who can provide
you network access with personalized service and a commitment to the
community that they are serving.

-- 
sameer						Voice:   510-841-2014
Network Administrator				Pager:	 510-321-1014
Community ConneXion: The NEXUS-Berkeley		Dialin:  510-549-1383
http://www.c2.org (or login as "guest")			sameer@c2.org

RADIO! RADIO!  -  Post Picnic Report

 Well , I liked it - of course , I may be biased. 

 Bryce beat me to the site , with half of his equipment unloaded when I got
there. Raffaele , and then Willis Wong , showed up to help with the setup.

 Thanks to all the folks who came and shared and danced. It was great to 
see so many new and old faces - I wish that I had talked to everyone. 

 The FM stereo transmitter didn't work out as well as I'd hoped - I'll need 
to design a signal pre-processer and a better antenna to cut down on the
noise & distortion. Also , maybe another frequency than the one shared by 
a Portugese radio station in Gilroy.

 Thanks to all the DJs! Bryce , Laura , Ernie Deaks , John S. Lee/JSL , Harry
Who , Talizman , and Loren. My apologies for not getting the second tarp 
up sooner - if we ever do that site again , blocking that strong afternoon
breeze will have to be planned for. Also , for next time - a sound level 
meter to help track the volume level to park ranger specifications. 

 It was definitely a learning experience for me - I'll be posting something 
on the planners list about what I could have done , or could have done better.
The one big mistake I made was forgetting to ensure a back-up sound system
in case Bryce had an unfortunate accident!

 Great weather , a bothersome but not totally mean parker ranger , and 
good people!

Larry " Want some ice cream? We got LOTS!!! " Ching  / larryc@netcom.com


From sfraves-owner  Sun Aug 21 23:31:26 1994
Return-Path: owner-sfraves
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.9/8.6.5) id XAA12121; Sun, 21 Aug 1994 23:31:26 -0700
Received: from mail02.prod.aol.net by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.9/8.6.5) with SMTP id XAA12115; Sun, 21 Aug 1994 23:31:22 -0700
From: RobertJ308@aol.com
Received: by mail02.prod.aol.net
	(1.38.193.5/16.2) id AA27174; Mon, 22 Aug 1994 02:30:57 -0400
X-Mailer: America Online Mailer
Message-Id: <9408220230.tn58766@aol.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Date: Mon, 22 Aug 94 02:30:55 EDT
Subject: If this is the Futur.....
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

I must at first admit that I expected something different from Futur, but
Futur is what I got.  I thought I was going to hear the East Coast dj's of
Acid House and Progressive House music. NOT!!!! 
Instead, Joey, & DB played industrial grade 145bpm + plus Hardcore. Since
this was my first, I guess I am measuring my response to it, by my experience
of dancing to it. Joey blasted off like a runaway subway train on speed.
Instead of dancing into a body gro0ve I found myself furiously trying to keep
up with the beat.

 Not unlike my experience of dancing to Ska music this summer in Tahoe. Maybe
frenzy is the wished for psychic state? Could someone tell me if this music
is driven more by speed than X? 

While Josh Wink did play some House, it wasn't until Jeno began at 4:00am,
did I think that the party began. At 4, the entire vibe of the party changed.
Fresh replacements, many SFravers, lee and janie, Craig, Peter and a few
other notables appeared out of nowhere. I did go to the party to hear Jeno
play a massive sound sytem, and I wasn't disappointed.

 By comparison, I noticed that Jeno plays with and to the crowd. The music
rising and falling organically, my heart rate rising and lowering.  Dancing
to it creates waves of exhilaration and trance. The hardcore was faster than
a speeding bullet, never varying speed, once began.

Certainly ,the sound and light show was among the best of the summer's
parties, and the dancers also added to the visuals. Am I just cynical in
thinking that the hardcore I heard is just headbanger heavy metal gone disco?
Did I miss something here?  ........ Robertj...........Monterey

> i don't have my notice with me at the moment, but as i recall it said that
> you'd _still_ pay the fine before you go to court (which is a trial by
> judge only) & you'd get it refunded if found not guilty.
> we're going to request a month's extension (& maybe keep doing that as long
> as we can get away with it).

from my court experience, if you set a court date and plead not guilty, 
you pay the fine as bail...

the wierd thing is that if you plead "guilty with an explanation"
you dont have to pay the fine until you go to court

this creates an interesting situation becuase the officer
does not have to show up, but the judge can still let you off
this was in traffic court and i dont know what different options might be 
available for this situation, BUT chances are you
have to pay before and then get a refund

Its kinda cute how you're innocent until proven guilty,
but you not only have to lend the government money
until they say you are not guilty
but you have to lose money/time by going to court
just because you are innocent

i just wonder how many people have "proved their guilt"
because they couldnt take time off work
or it would cost them more money to do so
or simply lack of transportation

i dunno.. the words "drowning" and "witch trials"
seem to come to mind




 ,
dana

"You know, the last person I met with a tie-dyed shirt tucked into
their pants with a belt on was a Drug Enforcement Agent.
I just thought I would let you know that."

Robert sez:
>it wasn't until Jeno began at 4:00am,
>did I think that the party began. At 4, the entire vibe of the >party
changed.
Yeah it did.

>By comparison, I noticed that Jeno plays with and to the >crowd. The music
rising and falling organically, my heart rate >rising and lowering.  Dancing
to it creates waves of >exhilaration and trance. The hardcore was faster than
>a speeding bullet, never varying speed, once began.

OK, so it was your dependable Jeno set, but it did it for me.  I really tried
to dance to the other DJs slammin sets but I just couldn't get going and I
really like hardcore - it's killer on the pumpin' car stereo at night at 90+
mph or at home in that immobile, at-one-with-the-couch state of mind.
 Fortunately, Richmond civic center gives you the option of a great balcony
view of the whole show(and show it was but that's why I went.)  I *really*
enjoyed watching the Lasers, dancers, etc. and nodding my head to some really
amazing 150 bpm choons - a nice balance of relaxation/stimulation.  The
work-out from Jeno was way too short and left me hungry for more.  Couldn't
talk anyone into driving me to Sunset and I didn't feel capable even with a
couple of double mochas in me.  Anyone else in Marin want to carpool once in
a while?  

DinDaaDaa, DinDohDoh.... :-) 




From sfraves-owner  Mon Aug 22 11:48:41 1994
Return-Path: owner-sfraves
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.9/8.6.5) id LAA20556; Mon, 22 Aug 1994 11:48:41 -0700
Received: from ns.PacBell.COM by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.9/8.6.5) with SMTP id LAA20548; Mon, 22 Aug 1994 11:48:32 -0700
Received: from srv.PacBell.COM (mother.srv.PacBell.COM) by ns.PacBell.COM (4.1/PacBell-07/19/94)
	id AA10007; Mon, 22 Aug 94 11:48:28 PDT
Received: from pbssi.srv.PacBell.COM by srv.PacBell.COM (4.1/SMI-4.0)
	id AA18911; Mon, 22 Aug 94 11:48:27 PDT
Received: from lizard.srv.PacBell.COM by pbssi.srv.PacBell.COM (4.1/SMI-4.1)
	id AA13771; Mon, 22 Aug 94 11:48:26 PDT
Date: Mon, 22 Aug 94 11:48:26 PDT
From: lxfogel@srv.PacBell.COM (Lee Fogel)
Message-Id: <9408221848.AA13771@pbssi.srv.PacBell.COM>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: weekend report
Cc: jlf3@mofo.com, lxfogel@srv.PacBell.COM
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

We had a pretty good time at Future.  A high tech production, but not
overly cheesed in commercialism; excellent visuals, sound and assorted 
extras like exotic dancers and a firebreather.  The main feature of this 
party was the out-of-town DJs and live techno bands.  Most of the nite 
featured music that was harder and faster than anything we ever get at the 
mainstream parties around here.  When we arrived (2am), DJ DB was spinning 
an eclectic high energy set that thoroughly entertained me. It was also my 
first taste of a DJ who does the MC thing with a microphone.  I've never 
depended on a DJ screaming in my face to inspire me to dance, but the 
crowd seemed to react positively to it, and it didn't detract too much from 
some great spinning.

The heat of the main room and the high bpms wasn't Janie's cup of tea, so
we spent a lot of time in the alternative space located near the front
entrance.  It was kind of an inconsistant atmosphere there; ambient DJs 
alternating between the hard acid trance of the live bands.  For $25, I 
would have liked to have seen one of the side rooms opened as a real chill 
space.  Of the live acts, Air Liquide was the only one that impressed me.  
The ambient (with beats = soft trance?) sets were very good however.

Overall Future was a good party.  The vibe was pretty good, not exactly a
love-in, but lot's of enthusiasm and happy faces.  

The Sun, Moon, & Stars:

I have to say that by far, Sunset has been my favorite regular party this
summer.  Great sound, great DJing, great vibe, great scenery, beautiful
setting, free/donation, easy access (4 me) and completely legal.  This time 
we got to hear Tracy spin a truly wonderful set, along with the regulars 
Galen & Solar whom we have loved week after week.  Mark (Ameba) had every 
right to be proud of his mate's performance, and his grin was so wide as he 
pranced around to it that I thought his head was going to split in two. <:-D

The setting was extra spectacular this week - a red/orange/purple dusk
covering one half of the sky, and a huge glowing full moon and emerging 
stars taking command of the other.  At the top of the hill, the 360 degree 
view was breathtaking.  At the party`s peak there were about 200 people, 
half of them dancing.  The park setting is so great for chilling and 
socializing.  I was reminded of the days of the weekly GG Park parties at 
Marx Meadows where people saw each other's smiles and got to interact.  The 
Sunset parties seem even warmer and friendlier than those were, and they 
last so much longer too, from 2 to 9:30.  It's great to see the breakdown 
of cliques and the happy interactions between ravers, local families, dogs, 
kids, kites, bubbles...  Things generally start to take off at around 5-6, 
peaking at sunset (surprise!) and staying strong until the end.  

Even though we had no sleep the nite before and the music was a bit more
laid back than at Future, being outdoors made us feel so much more alive 
that we *really* danced our asses off.  Galen, the who heads the "Pacific"
group that puts these on is yet another hero of the noncommercial SF Bay
Area house scene.  They are planning an extra long Sunset party for Labor 
Day weekend, and a nighttime rave in a month or so.  
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
Lee Fogel/\/\/\/\/\Everything/\Is/\Possible/\/\/\/\/\lxfogel@srv.pacbell.com
____________________________________________________________________________

	Well Future was exactely what I had expected music-wise.  Didn't
	really enjoy being worn out by deadly fast beat with no groove.  I
	was too worn out to stay and hear any of Jeno, we were just leaving
	and it did seem like the music was picking up.

	I enjoyed meeting all the new faces there (Matt, Michelle, Milton, and
Nina).
	I would like to say the groove and the vibe between everyone was great
	and I had tons of fun talking with the groups of people.

	I only hope that in the "futur" that the music will be more in synch
with the
	crowd.  In addition I did not take to kindly to paying $25 to get into
	the place after I waited 45 minutes to get in.  Was it my imagination
	or did that line start moving only after they started charging $25.

Date: Mon, 22 Aug 1994 13:34:20 -0700
Message-Id: <199408222034.NAA29241@am.ucsc.edu>
To: ren@nin.engr.sgi.com, sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: amaranth@cats.ucsc.edu (Kia)
Subject: Re: If this is the Futur.....
Cc: amaranth@cats.ucsc.edu
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Personally, I thought Futur was great.. I got in at around 9 pm (only paid
$15 and didn't wait in line for the security check for more than about 15
minutes) and was very impressed by the setup, even though the acoustics 
were a lot less than perfect (the reverb off the auditorium walls gave it
that "school gym" feeling).. Being a worshipper of the 303, I LOVED the
stuff being spun (who was that British guy?  I thought he was incredible..)
and most of the people around *me* seemed to really be enjoying it.  I 
hardly left the dance floor before heading for home at around 8 am.  

When the music was over, someone (I'm assuming it was the promoter) got up on
stage and thanked everyone, "including those guys who flew out from texas",
whom John (swoosh@cats.ucsc.edu) and I had picked up at the airport earlier
that day.. (Hi Chris and Mike!)  --for those who don't know, Mike was the
one who could do some *pretty* cool things with lightsticks.. :)

The visuals were intense -- absolutely spectacular - lasers, really trippy 
projections, and colored light effects really made the show (although 
I wanna kill the person who decided every three seconds was a good time 
to turn on the fog machine - cough, cough).  It was cool running into 
more sfravers (some of whose names I've forgotten.. I met sooo many people on
Saturday!) :) and especially ucsc ravers (like Matt!)  They even had this
weird floor show thing going on on a platform in the center of the dance
floor -- dancers covered in mirrors and glow in the dark things.. I could
never quite figure that out.  

The space-cheerleader quotient was high, as well as a lot of *young* 
people - I met a lot of 14, 15, and 16 year olds there (not that I should
talk, I just turned 18 last month). :)  I thought the vibe was really 
good, though, and it was definitely one of the best events I've been to 
all summer.  A lot of people came a long way for it, too (I ran into some 
people I went to high school with in Santa Barbara).  I was a little
disappointed to be the only sfravergurlinablacksprtsbra there though.
(Shame on you, susie and laura, you hawdcoah gurls!), but it was definitely
worth EVERY second (and every dollar I paid.. I feel sorry for whoever gets
to clean the women's bathrooms today).

k

   the amaranth family) of coarse herbs of various forms cultivated for
   their showy flowers 3: a dark reddish purple

based on how much money is in your checking account.  and they won't even

blink of an eye.  it's so painless.

From sfraves-owner  Mon Aug 22 14:37:42 1994

Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.9/8.6.5) id OAA23226; Mon, 22 Aug 1994 14:37:42 -0700
Received: from ultima.org by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.9/8.6.5) with SMTP id OAA23215; Mon, 22 Aug 1994 14:37:38 -0700
Received: by ultima.org  (Linux Smail3.1.28.1 #1) id m0qcgzr-0005qcC; Mon, 22 Aug 94 14:33 PDT
Message-Id: <m0qcgzr-0005qcC@ultima.org>
From: brycer@ultima.org (Bryce Ryan)
Subject: F&F^4
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Date: Mon, 22 Aug 1994 14:33:39 -0700 (PDT)
Cc: liquid@ultima.org, sfraves-planners@ultima.org
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL23]
Content-Type: text
Content-Length: 2399      
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Thanks to everyone who responded to my informal poll concerning Friends
and Family Four.  I tried to repond to you each individually, but got
lost during the past 4-5 days.  My apologies.  I did read each piece of
email carefully...and taken your comments to part.

So far, nearly 25 people have written in response.  The rate of response
has tailed off substantially since the weekend, so i'm taking it that most
everyone who wants to respond /has/ responded.  If not, please forward your
reply to me soon, so that it can guide me early on in the preparations.

The overwhelming response was that Saturday, September 24th was a fine date,
and that folks did want to have a party then.  I've spoken with the folks
at Komotion, and the date is confirmed, so we are all set there.

The primary concern of almost every response was the heat and humidity.
Both ethan and i have spoken with the folks at komotion, and they are very
aware of the problem, and want to help.  They have offered a number of 
suggestions, including doing the work up front and having our parties pay
back their investment, and alternately, gathering the money from the parties,
and having it done when there's enough money.  One kind person from the list
has offered to front some money...thanks, you know who you are.  Needless
to say, I will be talking with Matt, Judge, and other people from the
collective, and i will get back to you with the plan we agree on.  Thanks
again for your help!

The consensus was not so clear on the format of music for the big room
during the next party.  Quite a number of people were in favor of all
ambient, a number said that any format would be ok, one person suggested
that if we were to do all ambient that we should change the name, since
folks had an expectation of an F&F as hot and sweaty dance music, and
several others suggested varying the music from ambient to dub to dance
and back down to ambient over the course of the night.  A couple of folks
requested all dance like we have had for past Friends and Families.  It
would seem that diversity is the safest course :)  I will attempt to 
provide something to please as many folks as I can.  Thanks again for
your suggestions!

Well, that's it for the report so far.  If you have further comments,
please send them along by the end of this week!
-- 
----Bryce Ryan------------AMBIANCE-----------------brycer@ultima.org-------

In keeping with the continuing spirit of Friends and Family, the SFRaves
and community party, I'm calling on the list to help provide the talent
(musical, visual, and other) to help produce the next Friends and Family
party, which will be held near the Autumnal Equinox, on Saturday, September
24th, 1994.  Preference will be given to list people, and we will try to
invite at least one person from outside the list to share their talents
with us, and we will also try to debut at least one person in the big 
room.  

A number of you have already expressed an interest in performing.  Thanks
for your requests...no need to repeat them, i have them in a folder.  If you
haven't sent me (brycer@ultima.org) a note that you're interested in playing
for this one, please do so by the end of the week.  As I mentioned in my
prior post, the format will be diverse in the big room and probably in the
hallway as well.  Note that we also have only 10-12 slots available, so I 
may not be able to schedule everyone who is interested for this event...sorry.
Also, for you musical folks, if i haven't heard you play, i would like to
hear a tape...this is in keeping with ethan's request for the last party.

Thanks again for all your help, and for helping make these such great parties!
-- 
----Bryce Ryan------------AMBIANCE-----------------brycer@ultima.org-------

Date: Mon, 22 Aug 94 15:53:21 -0700
From: swoosh@ucscb.UCSC.EDU (John Elias Darrow)
Message-Id: <9408222253.AA15924@ucscb.UCSC.EDU>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject:  The futur was intense.
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Well, seeing as how I was one of  happy people near
amaranth (Kia, Kristin) and also being a 303 fiend, I
thoroughly enjoyed the extreme acid and intensity of the
night.  The light show was simply incredible, with the spheres
and transformations  going on in the Triangular
screen.  Powerful sound that did the severity of the music justice.
Yes, it wore you down fast and blitzed a traditional nice/peace vibe,
but experiencing that extreme was just amazing for me.  Absolutely
worth the $15 I paid to get in.  I guess a lot of people didn't
get to see how it built up, but I really liked the choreography of
the evening.  They started off much more mellow, with almost no lights,
and then started picking things up, sending off a powerful series of
strobes and a wash of color every now and then, and only began
introducing things like the lasers after an hour or more, and then
finally got to things like the video and craziness well after the music
had just built itself  up to the hardcore state it was around midnight
when the England guy came on.  And Josh Wink was just great.
So, I guess it just depends on your immediate crowd and mood,
and energy... which I had enough of to go straight until the
end, although I was moving much more slowly for the final twisted
da dum dum da doh doh... but... all in all one of the best
parties I've experienced.  It was intense but felt so good.
I personally, can't wait for another one, after at least a month or
two to rest my aching limbs.

And  everyone I met was just in the b                                             yup...  *grin*
-john.

Also:  I got to host two ravers from Texas who flew in for this event.
Chris and Mike had a good dtimetime, and I'm not sure exactly how the promoter
heard about them, but it was nice of him to thank them for coming at
the end.  Being as exhausted as we were afterwards, they weren't
quite up enough to continue raving Sundayu, so I ended up dropping them
back off at the airport, where they were able to move their tickets
home from Monday to Sunday./    Mike did have a really cool thing
going on with his glo-sticks, if any of you sawa him.

From: laura@taz.hyperreal.com (Laura La Gassa)
Date: Mon, 22 Aug 1994 19:17:26 PST
In-Reply-To: RobertJ308@aol.com
       "If this is the Futur....." (Aug 22,  2:30am)
X-Mailer: Mail User's Shell (7.1.1 5/02/90)
To: RobertJ308@aol.com, sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Re: If this is the Futur.....
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

I'm really suprised to hear about the fast tendencies of Josh Wink and Joeski.
When I left the East Coast last winter, Wink was playing groovy tribal stuff
and Joeski was spinning progressive house.

On the other side of the coin, if you think 145 bpm is fast . . . heh heh heh.
I start my sets around 140 and work up to about 160 . . . and it's not hardcore
I'm playing either :-)

No, I would not say the music is fueled by "speed" or "X" or whatever . . . there's
just a strong lingering influence of the Dutch and German hardcore scenes, but
I thought that was (sadly) dying out based on the reports I was getting from
friends back East.

I am wondering if the East Coast people played fast stuff because they were asked
to by the promoters?

I would not accuse the East Coast DJs of ignoring the crowd -- I've had to play
"on spec" before and it can really kill your desire to put out a good set.  I've
heard of one other party where Beltram was told to play the hard stuff, and he
was bumming because he really wasn't in the mood at all.  A side note to this

oh, never mind the side note, my editor is messed up.

Anyway, I've had some amazingly great times tranced out to blistering hardcore.
Most slower bouncier happier housier stuff puts me to sleep unless it's heavy
on "them acid noizes."  hee hee. 

Now, as for "real" hardcore (as opposed to the fast trance that a lot of peole
out here who don't have a steady diet of 140bpm+ music) goes, that started dying
as an art form a while ago in my not so humble opinion.  I started out spinning
the hardest of the hard -- 160bpm and distored 909's were my lifeline.  For a
short while in the spring of 1993 I was finding lots of good records in that
genre.  But then suddenly it all dropped off and I developed other interests.  
My point is that yeah, I could really see it degenerating into a cross between
speed metal and disco.  It's funny in a cheezy way -- Bryce's set at Liquid Drain-O
is a prime example - we were all laughing and dancing and waving our hands in the
air -- but I think the genre was just too narrowly defined to remain viable for very
long.

Well, enough babbling.  Sorry for the sentences that don't make sense, I have to
get out of my mailer and fiddle with the environment variables for my editor for
a while.

Laura (a little nostalgic for the days of Storm Rave in Brooklyn :-) )

breeze, food to share, very colorful SFR buttons, some bubbly babies, a

and just go "wowwwww!!"...

Subject: future + sunset
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com

Both these events left me feeling I had a nice, well-rounded weekend.

The music at future was fast.  At one point I could not believe how fast it
was.  But even more unbelievable was that I was keeping up with it.  I 
payed for this, not having enough energy to fully enjoy Jeno's sets.  The
Richmond convention center is a great place for Very Large Events.  It 
reminded me of the Shrine in LA.  The vibe was pretty cool.  People really
seemed to be into dancing and having fun.  My 15 dollars was well spent
on previously mentioned visuals.  With all the fog, you could sit up
on the balconies and look down on a truly heavenly 'scape.  I couldn't
imagine heaven being any more visually appealing. 

Sunset was also great.  I really, really enjoyed Tracy's spinning.  I hope
she becomes a regular at sunset.  Her soulful, housey, funk set made up 
for the colder trance sets spun by white males at Futur.

Sunset is held at the most incredible place in the Bay.  You get a full view
of the Bay bridge, the Golden Gate, Downtown, Berkeley and Oakland.
simply wonderful, wonderful.

-troy

We went to Futur and had a pretty good time.  The lights were incredible,
the music was fast and hard.

The chill space kinda sucked, though...esp. compared to a Gathering I went
to a while back that was also held at the Richmond Civic Center.  At that
one, a side room had been opened up and there were lots of mats on the
floor where people could lie down for the true chill experience.  At Futur,
the main lobby was the so-called ambient room, a bad place because of the
traffic.  People looked like they were enjoying themselves, however.  There
were some parachutes overhead that softened the decor somewhat, but nothging
on the floor to soften that!

Also, the entry price of $25 was way too much.  

The Sunset party at the Marina, however, was great, as usual.  Tracy & Solar
both did great sets...I got there when Solar was playing.  The full moon
rising over the hill was incredible!

I'm glad to hear that Galen is maybe going to start doing nighttime parties.
He really has his sh*t together.  I probably should say that _Pacific_
has its sh*t together, because there's more people involved than just G.
, I'm sure!

Anyway, I loved the housey sounds of Sunday!  I am way too wimpy for hard-
coah!

feeling very satisfied,

annthrax


(no relation to the band)

Well, this is my first post, I've been reading for a couple of weeks and
thought I should say hi. I live in Santa Cruz and have for 23 years, I've
been spinning for the last 6 years and raving for the last 2 and a half. I
have a small system that i wouldn't mind sharing/using somewhere. As yet I
have not spun a rave/party, but I've been spinning house for along time and
thought it was time to come out of the closet so to speak. I've also got some
lighting equipment. I look forward to meeting you all, and mail me if you can
use my services or if i can help set something up.
 I've heard a lot of people post about the "small party in Santa Cruz" that
happens on Fridays. It's called the Sweat Box (It does get hot as hell!) and
i thought you folks might want better directions. Take Hwy 17 and stay on it.
At the first light take a right, That's Hwy 9/River St. Go up 3 streets to
Encinal, take a left on Encinal. Take your first right and your first right
again. That's it, really easy. It's the last Warehouse on the right, Really
hot, good vibe, good music, i was told it will be happening this Friday (Aug.
26th) and then they are moving to a better location. Usually 5 bucks, or
donations. If you went last week, I'm the guy who showed up with all the
lights.
 Last thing, I'm headed to Oregon on the 25th (Portland) till the 31st.
Anybody know of anything going on up that way?
 Thanks, 
   Taylor

 Make sure the noise your making is worthy of the silence your breaking.
