> based on how much money is in your checking account.  and they won't
even > need to see your atm card, because we will all have barcodes
permanently > cemented to our foreheads, so they can just access your
account in the > blink of an eye.  it's so painless. 
--------------

ben franklin said something to the effect that "people who are willing
to trade a little liberty for a little security deserve neither".  i'll
also wager that they'll *get* neither, any takers?

i've seen alot in the media in the last few years about how americans
are increasingly willing to give up personal and civil liberties in order
"to be protected" WRT to hysteria over crime and drugs, and yet i've also
heard that both crime and drug use have been slowly but quite steadily
*decreasing* over a period of several years (don't remember the *exact*
#'s, but you get the idea).  what does this imply?  why would people's
willingness to give up freedom for protection from crime & drugs increase
when both are actually *decreasing*?!?!?   what is giving people the 
perception that they *ought* to trade valuable things like liberty for
a decreasing threat?

anyone have any insight on how these issues relate to the *crime bill*
just passed in the house of rep's?  how does this relate to the concept
and availablility of privacy?  TAZ's?  drugs?  what's the "big picture"?

*

obRave:  any forecasts for together?

> "You know, the last person I met with a tie-dyed shirt tucked into
> their pants with a belt on was a Drug Enforcement Agent.
> I just thought I would let you know that."
-----------------

my wife and i were eating in a favorite breakfast joint on haight
st in the city and these 2 middle aged guys in tie dye's sat down next
to us.  the minute they sat down, i had a feeling that there was something
*unusual* about them, they just weren't *at home w/ themselves* or something,
and as the meal progressed we eventually realized they were agents.  i
could be wrong, but i'd bet 500.00 on it any day of the week.  oh, i've
seen *plenty* of middle aged guys in tie dye, my dad included, but these
guys were a treat.  after a while we started baiting them, which was a 
gas.  even if these guys weren't narc's, there was something so 
frightfully insincere about them that it was almost like theatre, real
amusing.  anyone got any ideas for anti-security security?  while we all
know that things like operation dead-end (DEA's attempt to rid SF of
acid, starting w/ the deadheads) are going on around us, at raves, dead
shows, walking down the street on haight st. etc., we never talk about it.
i find that a little wierd, it's not like doing so is incriminating (so
i'm going way out of my way here, in case you hadn't noticed).  anyone
got any good/funny/scary/what-a-joke narc stories?  let's pry the lid
off this sucker...

in this age of crime bills, lack of respect for the constitution and bill
of rights and so on, what can a true freedom loving raver do to protect 
his (fleeting?) liberty?  a whole pack 'o ravers?

*

Tenderloin Waxx writes:

 > in this age of crime bills, lack of respect for the constitution
 > and bill of rights and so on, what can a true freedom loving raver
 > do to protect his (fleeting?) liberty?  a whole pack 'o ravers?

A few things:

To protect yourself, know your rights and defend them vigorously. Know
how to deal with law enforcement.

To improve the situation, there's a million groups working towards
reform. They could use your help. Sew seeds. Be a buffer between the
rave community and non-ravers you know.

And don't forget to enjoy what you *do* have. 

Sean

Doesn't the DEA have a WWW home page or something? :-) I know that they have
a magazine/newsletter available at well-stocked libraries.  It's certainly
interesting reading with lots of statistics and bust stories.  There have
been several articles in national magazines about the LSD crackdown usually
detailing that one young deadhead's now well-known plight - his girlfriend
turned out to be an excellent and dedicated publicist.  Most of these
articles point out the DEA policy change and subsequent Dead attack was
instigated by one person!  Prior to this guy's appointment a few years ago,
the DEA did not conduct investigations to uncover LSD operations, only making
busts on a 'if we run in to it' basis.   Just goes to show what a difference
one person can make. He said something like,"We've hit a vein, and we're
going to mine it till it runs out." nice guy.

  The Grand Canyon mega rave is on and looking great.    Authorities such
as park rangers and police are cool and laying back.    Several hundred
are already on site which is a stunning fabulous forest with lots of
trees.

  Bring a gallon of water per person per day,  it is dry and hot during
the day against dehydration for 3-4 days.   World Unity festival started
on Monday till Saturday evening.

Directions:   Kaibob National forest, Mt Kendrick.    Exit on the Parks
exit coming in on the 14 Rt  from the west.   Turn left at the T junction
of the ramp,  turn right at the gas station on Spring Valley Rd.   At the
junction with 144 road go straight on until the next junction turn left
onto the 90 rt then there will be rangers and sign posts.   180 is not
such a good route.

Info number:  415-679-1238

See U all there..

CC


From sfraves-owner  Tue Aug 23 19:13:32 1994
Return-Path: owner-sfraves
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.9/8.6.5) id TAA13603; Tue, 23 Aug 1994 19:13:32 -0700
Received: from cats.ucsc.edu by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.9/8.6.5) with ESMTP id TAA13585; Tue, 23 Aug 1994 19:12:56 -0700
Received: from si.UCSC.EDU by cats.ucsc.edu with SMTP
	id TAA22253; Tue, 23 Aug 1994 19:11:41 -0700
Received: by si.UCSC.EDU (8.6.9/4.7) id TAA15870; Tue, 23 Aug 1994 19:11:36 -0700
Date: Tue, 23 Aug 1994 19:11:36 -0700 (PDT)
From: Tony V Garcia <deepfog@cats.ucsc.edu>
Subject: A LARGE soap box on the drug war
To: SuperDuperRavers <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
cc: Me <deepfog@cats.ucsc.edu>
Message-ID: <Pine.3.89.9408231951.A15692-0100000@si.UCSC.EDU>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


The war on drugs is a front that keeps us from dealing with the real
issues in government.  Some of the real issues are that this country is
not taking care of its people.  Spending on prisons and incarceration have
gone up, while spending for education has slowly but surely decreased. 
DoesnUt anyone see that if everyone doesnUt have an equal opportunity to
grow and change through education that many of them end up turning to
crime or become a burden off the welfare system, to name just a few
avenues?  Social welfare has gone down steadily in the past 20 years, and
the people that suffer are the poor.  By not dealing with this problem, we
are strangling ourselves as a country.  Instead of locking people up for
doing drugs, why not educate them about the proper use and show them the
possible consequences of abuse? 


One really bad side effect about this stupid war on drugs is the minimum
sentencing bit.  I donUt know how many of you have seen 48 hrs with the
kid who is going to jail for 10 YEARS for selling a sheet of acid.  So we
are filling our prisons with nonviolent people like RRonS I think was his
name, and we are paying $40,000 per year to have a prison guard to guard
him.  For that price we could PAY for all of RonUs college tuition for 3
years.  But instead we are going to pay $400,000 dollars (plus benefits)
to keep Ron locked up in prison, where there is definitely not a good
chance for him to grow.  Someone who goes to college often puts back what
they were given simply by being self sufficient and not being a burden on
society, if they are in prison, they are simply taking up space.  It is
like a snowball effect, because the less we spend on education, mark my
words, the more society will degenerate, and we will feel the need to
build more prisons and give up more of our civil rights to capture these
RcriminalsS, most of which are non-violent and do not belong in prison in
the first place. 

Last night on KGO radio (810 am) Bernie Ward (10pm-2am) had a female
caller whose husband is serving a 4-year term for possession of marijuana. 
She has 2 kids, I believe,and is now trying to support herself and also
send her husband money in jail.  According to this caller, 80% of the
people in this particular prison are serving time for the same types of
crimes:  possession of drugs.  Now what the **** do I care about these
people carrying drugs?  Do we really have to fill up our prisons with
these people?  The prisons are so full it is no wonder to me that some of
the violent offenders kind of Rslip through the cracksS.  And who asked my
permission to build these prisons and pay guards and wardens salaries to
do absolutely nothing but sit on their behinds and watch the prisoners
age? 

ThatUs all for now.  Of course thereUs always dessert...
---deepfog

From: brycer@ultima.org (Bryce Ryan)
Subject: Oyster Bay: Initial Legal Consultation
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com, oyster-gate@ultima.org
Date: Tue, 23 Aug 1994 23:37:30 -0700 (PDT)

Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Greetings!

I had a conversation with Bob Felvidge this evening, who we were referred
to indirectly by a friend of Fred's (thanks so much, Fred!).  Bob has worked
on at least one similar case involving a group of bike messengers in San 
Francisco, and has some familiarity with the East Bay judiciary. 

Bob and I spent some time discussing what I knew about the citations.  We
then went on to discuss some strategies, and possibilities concerning the
citations.

Because of the public nature of these lists, I would prefer that people
who were issued these citations get together to discuss these matters
relatively soon, in person.  I propose a meeting at my house in the
next few days, let's say Friday night.  Please email me privately for
directions and what not.  

Also, Bob has requested the following factual information to help in
his preparation of a case (should we decide to engage his services):

1)  a copy of the entire ordinance
2)  a list of names, addresses and phone numbers of everyone who was cited
3)  a copy of the front and back of a few citations, plus a copy of the
    material mailed by the Alameda County court system.  At the very least,
    he needs a citation written by the second officer...mine was written
    by Badge Number 85.  

I will take care of Item 1.

If you were cited, and will consider participating in this effort, please
send me your contact info as soon as possible.  I will keep this information
in confidence, as will Bob, i'm sure.  If you prefer not to send this
information via email, perhaps you can come to the in person meeting, and
give me the information then.

I am willing to do quite a bit of legwork on this.  If it is most convenient
to meet you somewhere to obtain a copy of the citation and supporting materials,
i'll do it.  If you'd like to contact me by phone, my business number is
415.642.9791

Ideally, we'd like to get this information together by the end of the week,
so we can make a decision, and proceed apace.  It would be best if we can
obtain some contact information about /everyone/ who was cited, to obtain
the broadest array of facts, and present as unified a strategy as possible.

Thank you all for your time and patience.
-- 
----Bryce Ryan------------AMBIANCE-----------------brycer@ultima.org-------

Tonight was definitely in my top-5 most memorable evenings spent at 1015. 
(Keeping in mind that I work the main dance floor lights virtually EVERY 
Friday and Saturday, all night, and have for the past two years...that's 
pretty remarkable!)   I'm really feeling sad to lose this experience for 
the future. 


Here are people doing a club FOR THE PARTICIPANTS...not 
their money!!! (This was evidenced their charging NOT ONE DOLLAR for 
admission, even though there was a truly magnificent performance by 
DubTribe.   I didn't hear even a hint of dissent, except for the lack of 
opportunities to be Together again. 

*Bravo!!!!!* to all involved in this production.  Please come do us again 
soon!


                             	 Kerry
				 Lighting Operator/Programmer/Tech
				 club 1015

in general if anyone offers INTERNET access services? Or knows of a
good INTERNET access service?

 Info needed:
 1) Monthly charge.
 2) Charge for memory usage.
 3) Other usage charges.
 4) Assuming the basic services ( email , newsgroups , ftp , telnet ),
    what other special services are available?
 5) Telephone area code(s)? ( I live in Sunnyvale , in the South Bay,
    so a service that's only in the 415 area is a toll call. However ,
    others may be interested , and I may be logging in from another 
    location other than the 408 area ).
 6) General opinion of the access provider ( please let me know if
    you're the owner or an employee !  :-)  )

and post the resulting summary to sfraves/sfraves-planners.

>  Given the recent discussion about NETCOM , I'd like to ask the list
> in general if anyone offers INTERNET access services? Or knows of a

Ok, I'm just going to post this because it's a fair deal:

The Duck Pond Public Unix
(408) 249-9630
4 lines, 14.4k modems
$10/month for 5 megs storage per day
$15/month for 10 megs storage per day
email, uucp, ftp, telnet, archie, lynx

There's no time limit per session, but you figure with 4 lines and 
currently 40 users, one should be curteous.  The sysadmin is fair and is 
always working on the system.  Just recently he upgraded modems and added 
a hunt group so you only need to dial one number.  Also newly installed 
is the lynx www browser and the pine mail program.  I've been on Quack 
for several months now and think it's a real good deal.  To get on you 
just dial up and login as "guest" for info, or you can  
http://quack.kfu.com to the home page.

-willis
walrus@quack.kfu.com

In reply to a recent inquiry by Ken Stuart:
> Just as an inquiry  (ie I am NOT advocating anything in particular) --
> Is there any sort of policy or community_agreement on whether or not it is 
> ethical to post <event>information to sfraves that is " word of mouth only 
> ; just tell your friends " ?
> ( Perhaps it depends on your definitions / interpretations ? )
> respect to all,
> Ken    

 "Ethical" ? That's a heavy word - I'll pass on commenting weither an
ethical problem is involved.

 Dealing with a purely speculative , imaginary case - let's say someone
was holding a party , and they wanted to limit attendance for some
reason - maybe the site of the party is too small for a large crowd ,
maybe the party is supposed to be for the his friends and aquaintences
he's met in SFRaves , as well as other friends he knows. Then , this
fellow would be in his rights to request some limitation on the folks who
know about his party. That's my opinion. There's a difference between
a public party and a private party.

 Even public parties may want to limit the maximum size of the crowd , 
forsite and human comfort purposes, and other reasons. ( The FMR , for
 example ).

 For a can of worms - why use the term "ethical"? Ken , please expand
on this term in your inquiry. 

 Larry Ching/larryc@netcom.com

Well I guess I should ponie up :)


	InterNex Information Services (of which I am part owner) offers
	SLIP/PPP access into the Internet via ISDN.  

	WE DO NOT OFFER SHELL ACCOUNTS BUT...  

	What other service provider can offer you Mosaic on your Mac or
	PC at 112kbps?  Basically we connect your MAC or PC directly to
	the Internet, you have your own domain name and receive mail
	directly to you home or company machine.  With the new
	residential ISDN tarrifs in effect you have unlimited calling
	between the hours of 5 pm and 8 am, it is $.01 per minute at
	other times.  Our rates start at $29/month (first 30 hours
	connect time included) and $2/hr above that.  The lowest cost
	ISDN board for a PC is around $500, this let's you connect at
	56 kbps. On the high end, and ascend router (smaller than a
	modem) cost arount $1500, but you get 112kbps and can hook up
	up to 254 different machines on your side, you could even run
	your own community ISP. This is the type of connection that
	nexsys.net (my home machine) has.  Starting in October, we will
	be offering frame-relay (dedicated 56k and above) connections.
	In addition to myself (Director of Network Operations) we have
	other ravers working here also.  If you want more info send a
	mail message to:

	info@internex.net

	or just email me.  

	SFravers who sign-up through me between now and September 15
	will get the first month of Internex' fees waived.
	(That's $29 + what ever you use for the first month)
	 (You have to e-mail me first to get this deal !)

From: csc@pilot.njin.net (Sean Casey)
Message-Id: <9408251652.AA17953@pilot.njin.net>
To: <ken@snowcrest.net>
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Word of Mouth
In-Reply-To: <17037.ken@mtshasta.snowcrest.net>
References: <17037.ken@mtshasta.snowcrest.net>
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Posting to sfraves is posting to a rather public place. One can ask
for discretion, but it's like putting flyers somewhere and asking for
discretion.

There have been some rumblings that law enforcement subscribes to this
list. Another thing to consider. Personally, I'd consider it unwise to
post complete directions to any renegade or break-in on here.  The
longer a location is known, the more coordination law enforcement can
make with other jurisdictions, etc. And one may not only jeapordize
their party, they may jeapordize all future parties. (For a fine
example, look at how the FMR folks have ruined more than one site for
all parties.)

I don't mind telling people how to thwart the law, because I feel law
enforcement has much better things to do than go around breaking up
parties. I.e. get a life, fight some crime.

Sean

To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Re: Word of Mouth
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Hey, Ken!

I think it really depends on the source. If you 
know the people/person who are/is hosting 
said event, then just ask them/him/her- would it be OK 
to post the info to SFRaves? If the event is to be held 
at an "illegal" site, or in a place where the police 
may very well make their presence felt, then give it 
lots of extra consideration before posting the info. 

Conversely, you could offer to send the info 
upon request; i.e., you tell the list you have some 
word of mouth info about an event, that you're hesitant to 
post it to the list, etc...., but that if someone's 
interested, then he/she should mail you personally for the info.
It's usually good to supply some teasers here, like a DJ list 
or general locale- say, Santa Cruz County or East Bay, etc...


Take care-

Jocelyn

I stocked up on invites at Mushroom Jazz and Together this week, so
now there's plenty of listings for your party needs.  Mushroom Jazz
is incredibly crowded nowadays, and Together has retired in to the
SFR Hall of Fame after over a year.  I can't think of a whole lot of 
weeklies which lasted over a year - Housing Project, Boogie Buffet,
Osmosis (?), Spundae, Mushroom Jazz, Carefree (?), Deep Space (?) - 
any others?

Thanks to all who sent info this week...

Date: Thu, 25 Aug 1994 14:35:38 -0500
To: nrg@netcom.com, brycer@ultima.org (Bryce Ryan)
From: komotion@netcom.com (Komotion International)
Subject: ACHTUNG! You are not permitted...
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Hi, folks. As some of you may already have heard, Komotion was paid a visit
this morning by a member of the S.F. Fire Department. He cited numerous
fire code violations at the space and seems intent on shutting down
Komotion's live music and house parties indefinitely.

The fire marshal, one Lt. A.S. Armanda, apparently came in response to a
complaint from a patron of one of our recent events, claiming that the
building appeared to be unsafe. Although no one has come forward as the
complainant, it seems most likely that the call was made by someone at
Friends & Family 3, as that was the most heavily attended event at Komotion
in months.

At this point, we are calling an emergency meeting TONIGHT (Thursday) at 6
p.m. at the Komotion collective warehouse at 2779 16th Street (at Folsom).
Sfraves list members and anyone with an interest in or experience with
these issues are especially encouraged to attend.

As for the immediate implications of this information, it seems quite
likely that F&F IV is on hold until further notice.

Komotion has had a long and tenuous relationship with police and fire
authorities in its eight-year history. Visits from fire marshals are
nothing new, but with this visit the SFFD appears to have escalated its
threats. The marshal indicated that if we continue to produce in events
with an occupancy in excess of 49 PEOPLE, he will personally issue $270
citations to everyone in attendance.

I seem to recall that this $270-per-person allegation has come up before in
the SF rave community. I apologize for not reading or archiving this list
more carefully--Komotion just joined a couple of weeks ago--but I remember
seeing the "A $270 Party" thread. If anyone has any info or advice that
might be helpful, please your getting in touch and/or coming to our
meeting.

Lastly, on the off chance that the mysterious individual who made the
complaint to the authorities is a reader of this list, we would REALLY like
to hear from you and better understand your concerns. Your actions have
placed eight years of organizing of music and dance in jeopardy. Do you
really feel that unsafe?


En solidarite,

Judge @ Komotion





              Komotion International  2779 16th St at Folsom
          Magazine/Performance Space/Art Gallery/Recording Studio
           Tel 415-861-6423 Fax 415-431-6523 komotion@netcom.com
             Send stuff to; P.O. Box 410502,S.F.,CA 94141-0502
                              * B E C A U S E *

Boy, somedays you just can't get people to show up, and others you get
so many the gesta^H^H^H^H^Hfire marshall's office becomes involved.

Perhaps someone was genuinely concerned for the safety of the
attendees. Perhaps other motives are involved. If I were a competing
promoter and worried about losing $15-$20 a head to an F&F party,
complaining to the fire marshall would be a brilliant move.

Not that I know what really happened. Except maybe not enough payola
to grease the officials. Always comes down to money, doesn't it? Can't
even throw free parties anymore, because someone with a desk isn't
getting their cut.

SpaceHunt '94 resumes...

Sean

Subject: the future in space
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


	Spaces will always come and always go.
	There will always be new ones we are excited about and
	old ones we are tired of.

	The constant shifting of spaces keeps us on our toes
	and keeps the scene alive.

	The Engineers at the Blue Cube are currently designing
	the Cubic Acoustic Transparancy system which will distribute
	sound throughout the public Blue Cube areas with minimal
	leakage to the outer world. We also have acquired a high power
	industrial rackmount blower which will be used as an exhaust fan
	to both serve as a dithering engine for outside noise and as a
	ventillator for the inside.

Seems to me that you should be able to find out the specific nature of
the complaint, if not the name of the complainant.  In most places
(certainly in Portland) you can work things out with the Fire Marshal
assigned to your area if you address things in a businesslike way and
give them some room to maneuver and satisfy the requirements of their
bureaucracies.  If you have one who's simply got it in for you, nothing
you do will satisfy them and you should plan now to follow an appeals
route.  

I don't feel that F&F3 was run in an unsafe manner, mostly because 
I had complete confidence in the ability of those running the event to
deal with any problems that developed, both our crew and the Komotion
staff on hand.  I think you can advance with confidence knowing that
is your situation.

Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

"Fred Heutte" writes:
 > If the Space Engineers of the Blue Cube *really* want to impress us,
 > perhaps they will think about the Digital Noise Cancellation System
 > which will rocket them into heroic orbit in the mythos of the world
 > rave community!

I've looked into this in depth, and unfortunately it's just too
difficult. To make it work, one would have to generate phase inverted
sound waves in a dispersion pattern that exactly matches that of the
sound leaving the house. If the dispersion pattern doesn't match
exactly, the interference causes the waves to cancel at some
locations and add up at others. At some locations it will be quiet,
and others it will be louder what than one started with.

It works with headphones because one is working with a small area
where the the sound dispersion is easy to duplicate. It's much easier
to cancel sound coming in than sound going out. 

One possibility might be to couple subwoofers to the walls and use
them to cancel the shake caused by the music. I don't know what it
might do for the acoustics inside, but it might reduce the amount of
bass transmitted outside. Wonder if it's been tried?

Just imagine if one could do it. Total stealth parties :).

Sean

Part of the problem is the fact that certain parts of the government are
getting paid to *deal* drugs, while other parts are getting paid to lock
users and dealers up.  There is an enormous subculture in the intelligence
and policing agencies involved in the trafficking of hard drugs, especially
cocaine (bush and is buddy Oliver North were apparently raking  in the cash
to fund their adventures in central America...



> years.  But instead we are going to pay $400,000 dollars (plus benefits)
> to keep Ron locked up in prison, where there is definitely not a good
> chance for him to grow.  Someone who goes to college often puts back what
> they were given simply by being self sufficient and not being a burden on
> society, if they are in prison, they are simply taking up space.  It is
> like a snowball effect, because the less we spend on education, mark my
> words, the more society will degenerate, and we will feel the need to
> build more prisons and give up more of our civil rights to capture these
> RcriminalsS, most of which are non-violent and do not belong in prison in
> the first place. 
---------------------------------

I heard the prison "industry" was the fastest growing "industry" in
California, so I think the point is that certain folks in the "prison
industry" want a cut of that 400,000.00!!  Like you said it's all
about money and these people want money more than they want you to
keep your rights.  Whether America survives or not (IMHO) in the long
term depends on whether we can pry these people's cold dead fingers
from the reins of power and it ain't going to be easy...

"The muscle of the Catholic Church--when backed by the police--has also 
been felt on the streets, as Ira Sandler, owner of the popular gay 
nightclub 1015 folsom, knows well.  Catholic Charities had submitted a 
plan to put up low-income housing next to the club, and when Sandler 
officially complained this year, fearing there would be too many 
conflicts with the residents, a police offical declared at a public 
meeeting that he was going to shut down the club.

Rennie.

From sfraves-owner  Fri Aug 26 14:52:57 1994

From: csc@pilot.njin.net (Sean Casey)
Message-Id: <9408262151.AA14610@pilot.njin.net>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Re: A LARGE soap box on the drug war
In-Reply-To: <Pine.3.89.9408261139.A16913-0100000@netcom>
References: <Pine.3.89.9408231951.A15692-0100000@si.UCSC.EDU>
	<Pine.3.89.9408261139.A16913-0100000@netcom>
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Since hate, fear, finger pointing, and denial of responsibility are so
deeply engrained in our society, I don't think the basic ideological changes
needed are going to come for hundreds of years at least. There are
groups with sound reasoning, but they are outnumbered by our fast
breeding spoon fed philosophy majority.

What we will probably see is relief in the form of practiciality. When
1 out of 5 people are in prison, the economics of the thing will start
to become apparent to even the most thick-headed. When people's share
of the enforcement burden gets painful enough, they'll press for
reform.

Thus reform will be driven essentially by evolution, and not
enlightened choice (the cold war was a good example). I don't think it
will take *that* long though, as people are already starting to feel
the crunch.

A friend of mine, a psychobiology major, said it well when writing to
a university administrator who had been applying pressure on him for 
providing educational drug information:

    "... tried to convince me of the brainwashed misinformation that
    alcohol (for example) is inherently "better" than marijuana (for
    example) simply BECAUSE IT IS LEGAL. I'm sorry, but legal
    scheduling is irrelevant to the laws of chemistry and
    pharmacology. Criminalizing something doesn't make it a poison and
    legalizing it doesn't make it good for you. I find it hard to
    believe that, were caffeine criminalized tomorrow, the University
    would take the position that it's a terrible drug that destroys
    lives and kills millions of people each year. However, that seems
    to be the brainwashed, propagandized position taken by so many
    people against other drugs based solely on the fact that they've
    received an illicit status."
                                  
So hang in there, and keep yelling. My biggest suggestion to people
fed up with the way things are: Find ways to communicate your ideas
effectively. Doing it online is a good start. Since most people aren't
online, find ways to reach them too.

For those people distributing information at raves, keep it up. I am
finding that a lot of people actually read and remember the
information. It's working!

Sean

On Fri, 26 Aug 1994, Susan R. Kameny wrote:
> also what about oliver stone conspiracy theory #666 that the Irish 
> Republican Army sells e to support their cause *religious/homeland*

There's actually a lot more to that story.  I think there's a thread 
about this on alt.drugs right now.  Baseline being that for the first 
time in a couple of years, the quality of Ecstasy in Northern Ireland 
clubs is very high, and this has been leading to much more peaceful 
coexistance and lowered tensions in the area.  The IRA has been linked to 
the rise in supply, to the point of strong-arm tactics to chase the bunk E 
dealers out of the Irish clubs.

	Brian



From sfraves-owner  Fri Aug 26 18:26:23 1994

X-Sender: komotion@localhost
Mime-Version: 1.0

Date: Fri, 26 Aug 1994 18:26:10 -0500
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: komotion@netcom.com (Komotion International)
Subject: Komotion Update (Re: ACHTUNG! You are not permitted...)
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Hello again, sfraves. Thanks to all list members who have sent suggestions
and messages of support as we sort through this mess.

First a clarification: so far, no one at Komotion has been cited for any
code violations. At the time of Lieutenant Armada's visit on Thursday
morning, the space was empty. Hence, no public assembly was taking place,
and no violation was actually witnessed.

The inspector did make quite clear, however, that in his opinion, Komotion
is unsafe for public assemblies of ANY shape or size, and cited specific
requirements which must be met before lawful gatherings can take place:

   -- chemical flameproofing of all curtains, carpets, acoustical tiles or
      other flammable materials hanging from the walls;

   -- a thorough clearing out of debris from doorways, corners, bathrooms and   
      the adjacent alley which serves as a fire exit;

   -- acquisition of new trash cans equipped with lids, and made of some
      non-combustible material;

   -- overhaul of all electrical wiring, including the entire sound and
      lighting system, to be supervised by a licensed electrician;

As soon as these basic conditions are met, we can schedule a re-inspection
of the facility by Lt. Armada himself, at which point our right to public
assembly will be reconsidered. In the meantime, we are expressly forbidden
from booking shows, parties, readings or gatherings of any kind.

For the most part, these are basic housekeeping concerns, certainly long
overdue, and as such we do not dispute them. (Some of it sounds a little
weird - like the wall hanging business - but still easily accommodated). We
expect to have most of the major renovation done within the next couple of
days, albeit at some expense. An electrician friend-of-a-friend has agreed
to sign off on the wire repairs. In addition to the trash pickup, we've
decided to repaint the entire building, in order to give the space more of
a clean, orderly appearance.

Of more serious concern is the inspector's estimate of the maximum legal
occupancy for the building. Armada indicated that even after the above
repairs are completed, we are still only authorized to produce events with
an attendance of 49 PERSONS OR LESS. This figure is the bare minimum for
meeting halls, parties in private homes, and other gatherings not requiring
a permit.

If enforced, this limit would spell death for rave/house parties at
Komotion, as well as make it nearly impossible for us to pay our rent as a
benefit promoter booking six to eight events for month.

At this point, our next step has been to consult an lawyer to clarify our
rights and responsibilities. We have made an appointment through S.F.
Lawyer Referral with an attorney specializing in building and fire codes.
With his help, we may be able to ascertain the basic modifications
necessary to get our occupancy raised to at least 99--still a bit tight,
but a significant improvement. Till then, all our future events, including
F&F IV and YSH, are on hold.

We realize that to some of you, Komotion may be just another room to rave.
To us and our supporters, it is a unique and vital non-profit community
resource serving artists and activists of all colors and persuasions. Some
of us have invested much of our adult lives in building a music and dance
environment that inspires, informs and breaks down borders.

Well, that's the news. Once again, we at Komotion would like to thank
everyone in the sfraves community, and the Friends & Family crew in
particular, for everything they've done to make this relationship work. I
hope we'll get the chance to work together again in the future.

One more thing. After rereading my original "ACHTUNG!" post in light of
comments made by Marty (MVasey@eworld.com), I want to apologize to anyone
who may have been put off by the tone of that message. If my words seemed
to assign some sort of "blame" on sfr for recent events, the effect was
wholly unintentional. We do not wish to alienate you or anyone else.
Sfraves and Friends & Family have introduced us to a new and vibrant
subculture full of good people, positive energy and much to teach us all.
Let's hope we can keep it going.


En solidarite,

judge @ komotion



              Komotion International  2779 16th St at Folsom
          Magazine/Performance Space/Art Gallery/Recording Studio
           Tel 415-861-6423 Fax 415-431-6523 komotion@netcom.com
             Send stuff to; P.O. Box 410502,S.F.,CA 94141-0502
                              * B E C A U S E *

As I understand it, the main structural difference between us and, say, 
1015 is the lack of a rear exit. The wall behind Komotion's stage is 
right up against that of the next building; hence no room for exits.

One possible option is knocking out a doorway through the west wall that 
opens onto the adjoining alley, but that could take $$$ and our landlord 
is not obligated to pay for it...

---------- Forwarded message ----------
From: hopkins@kaleida.com (Don Hopkins)
Subject: Electric.Carnival@lollapalooza.com
Cc: void@asylum.sf.ca.us, levitt@interval.com

If you're going to Lollapalooza, be sure to check out the Electric Carnival!
It's the big white tent in the Shoreline Ampitheater parking lot with blue
red and yellow dots on it, like a bag of Wonder Bread.  Not only is it 
professionally air conditioned, with its own set of industrial strength
diesel generators, but it's also packed full of hands-on interactive media!
It's really a big experiment sponsored by Paul Allen's Interval Research,
that's touring around with the concert. They've put together a whole bunch of
interactive exhibits, with facilitators to help people use them, and they're
video taping how people interact, and interviewing people to find out what
they think of the stuff. 

I'll be facilitating multi player SimCity running on an SGI Indigo and an
NCD X terminal in a couple of kiosks, which is a product I developed for X11.
As a special offer to sfrave subscribers, if you mention the name of this
mailing list, I'll show you the secret undocumented cellular automata screen
saver, which is especially good if you're on drugs, so come prepared and share! 

There's also something called the Midi Zoo, where you can see and hear Bounce,
another project I'm hacking on with David Levitt. Bounce is a visual data flow
programming language, for creating real time simulations with midi, macromind
director graphics, networking, and all kinds of esoteric i/o devices like data
gloves and convolvotrons (it was originally called "body electric", and was
developed by VPL for virtual reality programming, and David and I are
developing it into a product for implementing interactive multimedia).
Bounce is hooked up to a bunch of bizarre midi stuff like synthesizers, 
keyboards, drum pads, slider boxes, a midi controlled mixer, a vocalizer that
shifts the pitch of your voice and harmonizes in barbershop quartet, a jam man
that loops and layers sounds, and other stuff I couldn't begin to describe.
It's the big noisy mess of cables in one of the lion cages, you can't miss it. 

There will of course be a network connection, and lots of world wide webbing 
and stuff like that. I'm not supposed to give out the official web address
yet, but you might be able to guess. I've assembled some media I recorded at
the Lollapalooza show in Colorado, and some info about simcity and bounce,
which are at the following addresses: 

http://web.kaleida.com/u/hopkins/electric-carnival.html
http://web.kaleida.com/u/hopkins/midi-zoo.html
http://web.kaleida.com/u/hopkins/bounce.html
http://web.kaleida.com/u/hopkins/simcity.html
http://web.kaleida.com/u/hopkins

        -Don

PS, Yes, it's real, I'm not joking:

PPS: And here's a summary of some recent news coverage from earlier this month.
John Markov wrote a good article on it, I think. 

PAUL ALLEN'S ELECTRIC CARNIVAL
        Paul Allen, Microsoft's other co-founder, is financing a $2 million
traveling technology exhibit as part of the Lollapalooza tour.
Concert-goers can take time out to play with computerized toys that turn
their voices into alien sounds or manipulate their images digitally to see
what offspring might look like. Meanwhile, Allen's company, Interval
Research Corp., is taking notes on what attracts the sub-Generation X
crowd, seeking hints on what might be the Next Big Thing in consumer
electronics. (New York Times 8/5/94 C1)

Sean Casey wrote:

> Komotion International writes:
>
>  > For the most part, these are basic housekeeping concerns, certainly long
>  > overdue, and as such we do not dispute them. (Some of it sounds a little
>  > weird - like the wall hanging business - but still easily
>  > accommodated).
> 
> I'd guess it's the possibility of a smoker accidentally igniting a
> curtain or wall hanging. I seem to remember something like this
> starting the Beverly Hills Supper Club fire.

Yeah, you're probably right. But how do art galleries get around this? 
I've definitely been to some pretty smoky spaces with plenty of canvas 
hanging around, and I don't ever recall seeing a 'certificate of 
inflammability' hanging from anything. 

As for the curtains, they're in the main room, where smoking is not allowed.

> I do agree that the main room needs a second exit. I suppose that even
> if seriously inconvenienced, some good will come of it.

We have $500 in the bank. If done by a contractor with a permit, adding 
another exit to the main room could cost as much as $10,000. Considering 
the fact that we may not be able to have large shows until the exit is 
already in place, that money could prove very difficult to raise.

Serious inconvenience indeed. We may never know what good could 
theoretically come from such a feat.

> If any of us can help, please let us know.

Thanks. Right now we've got the painting, the flameproofing and the 
electrical work covered. We're taking down the lighting system for now, 
as it's just too messy to bring up to code. When it comes time to put in 
a new, legal one, I'm sure we could use all the help and advice we can get.


--judge

From sfraves-owner  Sat Aug 27 22:58:15 1994

Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.9/8.6.5) id WAA22497; Sat, 27 Aug 1994 22:58:15 -0700
Received: from well.sf.ca.us by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.9/8.6.5) with ESMTP id WAA22492; Sat, 27 Aug 1994 22:58:11 -0700
Received: (from phred@localhost) by well.sf.ca.us (8.6.9/8.6.9) id WAA09232; Sat, 27 Aug 1994 22:58:06 -0700
From: "Fred Heutte" <phred@well.sf.ca.us>
Message-Id: <9408272258.ZM9230@well.sf.ca.us>
Date: Sat, 27 Aug 1994 22:58:05 -0700
X-Mailer: Z-Mail (3.0.0 15dec93)
To: orbital@xmission.com, sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Snivilisation
Cc: uk-dance@tqmcomms.co.uk
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Mime-Version: 1.0
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

I picked up the vinyl double-pack today.  Looks like it has the same cuts
as the import CD (I didn't see the US release), though in a slightly
different order.  

On first listening it doesn't have any obvious "classic" tracks like Chime
or Halcyon or you-name-it, but it's worth a serious listen and is high
quality work (as always with the Hartnolls).  What I really like about
Orbital is that P&P don't merely drop their melodic ideas into different
'genres' (as listening to any random release these days with the obligatory
"radio mix," "club mix," "trance mix" and so forth shows), but they *adapt*
those genres to an overall musical conception.  Which is why it was a bit
amusing to read from some quarters that Snivilisation is 'a bit ambient'
or 'has breakbeats!' or 'is aimed at the commercial market' or various
other things I've read -- all true, to be sure, but sort of missing the
point.  

The other thing I like is that Orbital never stand still.  They could have
just relaxed into the fantastic groove they found in the 'brown album' --
surely a classic effort overall.  Snivilisation goes in all different
directions.  

c u in the future

phred

From sfraves-owner  Sun Aug 28 19:21:50 1994
Return-Path: owner-sfraves
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.9/8.6.5) id TAA10047; Sun, 28 Aug 1994 19:21:50 -0700
Received: from holonet.net by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.9/8.6.5) with ESMTP id TAA10042; Sun, 28 Aug 1994 19:21:46 -0700
Received: from localhost (dmi@localhost) by holonet.net (David M. Ilstrup)
	id TAA01843; Sun, 28 Aug 1994 19:19:24 -0700
Message-Id: <199408290219.TAA01843@holonet.net>
Subject: RE: A LARGE soap box on the drug war
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Date: Sun, 28 Aug 94 19:19:21 PDT
From: "David M. Ilstrup" <dmi@holonet.net>
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Yes Tony, I empathize with you completely.

There was a clip with Prez. Clinton speaking to a group of teenagers on TV
a few days ago. I think it was actually footage from back during the 
campaign, but the drug thing is hot in the media right now... anyway,
he said something like the following:

"You know, my brother was arrested for possession of cocaine awhile back
and he did 14 months in prison, and then went into rehab. I'm glad it happened,
because if it didn't; I'm sure he'd never have gone into rehab and he'd
probably be dead by now."

<flame on>
So what, Bill? So you've got it so together, that you can be president of the
United States, and you can't even help your own brother with his drug problem?
It's the responsibility of the police to arrest your brother, so that he can
be helped with his drug problem? Would he be dead from doing coke, or dead
from dealing with the wrong people; people he would never have seen were
the substance legal. Is jail supposed to be healthier than getting high?
<flame off>

You can see what I'm getting at.

This kind of thinking is especially scary to me, because it reminds me very
strongly of the kind of thinking I'd hear from my own and my friends' parents
when I was a teenager, and by extension perhaps reflects the thinking of a
large portion of the people that support the WOD. People are so hysterical 
about drugs, they feel like they need police to deal with their own relatives.
This is irrational panic fueled by fear of the unknown.

This is why the need for *education* about the real effects, dangers and 
potential rewards of various drugs is so great, IMHO. Knowledge tends to dispel
fear, and replace panic with rational assessment. Obviously, there *is* the
potential of negative effects of varying severity with different substances,
but if this information is made available, and a substance is available in 
known quantity and purity, the risks are minimized. Say if the FDA controlled
drugs instead of the DEA.

At least there has been some of what I would call non-hysterical presentation
of the issue recently in the media (at least on MTV, which isn't much from
the standpoint of political influence, but at least it's national media).
There still seems to be a real lack of agreement about physiological effects
from long term and casual use of various schedule 1 substances.

Anyway, I guess the point is that I don't see how drug use can be treated
as anything but a health issue. There is simply no justification for turning
it into a crime.

-dmi



From sfraves-owner  Sun Aug 28 21:43:16 1994

From: Willis Wong <walrus@quack.kfu.com>
Subject: review: HOPE ...for a brighter tomorrow
To: sfraves list <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
Message-Id: <Pine.3.89.9408282123.A23781-0100000@quack.kfu.com>

Did anyone attend this party?  I was there and had a helluva time 
spazzing out to some great music.  The space it was in was great!  Large 
ceiling warehouse with hardwood floors that really had some BOUNCE.   

Four turntables as promised, but only two being needed.  Visuals... well 
not much but I would have to say I didn't care because people were into 
the dancing thing and that made me happy. 

Lots of SPACE to move around too!  Bongo drummers in the far end for that 
boonga beat... only ONE bathroom for everyone and it was kept pretty clean
 somehow.  I found it difficult to wait in line for the bathroom while 
the "ribbit" song was going off and the crowd was going crazy.. dancing in 
line was painful yet necessary :)

An interesting thing with this setup was the main speakers were placed 
far away from the dj.  Only a smallish (yet loud) monitor type speaker 
was in front of the dj table for people up front.  it was strange to see 
larger crowds forming _away_ from the dj in front of the big speakers.  
but it was definitely a better distrbution of sound for this space giving 
more room for everyone to move.

-willis
walrus@quack.kfu.com

From: "Dana WATANABE" <DWATANAB@uci.edu>
Message-Id: <199408291650.AA19349@mothra.nts.uci.edu>
Subject: Ecstasy solving conflict in Northern Ireland? (fwd)
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com (sfraves@hyperreal.com)
Date: Mon, 29 Aug 94 9:50:39 PDT
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk
 
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.3 PL11]

> From: Nicholas Saunders <nicholas@neals.demon.co.uk>
> Date: Fri, 19 Aug 1994 07:00:52 GMT
> Newsgroups: alt.drugs
> Subject: Ecstasy solving conflict in Northern Ireland?
> 
> I've just returned from a trip to Northern Ireland, where I went to check
> out stories of Catholic and Protestant kids hugging each other and making
> lasting friendships at raves. Could this be the end of the 'troubles'
> where 25 years of political and military effort has failed?
> Well, this phenomenom is certainly happening and I got lots of kids
> telling me so. But not so remarkable really, as the sectarianism is not
> as rigid as I have been led to believe. 
> 
> The truth is pretty amazing though. The paramilitaries control the supply
> of drugs in raves by monopolising the wholesale market. The dealers are
> not part of them, but are allowed to operate providing they buy from para
> sources at inflated prices. This was started by the Loyalists and now
> copied by the Republicans, and each now controls the sale of drugs in
> rave clubs in their own territory. Naive kids who try to deal get beaten
> up as a first warning and if they don't take the hint are liable to be
> kneecapped.
> So the punter is in the position of having to put money into killing
> people, which is a pretty heavy responsibility. On the other hand, he
> never gets ripped off - the drugs are consistently good quality. And they
> only allow speed, E and acid, while in England amyl nitrate, coke,
> ketamine and even crack is sold in many clubs besides more alcohol being
> drunk. At the two clubs I went to (one IRA controlled and the other UVF
> controlled) it was like the good old days with 95% on E - a really
> wonderful and sweet atmosphere. The scene is fairly new, and seems to
> draw a very young crowd, nearly all under 20 and down to 14. It is
> delightful, fresh and sweet - just like the good old days of raves. I
> went to a small club with 200 on Friday (where the owner allowed me to
> interview) and a big one with 2,500 on Saturday. The first was controlled
> by the IRA and the second by the UVF, and I was pointed out their member
> who was keeing an eye on the dealers. As the punters came in, they were
> frisked and then within two yards offered drugs! Both events were
> tremendously successful, in spite of very strict laws that make them
> close at 1.30 sharp. And the reputation brought them several bus loads
> from England, even London (quite something, its as far as Amsterdam).
> The unexpected point repeated to me many times was that its not just E,
> its the new scene that's opened up new ways of socialising and meeting.
> Before there were (and still are) discos which were always considered
> partisan according to the area they were located, but rave clubs draw
> from a wider clientelle which includes both factions.
> Most of this information was gained by interviewing kids on E.
> The kids I interviewed all (except one) said they had made friendships
> that lasted at rave clubs that they could not have at discos. And they
> also emphasised that they had no trouble, while fights were common at
> discos and pubs, though not particularly due to sectarianism.
> -------------------------
> Nicholas Saunders
> (nicholas@neals.demon.co.uk)
> Author, _E_for_Ecstasy_  ftp://ftp.hmc.edu/pub/drugs/mdma/e.for.ecstasy.Z
> and e.for.ecstasy.append.Z.
> Read/Search it for information on Ecstasy (MDMA), inc Alexander Shulgin's
> Bibliography.  Updated 1994, please send me any new information.


 ,
dana

"it will be a great day when our schools get all the money they need
 and the air force has to hold a bake sale to buy a bomber"

Received: from pilot.njin.net by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.9/8.6.5) with SMTP id KAA17509; Mon, 29 Aug 1994 10:13:12 -0700
Received: by pilot.njin.net (5.59/SMI4.0/RU1.5/3.08) 
	id AA12815; Mon, 29 Aug 94 13:12:42 EDT
Date: Mon, 29 Aug 94 13:12:42 EDT
From: csc@pilot.njin.net (Sean Casey)
Message-Id: <9408291712.AA12815@pilot.njin.net>
To: Willis Wong <walrus@quack.kfu.com>
Cc: sfraves list <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
Subject: review: HOPE ...for a brighter tomorrow
In-Reply-To: <Pine.3.89.9408282123.A23781-0100000@quack.kfu.com>
References: <Pine.3.89.9408282123.A23781-0100000@quack.kfu.com>
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

 > An interesting thing with this setup was the main speakers were placed 
 > far away from the dj.  Only a smallish (yet loud) monitor type speaker 
 > was in front of the dj table for people up front.  it was strange to see 
 > larger crowds forming _away_ from the dj in front of the big speakers.  
 > but it was definitely a better distrbution of sound for this space giving 
 > more room for everyone to move.

I can't speak for everyone, but in my experience so far DJing the
further away the main system the easier it is to mix. F&FIII was a
real education in this respect. The main system was booming in over
the monitors, so I crank up the monitors, then my headphones can't get
loud enough to hear over the monitors! (why do some DJs tilt their head
to one side? to compress the earphone against their ear...). It was a
lot of work sorting out all the sounds, but something that should get
better with experience. I'll probably think about having some extra
headphone amplification available for those mixers that don't put out
a lot.

I am a fan of booming monitors at the DJ booth so people can jam right
there with the DJ. I also love a lot of DJ<->crowd interaction, as
it's just plain fun. I think that was the best part of spinning at
F&FIII, having my friends right there in my face and throwing that
energy back and forth. Whew!

Sean



From sfraves-owner  Mon Aug 29 10:18:36 1994

[Netcom's explanation for the duplicated messages]
 > > One side effect of the high loads on the mail servers is the occasional
 > > duplication of mail messages.  This behavior seems to be more common
 > > with mail originating from mailing lists.  We are researching solutions
 > > to the mail load problem, and expect to implement something within a
 > > week or so.

I've heard of this before on badly loaded sendmail systems. Either a
race condition or timeouts of the locks. I can imagine this happening
on a system with 30,000 users and one machine receiving all the
inbound mail. I'm curious to know how they plan to fix it.

Sean

Subject: RE: A LARGE soap box on the drug war
To: "David M. Ilstrup" <dmi@holonet.net>
cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
In-Reply-To: <199408290219.TAA01843@holonet.net>

On Sun, 28 Aug 1994, David M. Ilstrup wrote:

> Yes Tony, I empathize with you completely.
> 
> There was a clip with Prez. Clinton speaking to a group of teenagers on TV
> a few days ago. I think it was actually footage from back during the 
> campaign, but the drug thing is hot in the media right now... anyway,
> he said something like the following:
> 
> "You know, my brother was arrested for possession of cocaine awhile back
> and he did 14 months in prison, and then went into rehab. I'm glad it happened,
> because if it didn't; I'm sure he'd never have gone into rehab and he'd
> probably be dead by now."

All I can say is the president is obviously saying this in part to keep 
his public opinion up.  This country is in a "drug scare" that is almost 
as bad as the "red scare" of the 1950's.  And it is really sad, because I 
have met so many people out there that have so many misconceptions about 
drugs.  Look what happened when the surgeon general just hinted about the 
legalization of drugs.  I was afraid she was going to get the can.  There 
are no politicians that I know of out there that will even touch the 
subject of drugs unless they come out against them, because that is a 
sure-fire plan these days.  "stamp out drugs, stamp out crime, stamp out 
illegal activities".  It makes me angry.  When is this country going to 
grow up and pay attention to the real issues?  

> 
> <flame on>
> So what, Bill? So you've got it so together, that you can be president of the
> United States, and you can't even help your own brother with his drug problem?
> It's the responsibility of the police to arrest your brother, so that he can
> be helped with his drug problem? Would he be dead from doing coke, or dead
> from dealing with the wrong people; people he would never have seen were
> the substance legal. Is jail supposed to be healthier than getting high?
> <flame off>
> 
> You can see what I'm getting at.
> 
> This kind of thinking is especially scary to me, because it reminds me very
> strongly of the kind of thinking I'd hear from my own and my friends' parents
> when I was a teenager, and by extension perhaps reflects the thinking of a
> large portion of the people that support the WOD. People are so hysterical 
> about drugs, they feel like they need police to deal with their own relatives.
> This is irrational panic fueled by fear of the unknown.
> 
> This is why the need for *education* about the real effects, dangers and 
> potential rewards of various drugs is so great, IMHO. Knowledge tends to dispel
> fear, and replace panic with rational assessment. Obviously, there *is* the
> potential of negative effects of varying severity with different substances,
> but if this information is made available, and a substance is available in 
> known quantity and purity, the risks are minimized. Say if the FDA controlled
> drugs instead of the DEA.
> 
> At least there has been some of what I would call non-hysterical presentation
> of the issue recently in the media (at least on MTV, which isn't much from
> the standpoint of political influence, but at least it's national media).
> There still seems to be a real lack of agreement about physiological effects
> from long term and casual use of various schedule 1 substances.
> 
> Anyway, I guess the point is that I don't see how drug use can be treated
> as anything but a health issue. There is simply no justification for turning
> it into a crime.
> 
> -dmi
> 
>

To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: reviews
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk




A couple of reviews -

After wasting free passes for 1015 Folsom on some huge 
oldies office party I wound up with House music for $8
at the End Up last Friday night (a week ago).
I can't remember the official name but there was a big
"dance til ya drop" or some such banner out front.
Amusing people looking for FMR info from the doormen.
The music was good.  Fairly hard with a dash of 
diva to lighten it up.  Male strippers (sporting the
ever fashionable Tom Cruise in Diapers look) were an
added bonus.  Go with friends if you want to avoid flirting.
We were committed to boogie because a friend of a
friend and fellow dancing fool died of an overdose.
I would say the evening worked out great.
People.  Moving.  Keep your head On.

Tribal Funk this Saturday was $5 and in Oakland.  I knew I 
couldn't stay out late but I was buggy from a cold and too
much time at home so I went for awhile.  Small place, medium 
enthusiasm crowd, and the music was heavy rotation funky house.  
It was not a party that fit my mood, I guess.

Dave

Hi--

I'm taking advantage of posting my last to sfraves
for awhile by thanking those who came to and contributed
so much to my GAP on Saturday and Sunday:

Bryce for the Liquid Sound System which he didn't even
get a chance to spin on himself, except at the opening
set up time

Allen of ameba for rescuing us from our unplugged phase,
which because of his magick lasted only about an hour, for
spinning the most excellent seven or so hours heard anywhere
(Craig has made audio/video copies for me which we are all
welcome to copy!)--it would have been excellent no matter 
how long or short the time was!  Have *you* heard this guy spin?

Craig for the video projection *balls* that glowed all night
with his particular brand of computer-videography magick (again,
the audio-video record is now in the Penna archives!)

Laura for spinning a kicka** set that got us all going and if
that weren't enough her mere (*mere*?!) presence at the party
upped the energy and consciousness quotients a buzzillion points!

Ethan nrg Miller for the flamin' set that brought the law down,
but kept the party going until that magick tyme in Sanity Cruise
when all cords must be unplugged (around midnight), so we could
talk, communing with each other and with nature until Allen showed
us a way to plug in again

deepfog (Tony V Garcia) for doing a tremendous starter set that 
not only warmed us up but heated us to the quantum level we needed
to keep on our feet until midnight and beyond.  Keep this man in
mind for *your* next party!

jason d (Jason Davis--Robert Ernest's account on e-mail here) for
his seamless set that just kept flowing so endlessly thatI didn't
separate the records' bpm from my own (the rave equivalent of not
being able to separate the dance from the dancer). *This* is another
up-and-comer in our dj world to keep in mind! Yow!!!

Larry for being the beautiful man he always is, showing up late,
leaving late, making sure everything and everybody were a-okay!  It's
*always* a special energy when Larry is there, n'est-ce pas? A
buzzillion tahnks and loads of quantum karma, Larry!

Susan (No, I won't be spinning) Kamany (opps! I misspelled your
surname?!) for being there--which is an ingredient more important
than it sounds unless you've *been there* with Susan!

I *know* I've forgotten *someone* with direct or indirect sfr
connections, so *please* post me to amend this, any of you who
are more prescient than I right now!  Please note my new Marin
county phone number as of Sept. 2 below.  I'll still be reachable
personally at my e-mail address below, but after tomorrow I won't
be on sfraves for awhile.  It's Peru in October - November and
India, etc., later in the winter.  Any tips any of you have I'll
welcome!

Bless you/us all!
Namaste,

will

From sfraves-owner  Tue Aug 30 03:23:25 1994
Return-Path: owner-sfraves
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.9/8.6.5) id DAA28200; Tue, 30 Aug 1994 03:23:25 -0700

Received: from eabbs.UUCP by netcomsv.netcom.com with UUCP (8.6.4/SMI-4.1)
	id DAA27669; Tue, 30 Aug 1994 03:20:15 -0700
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Tribal Funk
From: harmoniz@eabbs.com (Harmoniz)
Message-ID: <17862.1.uupcb@eabbs.com>
Date: Mon, 29 Aug 94 19:59:00 -0800
Organization: Easy Access BBS - San Ramon CA - 510-829-7627
Reply-To: harmoniz@eabbs.com (Harmoniz)
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

David's assessment of Tribal Funk seems pretty accurate, though he
clearly didn't stay to the end.
The site was an old abandoned night club, in some ways ideal - except
that there was only one WC!
To keep a VERY low profile, there were no in's and out's (which made
sense this time) and no one allowed in after 2 am (normal bar closing
time).
Jazz E was a no show, so DJ Utopia from Redding spun instead between 1
and 2:45 - this must have been when David was there, it was a good set,
but pretty standard house fare.
At 2:45 Tony came on and minutes later the Oakland Police arrived. :-(
The overhead spinning color light was taken down at that time - I'm not
sure if that was Tony's request or due to the police visit :-).
The police looked everything over, especially the display for Cloud
Nine, complete with neon light and full color brochures - I guess they
figured out that illicit substances don't have ads. :-)
While this was going on, the main speakers failed, but people continued
to dance, seemingly unaware, just to the sound from the (rather large)
DJ monitors.  When this was fixed, it produced the biggest positive
reaction of the evening :-).
Minutes later, the promoters stopped everything to announce that the
cops had to shut it down because they didn't have a permit - BUT, they
were going to allow them to continue to 4 am anyway (about 35-40 minutes
more).
So, Tony played another 20 minutes of tribally trancey sounds, followed
by only 20 minutes for Josh, who finished with "We Are Family" with
everyone holding hands in the air.
I think that there's an advantage in being in Oakland; the cops were
probably relieved that there were no weapons, alcohol or overt drug use
and so probably said to themselves "they're good kids, let's give them a
few more minutes".  Whereas in small-town-suburbia, they would have said
"what bad kids, wildly dancing to weird loud music, we better stop it
now." (Santa Cruz, perhaps?).
The one major downer was SO MUCH smoke in the air - maybe smoking is
more hip in the East Bay?  I can understand why the Captain is looking
for mostly outdoors events now (he also hates the smoke).
I wish smoking would some day become un-cool!  (fat chance)
h

actually got sexually harassed by some guy in a cheesy turtleneck 
shirt/sweater...having been familiar w/ gay dance clubs for a long
time (79?), i was surprised at the brazen (?!) attitude this guy had.
i'm dancing away, probably w/ a really dumb look on my face (my initial
impression was that the perpetrator thought I was too high to defend
myself...not!) when this hand came swingin' down around toward me butt!
at the last second i noticed this and grabbed the wrist just prior to 
contact.  i gave the guy a look like "oh no you don't!" and let go, 
thinking that this was over...next, he came dancing over and gyrates
by me, intentionally bumping into me and kinda reaching near, but not
actually grabbing this time...so i moved away slightly to give him
more room...he follows me and it becomes obvious that this is intentional.
for the next several minutes every time i think that i've managed to
survive the episode, dude comes over and either bumps or brushes up
against me or starts reachin' fo shit again...finally he tries to put his
hand on my waist or near there and i have to grab him by both shoulders and
firmly say "dude!  get off my tip!!!   ok?!?!?"  i let go and he starts
clucking to his friends acting like I'm harassing him!!!  after i physically
made it clear that i would accept no more, he quit, but I had to go to
that length...it was wierd and tho i'm not damaged by it, it further
underscores what women have told me for years about dealing w/ pushy men.
the part that really got me was how indignant he got when he couldn't get 
his way, truly amazing.  dude was *not* a raver, as far as I could tell.

however, 15-20 mins later, it was history, forgotten till the comment
above reminded me.  that was an amazing party, this little eye opener
not withstanding...I gotta check out jon howard more...

Jocelyn Cordell writes:
 > Lately in ba.mountain-folk there's been a discussion about
 > the practices/policies of CAMP (Citizens Against 
 > Marijuana Planting). Apparently, they fly their 
 > helicopters very low over the SC mountains. Someone said 
 > that they weren't allowed to fly below 1000 ft, though 
 > they've been spotted at ~300ft. Guess what- they're 
 > main benefactor is Anhauser Busch! 

Get their tail number and report the violation the FAA. Federal regs
require civilian aircraft to fly a minimum of 500' over uninhabited
areas and 1000' over inhabited ones except during takeoff and landing.
If more than one person calls, it will be taken quite seriously.

There also may be violation of privacy issues involved. It's one thing
to take pictures from the air. It's another to take close ups. Someone
with a fence or a wooded property has a reasonable expectation of
privacy.

Fight back!

Sean

the people in the main dance area.  This area is usually

Some of us are going to the BURNING MAN festival in the Blasck Rock

live it up!

wanna do is party and rave!

as well as some other interesting musical stuff.

Lectures..
Skeet Golf :)

Mijos! Sunset has been consistantly my favourite party. Outdoors, bay-view,
wave goodby to  Mr. Sun, kites, kids, dogs, sun/moon, shootin' stah,
smiles, dancing, talking, lounging, fruit, bubbles, energy, rest, no busts,
free, long,  Galen et al.

toys. The 21 and ups, the younger crowds, so much innocence, so many
smiles, knowing nods,  such exchange of love. Even if your weekend has
drained you, this is the place to recharge, or spend what's left of your
energy. 

Obviously, I had a wonderful,playful day. Love to all, beeeeee happy!

Hello! I have received written or emailed responses from 15 individuals,
and accounted for another 3, bringing our total to 18.  That leaves 3
individuals who were issued citations at Oyster Bay Regional Shoreline
who have not contacted me.

If you folks are out there, or any of you know how to get in touch with
them, please ask them if they would provide me with information on how
to get in touch with them (and possibly the attorney).  I can be reached
at brycer@crl.com, or 415.642.9791.  Thanks.

Also, FYI, Ultima.Org, and by extension, the oyster-gate mailing list, have
been having a series of problems over the past week.  Pardon the inconvenience.
The problems should be repaired shortly.  At this time, the list is 
inoperative.

(hello everyone, I finally got back on)

(Pullman was great)

anyway, I just glanced and read something to effect that smoke machines
weren't as bad as cigarettes..I dunno.  I don't smoke, but I really
hate smoke machines.  how many of us have left a party imagining our 
lungs coated with the smoke machine crap coated on our shoes?

I hate smoke machines.  I don't care if Rosco and all of those heads make
supposedly safe smoke machines, they still stink (pina colada flavor not
withstanding) and I don't know how they can be much better than cigaret
smoke...
at least with cigarets you can run.  It seems that a lot of the smoke machine
operators out there just want to completely gas the crowd...it sucks,
especially in small places..

just my non cents...

see ya all at Groove Kitzch and probably Spundaes..

(have a good week)
mike

hey jocelyn,

how's it going?  did you see the recent pfunk shows?  [i met you
at a pfunk outting at circle star > 1 yr ago w/ my wife les]

On Tue, 30 Aug 1994, Jocelyn Cordell wrote:

> Spun can scratch, but I don't know if the scratches 
> on his CD can be attributed to him. I would be 
> willing to bet that some, but certainly not all, 
> of the scratching is his doing. 
-----------------------------------------------
some of it sounds like he did it because of differences in the fidelity
of the scratches, i.e. some of the scratching is really clear and up front
while other scratches are more muffled/buried in the mix/sound like more
recording generations, etc.  it also sounded like jon howard was cutting
live at together (godDAMN that was the shit!), which set my blood to
boilin', it sucks if the dj is just doing tricks (or it *can* anyway),
but the art of scratch is a serious musical innovation in the right hands.


> In the interest of DJ history- Spun was a hip hop 
> DJ before he was a rave DJ- in the mid to late 
> eighties? 
-----------------------------------------------
i never heard about him back then, but i usta groove to doc martin at
the firehouse 7 (16th st., SF) back when he was spinnin' shit like
"life is..." and "dopeman", etc.  doc has some serious skills and is the
1st house/rave/etc. dj I got into (I had written house off as slap-
together-bar-music prior to hearing doc spin some of the heavily
percussive stuff he used to spin at townsend when he was there alot).
now i'm feeling a tilt back to da funk, and i must say, i ain't
complainin'...

-=j=-

To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: ravnbird@crl.com (RavnBird, Denis)
Subject: Re: reviews, Mix Club Ettiquette.
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

On Tuesday, Aug. 30, 1994 Tenderloin Waxx writes:

>On Mon, 29 Aug 1994, David Alves wrote:
>
>> added bonus.  Go with friends if you want to avoid flirting.
>------------------
>while i had a great time at together, i had a short-lived bummer when i
>actually got sexually harassed by some guy

This has been a very interresting topic of mine as of lately.  I'm a big
advocate of inclusion and mix groups.  I feel it is the only way to disarm
prejudice and intollerance, be it color, age, sex and orientation.  I
sometimes wonder what is appropriate behavior when you find yourself having
a sexual advance made to you by a person of the same sex (or opposite sex)
if you are of different orientation?

>i was surprised at the brazen (?!) attitude this guy had.
(read Tenderloin Waxx's posting "Re: reviews" for complete details).

>From your posting it sounds like you were bothered primarily because this
guy would not give up and that he became indignant he couldn't get his own
way.  Maybe because of the way you detailed quite graphically your
encounter makes me believe that you were anoyed more at the fact that he
was gay (or at least not your idea of a good looking individual no matter
what orientation he was). ---But that's probably beside the point as you
seem familiar with dancing at gay clubs---.

The point I'm trying to get at is the fact that in a mixed group we will
all sooner or later face this type of behavior and I feel there should be a
proper way to handle each other.
I've never been to "Together" so I do not know if it's a "gay" or "mix"
crowd.  But let's assume that mister X thought he was at a gay club.  Does
it give him the right to be blunt about his sexual advances.  Personnally I
feel that any public encounters should be handle with certain reservations
at first, until a certain understanding has been established.  I love to
dance with anyone (man or woman) and it usually feels great knowing we're
in the same frame of mind.

Keeping Tenderloin Waxx's story in mind, here is a story about an encounter
I had just a few weeks back.  This is a very simple innocent happening but
I still remember it to this day.  I was dancing by myself, in high orbit
with the music, and this guy walks to me.  He tells me a few words and my
natural reaction is to hold him by the waist so I can hear better.  *Very*
abruptly, he pushes both my hands away as if I did something to insult him.
Now he walks away and I'm left to wonder what that was all about.  Was I
staring at him earlier from my high plateau?  Did he think I was making a
gay pass at him?  Never could figure it out.  The point is still respect
and proper communication.  Being secure with oneself and being open to
diversity. (That is a beautiful peaceful picture to me).

>his way, truly amazing.  dude was *not* a raver, as far as I could tell.

Correct me if I'm wrong but I believe that blatant sexual behavior is more
prominent in "clubs" rather than at "raves".

Feed this thread for awhile.
I'm curious about your thoughts on mix club ettiquette.

Denis,  ravnbird@crl.com

Fog machines when overused are vile.  I owe a winter of chronic
bronchitis to a fog machine with weird molds growing in the
geletin-based juice.

In case anyone is wondering, I'm working in my new job now and
it's cool.  I got to buy a new wardrobe, too (no more jeans and
Ren & Stimpy t-shirts in the office).

When Judge gets an estimate of how much it would cost to put the 
alley-door into the main room at Komotion, could he let me know?

I love the idea of having a hip-hop DJ at a party.  For a while
in Baltimore they had hip-hop "chill" rooms that we're so chill they
were hot :-).  Also, a few renegades in New Jersey had a DJ that did
a hip-hop set.  It was a really cool change.  I also like the idea
of hearing an industrial/EBM set, too.  I used to get so tranced out
to the likes of Front 242 even before I realized what it was to trance
to music.  Variety yes!  

Laura

In CH's "Stoned is the way of the Walk":

"Remeber Sister Maggie? Breasts were kind of saggy
' Used to sell me buddha out of fucked up little baggies.
Set me up with ..(?).. even when I had no money,
she said pay me back with some latin dick honey."

Catholic nun selling pot in return for sexual favors.

A note on CH:  There first album was written and produced for black\hispanic
kids in the city, and I tend to believe all the stories.  The second album was
written and produced for white kids in the suburbs, and I think most of those
songs are fantasy.

A few other random thoughts:

Sunset was not quite as good this time.  The kids have found out about it.
Lots of poseurs (ie, kids who have the look but never dance).  I could do
without the obnoxious, self-important meth heads.  (the mello meth heads
are okay).

Fog is just sugar and water, your mucous traps it and moves it pretty
easily.  Smoke is vile chemicals.  Fog does not really bother me, smoke
does.  But hey, I know you are all addicted, so I don't mind too much.
Of course, if anyone wants to fill a room with some *kind* of non-addictive
plant smoke, I wouldn't mind. 

Hope was great after 5:00am, when we got there.  Tribal Funk was fun, but a
bit claustrophobic.

-troy

Just a quick reminder to let everyone know about
the SFR South Bay Lunch ...

When: Wednesday  
Time: 12:15ish to 1:15 or so ... 
Where: Greer Park, Palo Alto

Directions:

* From 101 (South or North) take the Oregon Expressway Exit
  Northbound: Past San Antonio Road 
  Southbound: Past University Avenue 

* Left at the first signal - W. Bayshore
  (it's a frontage road that takes you south again)

* Follow this road approx. 1/4 mile (pass apartment complexes on right)
  
* You will see the park on your right hand side. Turn into the first 
  driveway on your right.

* We'll meet on the grassy knoll , behind the round baseball fence.
  Next to the restrooms and ball courts.

Bring lunch, toys, yourselves!

I too hate those smoke machines.

someone said that the fog doesnt smell as bad
as cigarette smoke, but I beg to differ,
I have never smelled worse than after a party with
one of those things.  My underware, my socks everything
saturated with sticky fog wierdo stuff.  

Plus, Im not a chronic athsma sufferer, I only get
it from super aerobic activity, and never from 
dancing to house music, Except when there is a 
fog machine.  
(A freind with more severe athsma problems has had
to wait outside a club more than once from fog, 
Im sure poor ventilation and cigarettes played a
part, but it was the fog that got him gagging.)

Perhaps it isnt carcenogenic, but still, Im sure
that it cant possibly be good for you.  
I wonder if there is a way to get more info on
what it does consist of, and what it does inside
of you...
does anyone know?
I have always kinda wondered if it was doing me 
any great harm....

I just had to comment on this thread
thanks

On Tue, 30 Aug 1994 jesus.chrysler@sfnet.com wrote:

> Welp, think about it:  it could well have done him a good service.  Prison is
> kind of an enforced rehab.  Rehab the hard way.  So in this way, he's right. 

	From a few of the reports I have heard, quite a few of our 
country's "corrective" facilities are quite infested with the substances 
that could put one in there in the first place. (Where I heard this, I 
have forgotten so I guess you would have to take my word on it) Thus, 
prison does not always constitute forced rehab, nor even forced detox. 
Furthermore, one's environment plays a great role in someone going sober. 
Although a physical addiction may be ended in some prisons by a simple 
lack of the addictive substance, the accompanying mental addiction or 
craving will not necessarily be broken as well.  

dave
