Received: from smtpgwprod.ny.jpmorgan.com (smtpgwprod.ny.jpmorgan.com [146.149.1.22]) by tcpg01a.ny.jpmorgan.com (8.6.9/cjy.sub.1.0)
           with SMTP id JAA19541
Message-Id: <199408311348.JAA19541@tcpg01a.ny.jpmorgan.com>
Date: 31 Aug 1994 06:51:17 U
From: "Veglia, M." <veglia_m@jpmorgan.com>
Subject: RE: smoke machines.
To: "LACHUGA" <ALYATES@SCUACC.SCU.EDU>, sfraves@hyperreal.com
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Don't quote me on this, but someone that worked at Club Oasis in SF a couple
years ago said that most of the "good" fog machines, meaning the ones that
produce thick and dense smoke, use an oil-based fluid that is somehow
transformed into fog.  This oil-based crap is very bad for you, and many of the
employees of the club reported nausea and shortness of breath when the machine
was used consistently.  This is just a second-hand report, but it does
illustrate the point.

Unfortunately, I like fog when used properly with lasers and other light
sources to produce cool and eerie effects but not at the expense of my or
anyone else's health.

I know that dry ice is much better for you, but the drawback is that it is
somewhat dangerous to have around and use regularly, from what I hear.  The
other downside to dry ice is the fog is not quite as dense.

Just my observations and what I've heard...

Emcee Vee

just say... "sorry, I'm straight". If ur gay, and the person is straight, just

bastard know that u won't tolerate it...

gay or straight, should feel that they have to put up with unwelcome advances!!!

Off the soapbox :)

From sfraves-owner  Wed Aug 31 10:25:01 1994
Return-Path: owner-sfraves
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.9/8.6.5) id KAA17567; Wed, 31 Aug 1994 10:25:01 -0700
Received: from pilot.njin.net by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.9/8.6.5) with SMTP id KAA17559; Wed, 31 Aug 1994 10:24:57 -0700
Received: by pilot.njin.net (5.59/SMI4.0/RU1.5/3.08) 
	id AA21946; Wed, 31 Aug 94 13:24:36 EDT
Date: Wed, 31 Aug 94 13:24:36 EDT
From: csc@pilot.njin.net (Sean Casey)
Message-Id: <9408311724.AA21946@pilot.njin.net>
To: YOUR FRIEND MIKE <MROMO@scuacc.scu.edu>
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: smoke machines vs. smoke
In-Reply-To: <01HGJ2CH6DEA001LM0@scuacc.scu.edu>
References: <01HGJ2CH6DEA001LM0@scuacc.scu.edu>
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

YOUR FRIEND MIKE writes:
 > anyway, I just glanced and read something to effect that smoke machines
 > weren't as bad as cigarettes..I dunno.  I don't smoke, but I really
 > hate smoke machines.  how many of us have left a party imagining our 
 > lungs coated with the smoke machine crap coated on our shoes?

Smoke machine smoke is vaporized water and glycerine along with other
stuff to keep it from clogging the fog machine. It is non-toxic, and
as far as any research has shown, is not bad for your health.

It is a problem for asthmatics, as is cigarette smoke. Some people
find it annoying, some people really like it. Few people like it when
it's overdone. Lasers and fog are very very cool.

Sean

Brian McGonigle writes:

 > IMHO, no-one of any gender or orientation should make overt passes
 > at anyone else of any gender or orientation. Putting ur hands on
 > someone's ass ain't cool no matter what the situation/orientation
 > is...

I don't think it's that simple. In some circumstances, it is
acceptable (and expected) behavior. In others, it is abhorred.
Unfortunately, we have so much diversity in person and venue in the
scene, it's hard to get anyone to agree what the rules are.

I think in any case, if someone indicates a negative, it should be
dropped. But, to play the devil's advocate, where does that leave room
for persuasion? I had a very nice 2 year relationship because I got
persuaded.

Rules? Can we make rules?

Sean

From: csc@pilot.njin.net (Sean Casey)
Message-Id: <9408311757.AA23743@pilot.njin.net>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: What is your Fog Rating?
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Assume an indoor event with good ventilation. What level of fog are
you comfortable with? Assume non-toxic water based fog.

0. No fog at all.
1. Very light, occasional fog. (minor lighting enhancer)
2. Light occasional fog. (good laser enhancer)
3. Moderate fog.  (some visibility loss)
4. Zero visibility "where am I?" fog at some times.

Date: Wed, 31 Aug 1994 12:01:58 -0800
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: ravnbird@crl.com (RavnBird, Denis)
Subject: Re: What is your Fog Rating?
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

>Assume an indoor event with good ventilation. What level of fog are
>you comfortable with? Assume non-toxic water based fog.


>2. Light occasional fog. (good laser enhancer)

I would go level #2 in most cases because most places saturate real fast
with smoke and it can get to be a little nasty to breadth...

>3. Moderate fog.  (some visibility loss)

...but I don't mind level #3 either.  Awhile back I was dancing on the
upper level at DV8 and they had a fog machine spewing right over your head
(you know how low the ceiling is upstairs).  Well, I think that was
somewhat overkill (a definite level #4) but for some reason I enjoyed the
mood it created.  The loss of some visibility can change the atmosphere so
drastically that I thought I was being transported in different location
altogether.  You closed your eyes for a few minutes and you were with a big
crowd then the next minute you were in a more intimate room with only a few
faces visible through the fog.

Denis,  ravnbird@crl.com

From: Brian Behlendorf <brian@sfraves.org>
Subject: Raving in an Underground Nuclear Bomb Shelter in Russia [ddowden@artworld.com (Derek J. Dowden)] (fwd)
To: sfraves@sfraves.org
Message-ID: <Pine.3.89.9408311202.D18666-0100000@taz.hyperreal.com>

---------- Forwarded message ----------
Date: Wed, 31 Aug 1994 17:33:40 +0100
From: ddowden@artworld.com (Derek J. Dowden)
Subject: Raving in an Underground Nuclear Bomb Shelter in Russia

I guess you sf-ravers can't just drive up here for next weekend, but I
thought you might be interested anyway. I just spent Saturday night at the
Tunnel, corner of Lyubansky Pereulok and Zverinskaya Ul in St. Petersburg,
Russia.
The club features trance, house and ambient music in a converted
underground nuclear bomb shelter. The cover charge was 10,000 roubles which
works out to about $8. I couldn't find out who the dj was but the music mix
was quite current. Many people were quite cool (from my cultural
perspective), but there was an interesting contingent of young women
dressed in 'office secretary 1945'. I have a broken leg (rollerblading) so
I danced on one leg there. It ran all night (11am - 6pm) but we
unfortunately we had to leave about 1:30 because we did not have visas and
unless we returned to our ship by 2am we would be fined about 300,000
roubles.
Also, if you happen to be in Helsinki, I recommend the e-club. The cover is
about 20 FIM, and the hours are 9pm to 4am, though no one gets there til
midnight. The address is Mannerheimintie 3, contact Elukka Eskelinen of
PopZoo Productions at +358-40-5010017 for details. It is in some ancient
ornate ballrooms, divided into dance and chill areas and holds about 300
people. The night I was there they had DJs General Njassa and Magic Sam
(Finland) and DJ Mixmaster Morris (UK). Also they had 'Virtual Nightclub'
projected on the wall, a really interesting interactive rave simulation on
Mac CD-Rom from London.

Derek.

Date: 31 Aug 1994 12:40:59 U
From: "Veglia, M." <veglia_m@jpmorgan.com>
Subject: RE: What is your Fog Rating?
To: "RavnBird, Denis" <ravnbird@crl.com>, sfraves@hyperreal.com
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

When Denis mentioned DV8's upstairs room, it brought back a cool memory.
I remember when that Enigma song got popular, and DV8 had the upstairs
"ballroom" decorated with some ancient Greek (as I recall...) pillars, columns,
and statues.  That room had the "Wall-o-strobe" which when facing it without
fog would be as blinding as the sun!  Anyway, the DJ, someone remarkable, but
the name escapes me, would be playing music, and at the end of a song, he would
dowse the lights, fill the room with fog, then start the Gregorian intro to
that Enigma song.  The room would feel cold almost, even though there were many
people close together.  When the deep bass kicked in, the "Wall-o-strobe" would
kick in as well as the moving overhead lights.  The effect was awesome.

Ahh the good ole days...
(-=mcv=-)

PS:  I guess that means that I like level 4 fog rating, but with an
explanation.  Generally I prefer 3-4 based on the healthful,
for-the-fun-of-it-type fog.

"Smiles, everyone. Smiles!"  - Mr. Rourke, "Fantasy Island"

Fog machines do very little for me
In fact, light shows don't do much for me either
They are like black lights - sometimes too bright and
harsh and in your face.  Like everything at a party 
it is cool if escape is possible when desired.
(away from smokers, lights, heat ...)

I like people
lots of beautiful people

If I hit-on a woman like I've been hit-on by men 
I would be slapped.  And "hit-on", to me, is already
a brutish version of something that can be subtle
and exciting.  I don't care where you are I think
you should be respectful.  You are wrong if you
are using your location (club/party) as an excuse
to shortcut dealing with people on an individual
basis.

I wish someone would tell me about Groove Kitchen
This is a party with some history, no?

If not a full blown underground hiphop party then
maybe hiphop to crazy old acid with a clean end   
and fabulous people.  Get down.

I think variety is good, and can work as a theme
unto itself.  Too mixed up can throw me. 

Dave

place I know of his soul disco records on 15th & market in San Francisco.

else and you can hear some of the cuts before you buy...

According to a friend of mine who works for American Cyanamid, the
"dry fog" is a polymer and is exteremely save (it's been tested
for the usual carcinogenic kinds of things).  "Wet fog" is geletin
based (as in Jell-o) and so isn't carcinogenic as such BUT if people
don't clean out the fog machine weird mold can grow in it which you
could, in turn, inhale.

Laura

Thus I Through You Spew Your Pathetic Drivel At I
I Speak For I

Actively Seeks To Destroy Communication

Throw A Thought Into The Air
Others Will Seek Out The Thought

Trample A Thought Into The Mud
And You Manifest The Basest Form Of Despicableness
As Others Are Led To Watch On In Glee

Via Aqueductus Inforum Pluurum
Manifest Projection To The Infinite
